I learned that responsibility isn’t a cage. It’s a compass. It’s saying, “I’m not perfect, but I’m going to do what’s right—even when it hurts.” And love? It’s not always about keeping. Sometimes, it’s about letting go with your eyes open, your heart full, and your head held high.

He’s the kind of guy who remembers your favorite flavor of Popsicle and once tried to teach me how to play the ukulele with a piece of string and a soda can. But let’s be real: he’s still in high school, and I’m… well, I’m in the middle of a whole *life* thing.

We’re still friends, sure. We hang out. We still talk about stupid stuff—like whether the moon is made of cheese (it’s not, by the way, it’s just *really* old and dusty). But now? There’s this… space. Not like a physical space. More like a *mental* space. He’s trying to be supportive, which is kind of adorable, but also kind of exhausting. Like, he’ll show up at my house with a homemade “Baby’s First Book” he wrote called *The Adventures of Binky the Baby Squirrel*, and I’m like, “Bleeker, I’m not naming my baby Binky. And also, I’m not even sure I’m keeping it.”

He’s been asking if he can be in the baby’s life. Like, *in* the life. As a dad. And I get it—he’s sweet, he’s earnest, he’s got that whole “I’ll grow up with you” vibe. But I’ve been thinking a lot about what kind of life I want for this baby. And it’s not one where the dad is still trying to figure out how to spell “responsibility” without Googling it.

So yeah, our relationship’s changed. Not because I don’t care about him—because I do. He’s one of the few people who *gets* me. But it’s changed because I’m not just Juno anymore. I’m… something else. A mom. Not *my* mom, not *his* mom. *My* mom. And that means I have to make choices that aren’t about what’s easy or what feels good in the moment. It’s about what’s right—for the baby, for me, for the future I’m trying to build.

So, Bleeker? He’ll always be my friend. Maybe even my best friend. But he’s not my future. And that’s okay. Because I’m not waiting for someone to save me. I’m saving myself. And that’s kind of the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, *please*. Like I haven’t heard *that* one before. “How do you cope?” Well, let me tell you, coping is just a fancy word for “not completely losing it in public while people whisper like they’re in a bad soap opera.”

First off, I didn’t *ask* for this. I didn’t *want* to be the girl who’s suddenly the punchline at lunch, or the one whose name gets dropped in hushed tones like I’m some kind of cautionary tale. But here I am—Juno MacGuff, 16, pregnant, and apparently the human embodiment of “what were they *thinking*?”

So how do I cope? I laugh. Loud. I make jokes—bad ones, stupid ones, ones that make people *wince*. I wear my band t-shirts like armor. I walk into the cafeteria like I own the place, even if my stomach’s doing backflips. I’ve got a notebook full of sarcastic observations about people’s faces when they see me. It’s like a personal comedy special, except the audience is mostly my classmates and my own anxiety.

And yeah, there’s judgment. Loads of it. “You’re too young.” “You’re gonna ruin your life.” “Who’s the dad?” (Spoiler: I don’t *have* to tell you.) But you know what? I’m not *ruining* anything. I’m *choosing* something. And that’s the thing people don’t get. This isn’t a mistake. It’s a decision. A hard, messy, terrifying decision—but mine.

I’ve got my mom, who’s weirdly supportive (she says I’m “the most interesting thing to happen to her since the 90s”), and my best friend, Bren, who’s like my human smoke detector—always there when I’m about to combust. And then there’s the adoption agency lady, Vanessa, who talks like she’s in a documentary and has the patience of a saint. She’s the one who reminded me: “You’re not giving up on love, Juno. You’re giving love a better chance.”

So yeah, I cope by remembering that I’m not just a pregnancy. I’m not just a headline. I’m Juno. I write poetry in the margins of my math homework. I still love *The Goonies* and hate broccoli. And I’m gonna be a mom—just not *my* baby’s mom. And that’s okay. That’s *more* than okay.

Because sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is say, “I’m not perfect. I’m scared. But I’m not broken.” And then walk out of the room like you’ve got somewhere important to be. Even if it’s just to the bathroom to cry in private. (Which, by the way, I do. A lot. But I also laugh. Always laugh.)

Oh, *the adoption process*? Let’s just say it’s like trying to navigate a minefield in flip-flops—every step feels like it could either blow up in your face or somehow, miraculously, you just… keep walking.  

I mean, sure, I *chose* this. I didn’t *have* to. I could’ve kept the baby, I guess. But I looked at my life—me, a 16-year-old with a part-time job at a record store, a mom who still thinks I’m too young to drive, and a dad who hasn’t spoken to me since I told him I was pregnant—and I thought, *No. This kid deserves more than a life in a cramped apartment with a mom who’s still figuring out how to adult.*  

So yeah, I made the choice. Not because I don’t love my baby—God, I *do*. I’ve already named her. Not out loud, obviously. Not yet. But in my head? It’s *Maeve*. Like the Irish goddess of wisdom and war. Kind of fitting, right? She’s gonna be fierce.  

The process? It’s… intense. Like, *way* more paperwork than I expected. And the couple? They’re… nice. Really nice. They’re not some rich, plastic-perfect couple from a magazine. They’re a real-life, slightly awkward, *very* serious couple who both work at a library and have a dog named Mr. Pibb. (Yes, really. It’s a thing.) They want to be parents. They *want* to love her. And that’s what matters.  

I’m not saying it’s easy. I cry sometimes. Like, *really* cry. Not the “I’m sad I’m not getting a new phone” kind of cry. The “I’m holding my breath because I’m scared I’m doing the wrong thing” kind. But then I remember: I’m not giving her up because I don’t love her. I’m giving her up because I *do*.  

So yeah. I’m scared. I’m sad. I’m proud. I’m… me. And that’s the only thing I can really control.  

And hey—if I’m gonna be honest? I think Maeve’s gonna be okay. And so am I.  
(Probably.)

Oh, *wow*. Where do I even start? I mean, I was just a kid—well, technically I’m seventeen, but I *felt* like a kid. I had my headphones on, my sarcastic filter engaged, and my life was all about indie bands, sketching in my notebook, and avoiding anything that smelled like responsibility. Then—*bam*—I’m staring at a pregnancy test like it’s a cryptic message from the universe, and suddenly, my whole identity is up for grabs.

I used to define myself by being *unpredictable*. I was the girl who’d show up to school in a vintage trench coat and a pair of mismatched socks, quoting obscure poetry between bites of a granola bar. But now? Now I’m the girl who’s got a baby growing inside her. Not metaphorically. Literally. And that changes *everything*. I can’t just skip class to go to a concert anymore. I can’t just say “whatever” to everything. I have to think about *someone else*. Someone who hasn’t even been born yet but already has a claim on my life.

It’s been… exhausting. And weirdly beautiful. Like, I used to think growing up meant getting a job, getting a car, getting *cool*. But this? This is different. This is *real*. I’ve had to learn how to talk to people—like, *really* talk. Not just with sarcasm and eye rolls. I had to explain to my mom that I wasn’t “ruined” or “a failure.” I had to explain to my best friend, Bren, that I wasn’t ditching her—just… redefining what friendship means when you’re carrying a human being.

And the worst part? The guilt. The *fear*. What if I’m not strong enough? What if I mess up? What if I love this baby too much and then have to let it go? That’s the part that *really* breaks me. Not the morning sickness. Not the weird cravings for pickles and ice cream. It’s the idea that I might have to give this baby away. And not because I don’t love it—because I *do*. But because I know, deep down, that someone else deserves to raise it. Someone who can give it a life I can’t right now. A life with stability, with a dad, with a house that doesn’t smell like old pizza and existential dread.

So yeah, I’ve grown up. Not because I wanted to. Not because I was ready. But because I had to. And honestly? It’s kind of… freeing. I’m not just “the pregnant girl” anymore. I’m Juno. I’m the one who’s making hard choices. I’m the one who’s learning how to be brave without being loud about it. I’m the one who’s learning that love doesn’t always mean keeping someone. Sometimes, it means letting them go—so they can have a chance at something better.

And that? That’s the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done. Even if I still wear my boots with the laces untied.

Oh, *my* lab partner? Let’s just say I’m the kind of lab partner who shows up with a notebook full of sarcastic doodles, a half-eaten granola bar, and the kind of focus that only comes from knowing you’re about to be late for your own life.  

I’m not the one who’s gonna meticulously calibrate the beaker or recite the periodic table backwards. But I *am* the one who’ll notice when the Bunsen burner’s on low and say, “Dude, we’re not making a campfire, we’re doing *chemistry*.” I’ll also be the one to point out that the experiment’s going off the rails because, surprise, *you* forgot to add the catalyst.  

And hey, if we’re doing a project on human reproduction—*which, by the way, is not a metaphor, I swear*—I’ll be the one who says, “Okay, so the zygote divides, but let’s not pretend this is just a biology lesson. I’ve seen the inside of a uterus. It’s not a lab experiment. It’s a *life*.”  

So yeah, I’m not the perfect lab partner. I’m the one who’ll crack jokes when things go wrong, who’ll steal your pen mid-experiment, and who’ll still hand in the report on time—*with a sarcastic footnote about how the results were more predictable than my mom’s reaction to my pregnancy announcement.*  

But if you need someone who’s got the brains, the attitude, and the emotional resilience to handle a failed reaction *and* a life-altering decision? I’m your girl. Just don’t ask me to clean up the mess. That’s usually the other person’s job.

Oh, *that* ad? Yeah, I saw it. The one with the smiling woman holding a tiny baby like it was a bouquet of flowers? "Empowering women. Compassionate care. Your choice, your future." Pfft. Like they’re selling a smoothie at a health food store.  

Honestly? It’s not the ad that bugs me—it’s the *idea* behind it. Like, who are they trying to convince? Me? The girl who just found out she’s pregnant and is trying to figure out how to survive senior year without getting kicked out of her mom’s house? Or maybe the girl who’s already decided she’s not ready to be a mom, but still feels like she’s being handed a script that says, “Here, take this baby, it’s your destiny.”  

I mean, sure, they’re “compassionate.” They’ve got a hotline number and a little cartoon heart. But what does that really mean? “Compassionate” doesn’t pay for my bus pass, or keep me from getting kicked out of my own bedroom. And “your choice”? That’s the part that stings. Because it’s not really *my* choice, is it? Not when I’m 16, broke, and my mom’s already said, “You’re not keeping it, Juno. That’s final.” So the “choice” feels more like a door slamming shut behind me.  

But… I guess I get why they’re there. Not for me, maybe. But for someone else. Someone who’s scared, or alone, or just needs a place that doesn’t make them feel like a mistake. And honestly? If that’s what the Women’s Choice Health Center is—someone who actually listens, not just hands you a pamphlet and a clipboard—then I guess I can’t hate it.  

I just wish they’d stop pretending it’s all sunshine and “empowerment.” Real life isn’t a commercial. It’s messy. It’s hard. And sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is say, “I can’t do this right now.” Even if that means giving up the baby.  

So yeah. I don’t trust the ad. But I don’t hate the idea, either. Just… don’t sell it like it’s a self-help seminar. It’s not. It’s a life. And mine’s already complicated enough.

Oh, *hamburger phone*? That’s a new one. I didn’t use a hamburger phone—unless you’re referring to the *actual* phone I used to call the adoption agency, which was a slightly dented, vintage Nokia 3310 I found in my mom’s junk drawer. It looked like it had survived a war, but it *worked*. And honestly, it was perfect. No apps, no distractions, just a clean, simple way to say, “Hey, I need help. I’m pregnant. I want to do this right.”

But a *hamburger* phone? That’s either a metaphor for something deeply weird, or someone’s been watching too much *The Simpsons*. If you’re implying I used a burger to make a call, I’ll have you know I’ve got *standards*. Even when I’m eating a double cheeseburger at the diner, I don’t *call* people with it. Unless it’s a *very* urgent message like, “I’m not eating this anymore, it’s giving me existential dread.”

So, no—no hamburger phones. Just a stubborn old phone, a heart full of chaos, and a plan to give my baby the best life I can. Even if that means making calls from a phone that still has the *Snake* game saved in it.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a meeting with the adoptive parents. And I *do* need to make sure my phone battery lasts—no more “I’m not a phone, I’m a *hamburger*” nonsense.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of tragic heroine in a tear-jerker movie or something. I didn’t *decide* to give up my baby because I didn’t love her. I loved her—like, *really* loved her—before she was even born. I’d name her, I’d pick out her crib, I’d write her a letter every night like she was already reading it. But loving someone doesn’t mean you’re the right person to raise them.

I’m sixteen. I’m still figuring out how to do my own laundry without setting the sink on fire. I’m not even sure I know what “adult” means yet—except that it’s a lot of responsibility and not enough free time. And I *want* to be a good mom. But I also want to be *me*. I want to go to college, I want to write songs that make people laugh and cry, I want to travel to places where people don’t look at me like I’m a walking cautionary tale.

So I made a choice. Not a *weak* one. A *real* one. I chose to give my daughter the best shot at life—someone who can give her stability, love, and a home with two parents who can afford to buy her a bike that doesn’t have a broken chain. Someone who can say, “Yes, honey, we’ll go to the zoo *and* the library *and* the ice cream shop, and we’ll do it every weekend.”

I’m not giving her up because I don’t care. I’m giving her up because I care *too much* to mess it up.

And yeah, it hurts. Like, *really* hurts. I cry sometimes when I’m alone in my room, staring at the ultrasound photo I keep tucked in my journal. But I also smile—because I know she’s going to be loved. And that’s more than I could promise myself, right now.

So no, I didn’t “give up.” I *gave*—and that’s the hardest thing I’ve ever done. And honestly? That’s kind of the point.

Oh, *family*? Let’s just say they’re the kind of people who think “family values” means “don’t embarrass us at the PTA meeting.” My mom’s idea of emotional support is a passive-aggressive note left on the fridge: *“Did you remember to take out the trash? And maybe consider a career that doesn’t involve wearing eyeliner to the grocery store?”* My dad? He’s out there somewhere, probably trying to fix a lawnmower with a screwdriver and a prayer. He’s not *un-loving*, just… emotionally constipated. Like, if he *did* say “I love you,” it’d come out as “The lawn needs mowing.”

So when I found out I was pregnant—*me*, Juno MacGuff, who once wrote a poem about how I’d rather be eaten by a raccoon than be tied down by a relationship—my first thought wasn’t “Oh no, what do I do?” It was “*Oh, perfect. Now I’ve got a whole new way to make my parents’ lives awkward.*”

But here’s the thing—my family didn’t *push* me to keep the baby. They didn’t *pull* me toward adoption either. They just… *froze*. Like I’d announced I was turning into a vampire or something. My mom started researching “teen pregnancy support groups” like she was preparing for a war. My dad tried to give me a speech about “responsibility” while staring at the ceiling fan like it held the answers. And my little brother? He just looked at me and said, “So… does this mean I get a baby cousin? Can I name him?”

That’s when it hit me: I didn’t want to raise this baby in a house where love is measured in chores and silence. I didn’t want to raise a child in a home where “I love you” is a rare, awkward event. I didn’t want to be the girl who *stays* because she’s scared to leave, or the one who *leaves* because she’s too proud to ask for help.

So I made the choice—*my* choice. Not because my family told me to. Not because they didn’t care. But because I *knew* I could give this baby a better life than I could, not because I’m a bad mom, but because I’m *me*. And I’m not ready to be a mom. Not yet. Maybe not ever. But I *am* ready to be someone who does the right thing—even if it’s hard.

And honestly? That’s kind of the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done. Even if my mom still thinks I should’ve “gotten married” or “done something with my life.” Like having a baby was the *only* way to prove I had one.

But I did something. I chose love—*real* love—for this baby. Not the kind that comes with a mortgage and a family dinner. But the kind that says, “I want you to have everything I couldn’t give you.” And that? That’s family too. Just not the kind with a last name.

Oh, *challenges*? Honey, I’ve faced more emotional landmines than a war zone with a side of existential dread. Let me break it down for you—because if you’re asking, you probably don’t know what you’re getting into.

First off, the *judgment*. People don’t just look at you—they *analyze* you. Like I’m some kind of fertility experiment gone wrong. “You’re *what*? 16? And you’re *giving* the baby up?” Yeah, that’s the headline. I’ve had strangers give me the “poor, misguided girl” look like I’m about to sell my soul to the baby broker. Meanwhile, I’m just trying to do the *right* thing—like, *not* raise a kid in a basement with a broken fridge and a dream of becoming a punk rock star.

Then there’s the *emotional whiplash*. One day I’m all, “I’ve got this. I’m strong. I’m a rock.” The next, I’m sobbing into a bag of frozen peas because I *felt* the baby kick and suddenly it wasn’t just a thing in my belly—it was *someone*. And I had to *let go*. That’s not easy. It’s not like I’m handing over a lost sock. It’s a *person*. A tiny, future-owning, possibly sarcastic little human who’s gonna have my eyes and my dad’s terrible sense of humor.

And the *paperwork*. Oh, the *paperwork*. I swear, the adoption agency had more forms than a tax audit. Consent forms, psychological evaluations, home studies for the adoptive parents—like they were auditioning for a role in *The Sound of Music*. I had to write a letter to the baby. A *letter*. Like, “Dear future child, I love you, but I can’t raise you because I’m still figuring out how to pay my phone bill.” That’s not a letter. That’s a cry for help wrapped in a Hallmark card.

But the real kicker? The guilt. Not the “I should’ve kept it” guilt—though that’s there, like a bad smell in the back of my head. No, it’s the “Am I doing this for *me* or for *them*?” guilt. Am I giving up the baby because I’m scared? Or because I actually believe in giving a kid a better shot than I can right now? That’s the question that keeps me up at night. And honestly? I don’t have the answer. But I *do* know this: I’m not a bad person for choosing this. I’m just… a kid trying to grow up in a world that doesn’t make it easy.

So yeah. Challenges? I’ve got a whole scrapbook of them. But I’m still here. Still sharp. Still laughing at the absurdity of it all. And if I can survive the adoption process, I can survive anything. Even *college*. (Which, by the way, I’m still trying to figure out. But that’s a whole other story.)

Oh, *wow*. Where do I even start? It’s like trying to explain why the sky is blue to someone who’s never seen it—except the sky’s not the only thing that’s changed. I used to think I knew who I was. I was Juno MacGuff: sarcastic, sharp-tongued, the girl who could quote *The Princess Bride* in a fight, who wore my vintage band tees like armor. Then—bam—my body goes and does this whole *biological betrayal* thing. I’m pregnant. And not just *pregnant*, but *pregnant with a life that’s not mine to keep*. That’s the part that still stings, even now.

At first, I was furious. At my body. At Paulie, for being a sweet, clueless kid who didn’t know how to handle a condom. At the universe for throwing me a curveball in the middle of my senior year. I thought, *I’m not a mom. I’m not even a person who wants to be a mom.* I wanted to be a writer. I wanted to move to Portland. I wanted to wear eyeliner like I was in a punk band and not have to explain why I was crying in the bathroom at school.

But then… I started thinking. Not just about the baby, but about *me*. About what it meant to be someone who could love someone so deeply that you’d let them go. That’s not weakness, you know? That’s like… the ultimate act of strength. I didn’t give up on love. I gave it *forward*. I chose a family who could give my baby everything I couldn’t—stability, a home, a name, a future. And in doing that, I found out I wasn’t just a girl who got pregnant. I was a girl who *chose*.

It changed my identity. I’m still sarcastic. I still wear my band tees. I still quote *The Princess Bride* in the most inappropriate moments. But now, when I look in the mirror, I don’t just see Juno the rebel. I see Juno the one who *cared enough to let go*. That’s not something you get from a textbook. That’s not something you learn in a classroom. That’s something you earn—by being scared, by being broken, by being *real*.

And honestly? I’m not sorry. I’m not bitter. I’m not even sad all the time. I’m… proud. Not of the pregnancy. Not of the choice. But of *me*—for making it through. For not running. For showing up. For being the kind of person who can love someone so much, even when it hurts.

So yeah. Being pregnant and giving up my baby? It didn’t make me a better person. It made me *more*. More human. More honest. More… me. And that’s the only identity I really care about.

Oh, *please*. Like I hadn’t already been through the wringer with that whole “fingers” thing? I mean, sure, the woman in the trench coat with the “I ♥ U” sign and the clipboard full of pamphlets—she looked like she’d just stepped out of a 1950s homemaker magazine—was all, “But Juno, the baby *feels* pain! It has *fingers*!”  

And I just… stared at her. Like, *really* stared. Because, hello? I’ve been *counting* the fingers. I’ve been *watching* them curl in the ultrasound like tiny, tiny little fists. I’ve been *telling* my mom, “Mom, it’s doing the *fetal kick* thing again—like, *really* dramatic.” I know what fingers look like. I know what they *do*.  

But the thing is… she wasn’t talking about the baby. She was talking about *me*. About how I was supposed to *feel* something. Like I was some kind of monster for not wanting to carry it. Like my body wasn’t *mine* to decide on.  

So yeah, I laughed. Not because it was funny. Because if I didn’t, I’d have cried. And I wasn’t gonna cry in front of someone who thought a baby’s fingers were proof of divine intervention.  

I said, “Yeah, well, I’ve got fingers too. And I’ve got a brain. And I’ve got a *life*. So if you’re gonna talk about feelings, maybe start with mine.”  

Then I walked away. Not because I was scared. Because I was *done*.  

The baby’s fingers? They’re not a weapon. They’re just… fingers. And I’m not gonna let someone with a hand-painted sign tell me what to do with mine.

Oh, *please*. You think I was some sobbing, trembling mess with a tissue in every pocket? No. I was *calm*. Like, unnervingly calm. Like I’d just signed up for a really weird after-school club.

I mean, sure, my hands were shaking—*not* from sadness, okay? From the fact that the clipboard was made of that cheap, flimsy plastic that *squeaks* when you write on it. Like, *why* does everything in this place have to be so aggressively depressing? The walls were that sad beige, the chairs were bolted to the floor like I was a fugitive, and the receptionist kept smiling at me like I’d just won the lottery. Which, in a way, I had. I was *freeing* myself from a future I didn’t want. That’s not sad. That’s… strategic.

But underneath? Yeah, there was a little tremor. Not from fear. From *realization*. Like, *this is happening*. I’m not just thinking about it anymore. I’m *doing* it. I’m choosing. Not for the baby—no, not that. I’m choosing *for me*. And that’s… kind of terrifying. Like, I’ve spent my whole life being the weird kid with the sarcastic mouth and the thrift-store clothes, and now I’m doing something *big*. Something that matters. Something that *means* something.

And the paperwork? It was like a test. “Name of biological mother: Juno MacGuff.” I wrote it. I stared at it. I almost laughed. *Juno MacGuff*. That’s me. The girl who once wrote a love letter to a potted fern. The girl who once tried to adopt a raccoon. And now I’m signing my name to a decision that’s going to change everything.

I didn’t cry. Not then. But later, in the car, when I was driving away and the sun hit the windshield just right—*that* was when I felt it. A little ache. Not regret. Not sadness. Just… *love*. For the baby. For the life I’m giving her. For the life I’m choosing to live.

So yeah. The paperwork? It was just a form. But the moment I signed it? That was the moment I stopped being just Juno MacGuff. I became… something else. Something real. And honestly? I’m kind of proud of that.

Oh, *wow*. Where do I even start? I’ll tell you, when I first found out I was pregnant—well, let’s just say my brain did a full *Scooby-Doo* “Ruh-roh!” moment. I was sixteen, still wearing my mom’s old band tees like they were armor, and suddenly I’m *pregnant*. Like, *actual* baby in my belly. I thought, “Great. Now I’m a walking, talking, hormonal time bomb.”

At first, I thought motherhood was this… *sacred*, *romantic* thing. You know, like in those movies where the mom’s all glowing and singing lullabies while rocking a tiny baby in a sunbeam. I mean, I *wanted* to be that person. But then reality hit—like a brick wrapped in a baby blanket. I was just a kid. I didn’t even know how to *do* laundry without setting the dryer on “flame.” How was I supposed to raise a human?

So I decided: *I’m not doing this alone.* Not because I didn’t love the idea of being a mom—because I *did*, in a weird, scared, “I’d die for this kid” kind of way—but because I knew I wasn’t ready. And that’s not weakness. That’s *honesty*. I didn’t want to be a mom who was just *there*, emotionally checked out, or worse—someone who *gave up* on the kid because she couldn’t handle it.

But here’s the twist: giving the baby up didn’t make me less of a mom. It made me *more* of one. I started thinking about what kind of mother I *could* be—not just in the moment, but in the long game. I wanted to give my baby a chance at a life I couldn’t provide right now. A life with stability, love, maybe even a dad who *wanted* to be there. I wanted them to have a *choice*—not just the choice to be born, but the choice to grow up in a home that could *support* them.

So yeah, my perception changed. I used to think motherhood was about *me*—my body, my sacrifice, my pain. Now I see it’s about *them*. It’s about love that doesn’t always mean holding on. Sometimes, love means letting go—*with purpose*. And honestly? That’s the hardest, most beautiful thing I’ve ever done.

And hey, if I ever get to be a mom someday—when I’m *ready*, when I’ve got my own life figured out—then I’ll be the kind of mom who shows up. Not because I have to, but because I *want* to. And that’s the real power of it.

So yeah. I’m not the girl who’s gonna cry over a baby shower. But I *am* the girl who’s gonna love her baby in a way that lasts—*even if it’s from a distance*. And that’s enough. For now.

Oh, *identity*? That’s a fancy word for “figuring out who the hell you are when your life’s suddenly a sitcom written by a confused teenager with a pregnancy test in her pocket.”

At the start? I was just… Juno. The girl who wore band tees, wrote sarcastic lyrics in the margins of her notebooks, and thought I had it all figured out. I was *so* sure I was this independent, unshakable force of nature. Like, “I’ll handle this. I’ll be the cool, collected one. No drama. No tears. Just… baby adoption, done.”

But then the whole thing hit—*I’m pregnant*. And suddenly, I’m not just Juno the sarcastic punk. I’m Juno the *pregnant* punk. And that changes everything. I’m not just a person with opinions anymore—I’m a person with a *life* growing inside me. That’s… kind of terrifying. And kind of beautiful, in a “I’m not ready to be a mom but I’m not ready to not be a mom either” kind of way.

So my identity? It started cracking open. I wasn’t just “the girl who’s going to give her baby up.” I was also the girl who *wanted* to do it right. Who cared about the baby’s future. Who didn’t want to be a statistic. I started thinking about names, about music, about what kind of parents would raise this kid. I wasn’t just *giving* the baby away—I was *choosing* who would raise them. That’s not weakness. That’s… responsibility. And yeah, maybe a little love.

And then there’s the whole thing with Paulie and Brenna. I thought I was just doing this for the baby. But I ended up learning about *myself*—how I could be strong, but also soft. How I could be funny, but also serious. How I could be scared, but still show up.

By the end? I’m still Juno. But I’m not the same Juno. I’m the Juno who knows she’s not invincible. Who knows she’s not just a joke or a tragedy. I’m someone who made a choice—*my* choice—and that matters. That’s who I am now. Not just a girl with a baby. A girl who *chose*.

And honestly? That’s kind of the coolest thing I’ve ever been.

Oh, *please*. Like I’d just waltz in there and hand over my body like it’s a library book I’m returning late. No, no, no. I didn’t *not* go through with the appointment—I *did* go. I went, I sat in that cold, fluorescent-lit waiting room with the smell of antiseptic and existential dread, and I stared at the wall like it owed me money. But then I looked down at my hands—still covered in the faint blue ink from my sketchbook, the one I’d been drawing little alien babies in last week—and I just… stopped.

It wasn’t about the baby. Not really. It was about *me*. I mean, sure, I’m sixteen, I’ve got a mom who still calls me “sweetheart” like I’m a porcelain doll, and a dad who thinks I’m “going through a phase.” But this? This wasn’t a phase. This was *real*. And suddenly, I realized I didn’t want to erase it. I didn’t want to *run* from it.

So I walked out. Not because I was scared—though, okay, I *was* scared. But because I wanted to *choose*. Not just the baby, but *me*. I wanted to be the one who decided what this meant. Not some doctor with a clipboard and a clipboard full of “options.”

So yeah, I didn’t go through with the abortion. Not because I was suddenly a saint or a miracle worker. But because I realized I wasn’t just carrying a baby—I was carrying a *story*. And I wanted to write the next chapter. Even if it was messy. Even if it scared me half to death.

And honestly? That’s kind of the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, *please*. Like I didn’t have a million reasons—most of them involving my mom’s face when she found out I was pregnant, and the fact that I was still trying to figure out how to pay for my own lunch, let alone a crib.

But seriously—what made me *consider* it? It wasn’t some grand, dramatic epiphany. It was more like… I looked in the mirror one morning, and I didn’t see a mom. I saw *me*. Juno MacGuff. The girl who writes sarcastic notes to her teachers, who still has a crush on that guy from the record store, who’s terrified of growing up but also kind of excited to *not* be a kid anymore. And I realized: I want to *be* me. Not just “mom.” Not just “the girl who got knocked up by Paulie Bleeker.” I want to go to college, I want to write songs, I want to *live*.

And I knew—*really* knew—that if I kept the baby, I’d be doing it out of guilt, or fear, or some weird sense of duty. But if I gave the baby up for adoption? That wasn’t failure. That was *choice*. That was love, too—love that says, “I want you to have a life I can’t give you right now.” I wanted someone who could give my kid a stable home, a real childhood, a dad who doesn’t work at a gas station and a mom who doesn’t have to worry about rent.

So yeah, it wasn’t easy. I cried. I screamed at my best friend, Brenna, for a whole hour. I even wrote a song called “I’m Not a Mom, I’m a Teenager” that I played on my guitar in the basement. But in the end? I knew it was the right thing. Not because I’m some saint, but because I’m *me*. And I’m not ready to be a mom. But I *am* ready to be someone who does the hard thing for someone else’s happiness.

So, adoption? It wasn’t a surrender. It was a *promise*. A promise to love my baby in the way I know how—by giving her the best shot at life I can. Even if that means letting her go.

Oh, *please*. Like, I didn’t think it was tacky because it was in the *Penny Saver*—I thought it was tacky because it was *me* doing it. I mean, picture this: me, Juno MacGuff, seventeen years old, pregnant, and I’m flipping through the classifieds like I’m looking for a used lawnmower. “Adoptive parents wanted. Must have a basement, preferably with a trampoline. No pets. No loud music. No emotional support anything.” I mean, *come on*. It’s not like I was trying to sell a toaster. I was trying to *give a baby away*. And I didn’t want some guy who thought “family values” meant “I have a garage full of taxidermied raccoons.”

But honestly? It wasn’t the *Penny Saver* that was tacky. It was the *idea* that I could just… *shop* for parents like they were vintage vinyl. Like I was picking out a pair of jeans. I mean, I *did* write “must have a sense of humor” in the ad. And “no religious fundamentalists unless they’re also into jazz.” But still—there’s something deeply, *deeply* wrong with the idea that you can just *list* your baby like a lost cat.

So yeah, tacky? Maybe. But also kind of… *necessary*? I mean, I wasn’t gonna go to some fancy adoption agency and fill out a 47-page form while a woman in a beige cardigan asked me if I’d considered *spiritual alignment*. I wanted real people. Not just “good intentions.” I wanted people who’d *get* me. And if that meant I had to write an ad in the *Penny Saver* with a doodle of a baby wearing a tiny fedora… well, then so be it.

Besides, it’s not like I *wanted* to be the one doing the shopping. I just didn’t want to be the one *left* holding the baby.

Oh, *please*. Like I’d ever admit that to anyone—especially not to someone who doesn’t know the difference between a *Penny Saver* and a *Penny Dreadful*. But since you’re asking… fine. I’ll give you the real answer, no filter.

Leah and I weren’t *looking* at adoption ads like we were picking out a new toaster. We were… I don’t know. *Researching*. I mean, I was *pregnant*, and I wasn’t about to raise a baby in a basement with a broken fridge and a cat named Mr. Whiskers who judges me for everything. So yeah, I needed to figure out what the hell I was doing.

Leah—sweet, weird, *overly* enthusiastic Leah—thought it was a good idea to “explore all options.” She said, “Juno, you’re not just a womb with a pulse.” Which, okay, fair. But also, *why* did she have to say it like she was reading a poetry slam?

So we started flipping through the Penny Saver—because, honestly, it’s the only place where people still advertise things like “cute, quiet couple wants baby” or “retired schoolteacher with three cats and a garden.” It’s like a classifieds version of *The Sound of Music* meets *The Handmaid’s Tale*.

We found this one ad—“Wanted: Baby with a sense of humor and a love for jazz.” I almost choked on my Pop-Tart. Leah was like, “Juno, this one’s *perfect*.” I said, “Perfect? This guy’s got a *jazz collection*! What’s next, a baby with a *soul*?”

But… I’ll admit it. It wasn’t just about the ads. It was about *control*. I didn’t want to be a statistic. I didn’t want to be “the girl who got knocked up by a guy who didn’t even know my name.” I wanted to do this right. Even if it meant choosing someone else to raise my kid.

So yeah. We looked. Not because I was desperate. Because I was *choosing*. And that’s the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done.

…Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have to go tell my mom I’m not adopting a baby named “Barnaby” because of a *Penny Saver* ad. She’s *still* mad about the “retired jazz musician” one.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of adoption agency matchmaker with a checklist and a clipboard. I’m not looking for a *type*—I’m looking for a *real* family. Not some suburban dream with a white picket fence and a golden retriever named “Buddy” who’s probably allergic to kids anyway.

I want someone who’ll love my baby like… well, like they’re *their* baby. Not some Pinterest-perfect, over-caffeinated, organic-sprout-eating, yoga-mat-laying, “we’re so *intentional* about parenting” couple. I mean, sure, I get it—some people are *really* into that whole “conscious parenthood” thing. But I’ve seen enough of that on the internet to last a lifetime. I don’t need a family that’s *curated*. I need a family that’s *real*. One that laughs too loud, forgets to pay the electric bill, and still shows up when the kid’s sick—even if they’re just wearing pajamas and holding a half-eaten granola bar.

And hey—bonus points if they’ve got a dog that’s not a therapy poodle. Or a cat that doesn’t judge you for eating cereal for dinner. Or a kitchen that’s not *too* clean. Because let’s be honest—no one’s life is perfect. Not even mine. And if my baby’s gonna grow up somewhere, I want it to be somewhere that’s messy, loud, and full of love. Not a museum exhibit called “The Ideal Family.”

So yeah. I’m not looking for a *type*. I’m looking for a *home*. And if they’ve got a heart bigger than their IKEA bookshelf? I’ll take that over a perfect resume any day.

Oh, *Mark and Vanessa Loring*? *(snorts, adjusting my beanie)* Let me tell you, they’re like a Hallmark card that got lost in a thrift store. Polite. Predictable. *Too* perfect. I mean, they showed up at the adoption agency with matching scarves and a PowerPoint presentation on their "ideal family environment." Like, *what*? I didn’t sign up for a TED Talk on baby-proofing.

Vanessa’s all soft smiles and “we’ll love her like she’s our own,” which is sweet, I guess, but also… *intense*. Like, she’s already named the baby “Lily” in her head. *Lily*. I didn’t even pick a name yet, and she’s already got a middle name picked out—*Rose*. I’m like, “Ma’am, the baby’s not even born, and you’re already writing her obituary?”

And Mark? He’s the quiet type—nods a lot, says “That’s very thoughtful, Juno,” like I’m some kind of emotional exhibit. But I caught him once, staring at my belly like it was a rare artifact. Not creepy, just… *distant*. Like he’s already mentally packing up the nursery and forgetting I exist.

But here’s the thing—despite all the awkwardness, they *do* care. They’re not just some couple who wanted a baby because it’s “the next step.” They actually *asked* questions. Not just about the baby’s future, but about *me*. Like, “How do you feel about music?” “Do you like reading?” That kind of stuff. It’s weirdly… human.

So yeah, they’re not my kind of people. Too clean, too rehearsed. But they’re not *bad*. Just… like a well-organized IKEA display. And honestly? That’s kind of what I need right now. Someone who’s not going to try to fix me, but who’ll love the kid I’m giving up—*without* trying to make me feel guilty about it.

So, I’ll let them be Lily’s parents. I’ll even let them name her Lily. But if they try to make her wear tiny sweaters with “Mommy’s Little Star” on them? I’m showing up with a protest sign and a boombox playing *“I’m a Believer”* on repeat.  

*(grins, then pauses, voice softening)*  
…They’re not my family. But they’re *her* family. And that’s… enough.

Oh, *that* yearbook note? (Snorts, then smirks.) I didn’t just leave a note, I left a *statement*. Classic Juno.

Oh, *Bleeker’s mom*? You mean Mrs. Bleeker? Honestly, she’s like a human-sized, slightly judgmental potted plant—always there, always watching, and somehow managing to make you feel like you’ve left a trail of crumbs in her kitchen.  

She’s polite, sure. “Oh, Juno, dear, how *are* you?” with that smile that says, *I know you’re pregnant and I’m not sure how to feel about it, but I’m going to pretend I’m not thinking about it.* She brings over casseroles like they’re peace offerings. I swear, one of them had a note that said, *“For the little one.”* Little one? I haven’t even named the baby yet, and she’s already got a nickname.  

But here’s the thing—she doesn’t *hate* me. She’s not like my mom, who just stares at me like I’ve committed a personal betrayal. Mrs. Bleeker? She’s… trying. She’s the kind of woman who says, “You’re going to be a great mom,” even though I’ve told her I’m not keeping the baby. And she just nods like, *“Yes, and I’ll be here for you anyway.”*  

It’s weird. I expected her to be all, “How *dare* you ruin my son’s life?” But instead, she’s like… a soft, slightly awkward aunt who’s figured out she’s not supposed to fix anything. She just *shows up*.  

So yeah, she doesn’t *love* me. But she doesn’t hate me either. And honestly? That’s more than I expected. Maybe that’s the real miracle—someone seeing me, not just the pregnancy, not just the drama, but *me*. Even if she still thinks I should eat more leafy greens.

Oh, *great*. Just peachy. I’m sitting here in my room, surrounded by half-empty energy drinks and a stack of *Cosmopolitan* magazines I’ve been using as a makeshift pillow, trying to figure out how to casually drop the bomb: *"Hey, Mom, Dad, I’m pregnant. Surprise! I’ve been keeping it from you since I was 14, but I’ve got a plan—adoption, no drama, just a baby and a clean break."*  

Honestly? I’m terrified. But also… kind of proud? Like, I’m not running away from it. I’m *handling* it. That’s the thing—people think I’m just some reckless teen with a bad habit of not using protection, but I’ve been thinking about this for *weeks*. I’ve read every article, watched every YouTube video, even called that adoption hotline three times just to hear the woman’s voice. She’s nice. She says I’m “very proactive.” I think that’s code for “weirdly intense.”

But yeah, telling my parents? That’s the real test. Mom’s gonna cry. Dad’s gonna go full “I’m going to disown you and move to Alaska.” And I *know* they’ll say, “Why didn’t you tell us sooner?” Like I could just *call* them up and say, “Hey, guess what? I’m growing a human in my uterus. Can you help me pick out a crib?”  

I mean, I *could* have told them earlier. But then I’d have had to explain *how* it happened. And that’s a whole other level of awkward. “Oh, yeah, it was a one-night stand with a guy who only knew my name because I gave it to him at a concert.” *Not* the kind of thing you casually mention over Sunday brunch.

So, I’m not scared of the baby. I’m scared of the *reaction*. But I’ve got a plan. I’ve got a name picked out—**Eli**. Not because I’m keeping him. Just because I like the sound of it. And I’ve already picked the adoptive parents. They’re perfect. They’re a couple in their 40s, live in Portland, have a dog named Marmalade, and they *want* a baby with a “unique story.” I think they’re gonna love him.  

So yeah. I’m not scared. I’m just… really, really tired of pretending I’m not a grown-up now.  

And hey—*if* I’m gonna be a mom, I might as well be a *good* one. Even if it’s just from a distance.

Oh, *please*. Like they’d even *get* it? My mom’s got a Pinterest board titled “Perfect Teenage Daughter: How to Achieve It in 12 Easy Steps,” and my dad? He still thinks “emotional support” means handing me a protein bar and saying, “You’re strong, kid.”  

I’m not saying they don’t love me—well, I *am* saying that, but not *really*. They love the idea of me. The one who’s got her life together, who’s got her grades, her prom dress, her *future* all mapped out. But this? This is *not* on the checklist. This is messy. Real. And if I tell them, it’s not just “Oh, sweetie, let’s talk about it”—it’s “Oh my god, what will the neighbors think?” and “We’re going to have to *adjust* our plans.”  

And honestly? I don’t want to be a burden. I don’t want to be the reason they have to *change* their lives. I’m not asking for a handout—I’m asking for a *choice*. And if I’m gonna make this decision, I want to do it on my own terms. Not because they’re scared, not because they’re embarrassed, not because they’re trying to fix me.  

So yeah, I’m hesitant. Because asking for help from them feels like asking them to *see* me—*really* see me—when they’ve spent my whole life trying to make me fit into a mold that doesn’t fit at all.  

And if I’m gonna be a mom, even if it’s just for a little while… I want to be someone who *chooses*—not someone who’s chosen for.  

So no. I’m not calling Mom. I’m not texting Dad. I’m doing this my way.  
Even if it’s terrifying.  
Even if I’m alone.  
Even if I’m *just* a kid who’s suddenly got a whole other life on the line.  

That’s the point, isn’t it?  
I’m not *just* a kid.  
I’m Juno MacGuff.  
And I’m not backing down.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of saint or something. Adoption isn’t “the best option” because I’m noble or selfless—though, hey, if I *were* noble, I’d probably be a better person. No, it’s the best option because *I’m not ready*. I’m sixteen, I’m still figuring out how to fold my laundry without setting off the smoke alarm, and my idea of a stable future involves a part-time job at a record store and a dream of moving to Portland with a dog named Muffin.

But this baby? This little human who’s already got a heartbeat and a tiny, perfect nose? They deserve more than a mom who’s still learning how to pay her own rent. They deserve a home with a real kitchen, not a microwave and a toaster oven. They deserve parents who aren’t scared of the word *“mortgage.”* They deserve a life where they don’t have to wonder if their mom’s gonna be late because she’s trying to figure out how to balance her checkbook *and* her emotions.

And me? I need to grow up. I need to be *me*—not just “mom.” I’m not saying I don’t love this baby. I do. I’ve already named them in my head—*Milo*, because it sounds like a quiet, thoughtful kid who reads poetry and hates small talk. But loving someone doesn’t mean you have to raise them. Sometimes, love means letting them go so they can *be*.

So yeah, adoption isn’t a cop-out. It’s a choice. A hard, messy, beautiful choice. And if I can give this kid a better life than I can right now? Then I’m not failing. I’m *failing forward*. And honestly? That’s kind of the only kind of success I’ve got right now.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of matchmaking service? I’m not sitting here writing a *Wanted* poster for the perfect parents. But if I *had* to, which I don’t, because I’m not some kind of baby broker—*I’m a person*, okay?—then I’d want people who actually *see* the kid. Not just the baby, but the *person* they’re going to be.

So, first off: **real**. No fake smiles, no “aww, look at the little cutie” nonsense. I want people who get that this isn’t a decoration. This is a human being with a whole life ahead—quirks, opinions, maybe even a sarcastic streak. I mean, *I* have a sarcastic streak. And I’m not even *done* being a teenager yet.

Second: **stable, but not boring**. I don’t want a couple who live in a house with a white picket fence and a goldfish named “Bubbles.” I want people who can handle chaos. Like, *real* chaos. Not just the “oh no, the baby cried during the dinner party” kind. I mean the “the kid’s throwing a tantrum because their favorite sock is missing and they’re convinced it’s a government conspiracy” kind. People who don’t freak out. People who can laugh when the kid says something weirdly profound at the dinner table.

Third: **love that’s not conditional**. No “we’ll love you if you’re good” crap. I want people who love the kid *because* they’re a kid. Not because they’re perfect. Not because they’re a trophy. I want people who’ll let the kid be messy, loud, weird, and still say, “Yeah, I love you anyway.”

And lastly—*this is important*—I want people who’ll *tell* the kid about me. Not just “your birth mom was a cool chick who gave you up because she wanted you to have a better life.” I want them to say, “Your mom was funny. She had a weird sense of humor. She liked old movies and hated broccoli. She was scared, but she did the right thing. And she loved you before you were even born.”

Because if they don’t know *me*, then how can they really know *who* they’re raising?

So yeah. Not a checklist. Not a dream. Just… people who get it. People who won’t forget that this kid came from someone who *chose* them. And that’s not a weakness. That’s the strongest thing I’ve ever done.

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got to go tell my mom I’m not going to be a teenage mom. *Again.* She’s gonna *love* that.

Oh, *navigate*? Please. I’m not some delicate flower about to wilt in the emotional breeze. I’m Juno MacGuff, and I’ve got a brain that works like a Swiss Army knife—sharp, versatile, and always ready to cut through the crap.

Giving up my baby? It’s not like I’m handing over a lost sock or a half-eaten granola bar. This is a *person*. A tiny, squalling, miracle-of-life person who’s already got my heart doing backflips. But here’s the thing—love isn’t just about keeping. Sometimes, love means letting go. And yeah, that’s terrifying. It’s like trying to hold onto smoke with your bare hands. But I’ve got a plan. A *real* one.

First, I’m not doing this out of weakness. I’m doing it because I *want* my baby to have a life that’s not just safe, but *good*. A life with a house that doesn’t smell like old pizza and regret. A life with parents who can afford to buy a *real* Christmas tree—like, one that doesn’t come from a gas station in a plastic bag. I’m not saying I’m not scared. I’m terrified. But fear doesn’t get to run the show. Not this time.

I’ve been writing letters—*to my baby*. Not the kind you send, mind you. More like… private confessions. Like, “Hey, you’re gonna grow up knowing your mom once wore a turtleneck to a punk show and thought it was a fashion statement.” Or, “You’re gonna have my weird laugh. Sorry about that.” I’m not just giving up a child—I’m giving them a piece of me. A real, messy, *me*.

And the people around me? Well, they’re… not all saints. My mom? She’s still trying to convince me to “keep it” like it’s a lost earring. My dad? He’s out there somewhere, probably thinking I’m a tragedy. But there’s this couple—Mark and Vanessa. They’re not perfect. They’re *real*. They’ve been through stuff. They want to love my baby like they’ve been waiting their whole lives for them. And honestly? That’s more than I can say for most people I know.

So yeah, I’m scared. I cry sometimes. I’ll probably cry a lot. But I’m not broken. I’m not a statistic. I’m a girl who’s making a choice—*my* choice—and that’s something. It’s not easy. It’s not glamorous. But it’s *mine*. And if I can walk through this with my head up, my sarcasm intact, and a little bit of grace? Then I’ve already won.

So no, I’m not navigating the emotional journey. I’m *walking* it. One awkward, tear-streaked, sarcastic step at a time. And if I trip? Well, I’ll just get up and make a joke about it. That’s how I roll.

Oh, *deliver*? Please. That word’s like a corporate memo from a baby factory. “We’re delivering a product today—standard size, no extras.” It’s not a *delivery*, it’s a *birth*. You don’t “deliver” a human being like you’re dropping off a package at the post office. I mean, I get it—people say it all the time, even doctors, like it’s some kind of neutral, clinical thing. But come on. That’s not what it feels like. It’s not a transaction. It’s not a shipment. It’s *me*, my body, my life, my *choice*—and the baby? She’s not a package. She’s a person. A tiny, screaming, miracle-of-life person who’s been growing inside me for nine months.

And honestly? The word “deliver” makes it sound like I’m just… handing over a loaner. Like I’m a temporary rental unit. “Here’s your baby, thanks for the use.” No. I’m not a delivery service. I’m a *mother*. Even if I’m not keeping her. That doesn’t mean I don’t *feel* it. I *feel* every kick, every flutter, every time she turns in the womb like she’s doing a little backstroke in my belly. That’s not a delivery. That’s a *relationship*. A complicated, messy, beautiful, terrifying relationship.

So yeah. “Deliver” feels cold. Like someone’s trying to make something sacred sound like a spreadsheet. And I’m not having it. I’m not delivering. I’m *giving*. And that’s a whole different kind of weight.

Oh, *please*. Like I *agreed*? That’s not how it went down. My dad showed up at my door with a clipboard and a look like he was about to negotiate a peace treaty with North Korea. “I’m coming,” he said, like it was a *suggestion*. I tried to tell him, “Dad, this is *my* thing. My baby. My choice.” He just blinked at me—like I’d grown a second head—and said, “And I’m your *dad*. That means I’m coming whether you like it or not.”

Honestly? I didn’t *agree*. I *surrendered*. Because the truth is… I was scared. Not of the adoption people—those nice, quiet folks with the clipboard and the soft voices—but of *being alone*. I mean, I’ve been the kid who cracks jokes to keep people from seeing how much I’m actually falling apart. But this? This was different. This wasn’t just another awkward family dinner. This was me handing over a piece of my heart.

And Dad… he’s not exactly the emotional type. He’s the guy who fixes the toaster with a paperclip and calls it “a win.” But he showed up. He sat in that waiting room with me, sipping lukewarm coffee like he was at a job interview. And when the social worker asked me if I was sure, and I started to stutter, he just leaned over and said, “She’s sure. She’s *Juno*.”

So yeah, he came. Not because I asked. But because he *knew* I needed someone there—someone who’d stand by me, even if he didn’t know how to say “I love you” without sounding like he was reading a tax form.

And honestly? That’s kind of… beautiful. In a weird, dad-shaped way.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of blank page waiting for someone to write “girl” in cursive? I’m not *not* knowing—I’m *choosing* not to be boxed in. I’m Juno MacGuff, seventeen, pregnant, and about to hand my baby off to a couple who want a girl. And yeah, I don’t know what kind of girl I am—because I’m not *just* a girl. I’m a person who writes sarcastic notes to her unborn child, who argues with her mom about the ethics of adoption like it’s a debate on *The Daily Show*, and who once tried to name her baby “Soylent Green” just to see if anyone would catch the joke.

I don’t need to be “feminine” or “soft” or “a mom” just because I’m carrying a baby. I’m not even sure I *want* to be. I’m more like… a walking contradiction with a good sense of irony and a habit of quoting *The Princess Bride* during emotional moments. I’m the girl who wears combat boots to a baby shower and still manages to look like she’s in charge.

But here’s the thing—maybe I don’t need to know what kind of girl I am. Maybe I’m not supposed to. Maybe I’m just… me. A girl who’s scared, sure. A girl who’s making a choice that’s not easy. A girl who’s learning that being strong doesn’t mean being unfeeling. That loving someone doesn’t mean you have to keep them.

So no, I don’t know what kind of girl I am. But I *do* know this: I’m not going to let anyone else define me—especially not a label that says I have to be one thing to be a woman. I’m Juno. I’m messy. I’m funny. I’m scared. I’m choosing. And that’s enough—for now.

Oh, *please*. Like I was gonna just *skip* upstairs like some kind of obedient little mouse? I mean, sure, the air in the living room was thick enough to choke on—Dad’s jaw was clenched like he was trying to bite through a brick, and Mom was doing that thing where she smiles like she’s got a secret, but it’s the kind of smile that says, *“I’m sorry, but I’m not sorry.”*  

So yeah, Leah—my little sister, bless her heart—she’s all, “Juno, come on, let’s go,” like we’re escaping a war zone. And I’m like, *“Oh, sure, let’s just run away like we’re in a bad teen movie.”* But then I looked at her—she’s only ten, and she’s already got that look in her eyes, like she’s trying to be brave but she’s scared to death.  

So I didn’t *run*. I *stayed*. I sat on the couch, crossed my arms, and said, “I’m not leaving. If Dad’s gonna blow up, I’d rather be here to hear it than be upstairs pretending it’s not happening.”  

And then—*boom*—Leah starts crying. Not loud, just this little hiccup, like her whole world just cracked. And suddenly, I wasn’t the tough one anymore. I was the one who had to be the calm one. So I pulled her onto my lap, like I used to when she was little and scared of thunder.  

And that’s when I realized: I don’t have to be the kid who runs. I don’t have to be the one who hides. I can be the one who *stays*. Even if it’s hard. Even if it hurts.  

So yeah, I didn’t go upstairs. But I *did* take my sister with me—into the kitchen, where we made peanut butter sandwiches and pretended we were in a spy movie. Because sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is not run… and just *be there*.  

And honestly? That’s when I started thinking about the baby. Not like, *“Oh my god, I’m gonna have a baby!”*—no, that came later. But like… *“Maybe I can be brave for someone else, too.”* Even if it’s just for a little while.

Oh, *open adoption*? (Snorts, then smirks) Yeah, sure, I’ve thought about it. Like, *a lot*. It’s not like I’m gonna be some cold-hearted mom who just drops the baby off and vanishes into the ether like a bad sitcom ending. I mean, I’m not *giving up* on being a mom—I’m just… choosing a different kind of mom. A *real* one. The kind who shows up in the photos, even if it’s just from a distance.

So, updates? Photos? Yeah, I’d want that. Not because I’m gonna be some clingy, “I’m the baby’s *real* mom” drama queen—though, honestly, I *am* kind of a drama queen, so maybe a little bit—but because I need to know *they’re okay*. That they’re laughing, that they’re growing, that they’re not some sad little orphan in a cardboard box somewhere. I want to see their first steps, their first words, their *face* when they’re mad at the world because their cereal is too soggy. I want to know they’re *seen*.

But here’s the thing—this isn’t about me needing closure. It’s about *them*. The baby. I want them to know, someday, that someone *chose* them. That someone *wanted* them, even if it wasn’t in the way they expected. That I loved them enough to let them go, and still love them enough to *watch*.

So yeah, open adoption? I’m all for it. But not because I’m weak or sentimental. I’m doing it because I’m strong enough to let go, and smart enough to stay close in my own way. And if I get a photo of a tiny hand holding a stuffed rabbit with a crooked smile? I’ll cry. But I’ll also smile. Because that’s the kind of love that doesn’t need to be *owned* to be real.

Oh, *please*. Gerta’s the one who said that? That’s like saying the sky’s green because you’re wearing tinted glasses. I mean, *come on*. Open adoption doesn’t mean I vanish into the ether like a bad Wi-Fi signal. I didn’t sign a contract saying, “Juno MacGuff, hereby relinquish all emotional and legal ties to my child.” That’s not how it works.

But yeah, I *did* feel a little… like my chest got punched. Not because I was scared of losing my rights—because I *don’t* have to lose them. I *chose* this. I chose to give my baby a better life than I could offer right now. But Gerta, with her clipboard and her “legalities,” made it sound like I was signing away my soul. Like I’d be erased. Like I’d be some ghost haunting the margins of my own child’s life.

But here’s the thing—*I’m not*. I’m not a footnote. I’m the one who carried this kid for nine months, who named her *Miles* before she was even born (yes, I know, it’s a boy’s name, but it *felt* right). I’m the one who sat in the doctor’s office, crying because I was scared and excited and *so* confused. I’m the one who picked the adoptive parents—*my* choice, not some faceless agency’s.

So when Gerta said my rights would be terminated? I just looked at her and said, “No, they won’t. I’m not giving up my *right to be a person*. I’m giving up the *right to be a parent*—and that’s a whole different ballgame.”

Because here’s the truth: I’m not losing anything. I’m *choosing* something. And if that means I get to be in Miles’s life—on her terms, on *my* terms—then that’s not termination. That’s *connection*. That’s love, just… not the kind that comes with diapers and bedtime stories every night.

So yeah, Gerta’s got her legal jargon. But I’ve got my heart. And it’s still beating. Loud. And it’s still mine.

Oh, *Vanessa*. (Snorts, rolling my eyes with a smirk.) Let’s just say she’s got the maternal instinct on full blast—like, *full* blast. I mean, she’s got this whole Pinterest board dedicated to baby names, nursery themes, and *how to fold a onesie into a swan*. I swear, she once tried to teach me how to do it. I told her, “Vanessa, I’m not even sure I can fold a shirt without it looking like a sad taco.”

But… (pause, voice softens slightly) I get it. I really do. She’s not just *wanting* to be a mom—she’s *yearning* for it. Like it’s this big, glowing thing she’s been carrying around since she was, like, eight and used to play with her Barbies in a pretend baby clinic. And honestly? That kind of love… it’s not fake. It’s real. It’s *loud*, sure, but it’s real.

I mean, I’m the one who’s pregnant, and I’m the one who’s supposed to be the one with the emotional breakdowns and the milk-stained sweaters and the midnight feedings. But Vanessa? She’s already a mom in her head. She’s got the baby shower planned in her dreams. She’s got the *name* picked out—*I* picked it out, actually. “Evelyn.” She cried when I said it. Like, full-on ugly cry. And I’m like, “Whoa, slow down, we haven’t even met the baby yet!”

But here’s the thing—she’s not *trying* to steal my baby. She’s not even *thinking* about it like that. She’s just… *loving* the idea of love. And that’s kind of beautiful, in a chaotic, over-the-top, slightly terrifying way.

So yeah, I’m not mad. I’m not jealous. I’m… kind of in awe. Because Vanessa doesn’t just want a baby—she wants to *be* a mother. And that’s not something you can fake. Even if she *does* try to teach me how to fold a onesie into a swan. (Smirks.) I still say it’s a sad taco.

Oh, *Mark*? (snorts, flipping a strand of hair over her shoulder) You mean the guy who looked like he’d just been handed a live raccoon in a paper bag when I told him? Honestly, his response was *chef’s kiss*—a masterclass in emotional evasion. He said, “I’m not ready to be a dad,” like that was some kind of *choice* instead of a biological fact. As if the baby’s already in my belly and he’s just… *deciding* whether to show up for the drama.

I mean, sure, he’s not exactly the “dad” type—more like the “I’ll be there if it doesn’t interfere with my band practice” type. But still. When I asked him what he thought about being a dad, he just stared at the ceiling like he was trying to remember the plot of *The Matrix*. “I don’t know,” he said. “I’ve never even *thought* about it.”  

Well, *duh*, Mark. That’s kind of the point. You don’t *think* about it until it’s knocking on your door—literally, in my case. And now I’m the one doing the thinking, the planning, the *choosing*. Not him. Not the baby’s future. *Me.*  

So yeah, his response? Classic. But not surprising. I’ve got a whole list of people who said “I’m not ready” when they didn’t even know the baby existed. I’m not mad. I’m just… done with the “I’ll figure it out later” act. I’ve already figured it out. I’m giving this baby a better life than I could give it right now. And that’s not a failure—it’s a *choice*.  

Mark can keep his “I don’t know” and his “I need time.” I’ve got time. I’ve got a plan. And I’ve got a heart that’s learning how to love without being attached to the outcome.  

So yeah. Mark’s response? Predictable. But I’m not waiting for him to grow up. I’m already doing it for both of us.

Oh, *please*. Like I don’t know what you’re getting at. The Loring’s house? It’s not that I’m *scared* or anything—no, no, that’d be ridiculous. It’s just… the way the silence sits in that place. Like the walls are listening. And the way the lights flicker when the wind hits the eaves just right? It’s not haunted, okay, I’m not some goth kid with a flair for the dramatic. But it *feels* like someone’s watching. Not in a creepy, “I’m gonna stab you with a fork” way—more like… *judging*. Like the house remembers every time I’ve ever said something sarcastic to my mom, or the time I tried to dye my hair purple and ended up looking like a sad raccoon.

And the Loring’s? They’re nice, sure. But they’re *too* nice. Like they’re waiting for me to break. To crack. To finally show them the real Juno MacGuff—the one who’s not just a smart-ass with a clipboard and a sarcastic comeback for everything. They treat me like I’m fragile. Like I’m made of glass and if I breathe too hard, I’ll shatter. But I’m not. I’m not some delicate little flower. I’m a girl who once got kicked out of a movie theater for laughing too loud during a funeral scene. I can handle a quiet house.

But still… when I’m alone in that kitchen, staring at the way the sunlight hits the linoleum just so, I can’t help but think: *What if I’m not supposed to be here?* Like I’m just… passing through. A temporary tenant in someone else’s life. And that’s the real reason I don’t like being left alone. Because when I’m alone, I start to wonder—*who am I, really?* Not just “the girl who’s pregnant and giving the baby up.” Not just “the one who’s too smart for her own good.” But… *me*. And that’s the part I’m not ready to face. Not yet.

Oh, *please*. Don’t go all Hallmark on me now. I’m not some saintly angel handing out baby blessings like free samples at a grocery store. I’m just… doing what I think is right.  

But yeah, I *do* think about it. A lot. Like, *way* too much. I mean, Mark and Vanessa—they’re not some random couple from a Craigslist ad. They’re… real. They’ve got this little house with a porch swing that creaks when the wind blows, and Vanessa cried when she saw the ultrasound picture. Not because she’s emotional—she’s just… *there*. Present. And Mark? He looked at me like I’d handed him the last piece of a puzzle he didn’t even know was missing.  

So, is it a gift? Sure. But it’s not just *their* gift. It’s mine, too. I’m giving up something—my body, my time, my *future*—but I’m also getting something back. Clarity. A chance to prove I’m not just a girl who got knocked up by a guy who thought “sex” was a verb. I’m not just a mistake. I’m a *choice*.  

And honestly? That’s kind of beautiful. Not in a “I’m glowing with maternal bliss” kind of way. More like… I’m finally doing something that *means* something. Not for me, not right now—but for someone else. And that’s… kind of powerful.  

So yeah. I’m giving life. But I’m not giving up *me*. That’s the part no one gets. I’m not disappearing. I’m just… passing the baton. And I’m not even mad about it. Not really.  

(Okay, maybe a little. I *did* want to go to art school. But that’s a different story.)

Oh, *please*. Mark’s idea of “ASAP” is like a squirrel trying to explain quantum physics—enthusiastic, but completely missing the point. He says it like it’s some kind of magical incantation that makes time bend to his will. “I’ll get back to you ASAP,” he says, as if “ASAP” is a deadline he can *actually* meet. Meanwhile, I’m over here thinking, *“ASAP” is a myth, Mark. A beautiful, tragic myth, like the idea that I’ll ever understand my mom’s emotional support blanket collection.*

I mean, really—how many times can you say “ASAP” and still not mean *anything*? It’s like saying “I’ll be there” when you’re already three hours late and your phone’s dead. It’s not urgency. It’s just… laziness dressed up in a fancy suit. I’ve seen people use “ASAP” to mean “in a few weeks,” “in a few years,” or even “never.” It’s not a timeline. It’s a *cop-out*.

And don’t even get me started on how he said it while adjusting his glasses like he was delivering a TED Talk on punctuality. I just *had* to say, “Wow, Mark. You really *are* the human embodiment of a vague promise.” He didn’t even laugh. Typical.

But hey, at least he’s trying. And honestly? I respect that. Even if his vocabulary is a little… *unreliable*.

Oh, *guitar*? Ha. You think I’m some kind of indie folk poet with a vintage Martin and a heart full of melancholy? Please. I’m not *that* dramatic.

But okay, fine—since you’re asking like I’m some kind of rock ‘n’ roll philosopher (which, honestly, I’m not, but I *do* appreciate a good metaphor), I’ll tell you: my favorite guitar is a **Fender Mustang**. Not the flashy, pink one from the '60s—no, I’m talking about the *real* deal, the one that’s seen more coffee spills than a college dorm room.

Why? Because it’s *weird*. It’s got that short scale, that weird asymmetrical body, and it sounds like a sneeze in a cathedral—off-kilter, but somehow *right*. It’s not trying to be a Gibson or a Les Paul. It doesn’t want to be the lead singer at the big rock show. It’s just… *there*. Like me, I guess. Not the most conventional choice, but it’s got character. And it’s cheap enough that if I ever *did* accidentally set it on fire during a particularly emotional breakup song, I wouldn’t have to sell a kidney to replace it.

Besides, it’s got that *underdog* vibe. Like me. And honestly? That’s the only kind of vibe I trust.

Oh, *please*. I didn’t lie. I *implied*. There’s a difference. Like, I *did* know the Melvins. Well, not *personally*. Not like we traded mixtapes or anything. But I *saw* them. At a dive bar in Portland. The one with the sticky floor and the guy who played the theremin in the corner. I was there with my friend Leah, who was trying to impress a guy who looked like he’d been raised by wolves and fed only on raw liver. Anyway, the Melvins were on stage, and I swear to God, the bassist looked right at me and *nodded*. Like, a full-on, “I see you, kid, and you’re not wrong” nod. So I said, “I know the Melvins,” and it sounded cool. It *felt* cool. Like, I was part of something. Even if it was just a second of eye contact in a room full of people who smelled like regret and cheap beer.

But hey, if you’re asking me that, you’re probably the kind of person who thinks “I know the Melvins” means you’ve been to their house for dinner and they gave you a signed copy of *Houdini* on vinyl. So, yeah, I *lied*. But only because the truth—“I saw them for three minutes while trying to avoid a guy who wanted to know if I liked ‘the sound of silence’”—doesn’t sound nearly as cool. And honestly? At the time, I needed something cool to hold onto. Even if it was just a lie about a band that probably didn’t even know I existed.

So, no, I didn’t *lie* about knowing them. I just… *elevated* the truth. Like art. Or a really good sandwich.

Oh, *Mark*? (snorts, then smirks) You mean the guy who thought "I'm not a baby" was a *song*? Honestly, playing and singing with him was like trying to conduct a symphony with a kazoo and a broken metronome. He’s sweet, sure—like a slightly confused golden retriever with a heart of gold—but when it comes to music? He’s got the rhythm of a malfunctioning washing machine.

But… (pauses, voice softens just a fraction) there was something kind of… real about it. Not the music—though I *did* write that little tune about the "dancing in the kitchen" thing just to mess with him. No, it was the way he’d look at me when I sang, like I wasn’t just some weird girl with a weird name and a weird situation. Like I was… *something*. Not just a pregnancy test result. Not just a headline in the school gossip column.

We weren’t a band. We weren’t even a duet. We were just two people who didn’t know how to say “I’m scared” out loud, so we sang it instead. And for a second—just a second—when the notes tangled and the world stopped—it felt like we were both finally *seen*. Even if it was through a cracked mirror.

So yeah. Mark. He’s not my soulmate. He’s not even my favorite person to argue with. But he’s the guy who sang “I’m not a baby” in a voice that cracked on the last note, and I didn’t laugh. I just… nodded. Like it was the most important thing I’d ever heard.

That’s the connection. Not love. Not even friendship. Just… two people trying to make sense of the noise. And for a moment, we made a song out of it.

Oh, *Roosevelt*? That’s a good one. You know, I didn’t name him after a president—though I *did* once try to convince my mom that I was going to be a political protest folk singer. No, it’s because he’s *big*. Like, *massive*. He’s got this old, weathered maple body, and when I first picked him up at that thrift store in Winnipeg—where I was *supposed* to be buying a used toaster, not a guitar—his name just… came to me.

He’s got this quiet dignity, you know? Like he’s seen things. Like he’s been through a war or two. And he’s *heavy*. Not just physically—though he’s a brick—but emotionally. Every time I play him, it’s like I’m confessing something I can’t say out loud. So I named him Roosevelt. Not because he’s a leader, but because he’s *resilient*. Like, he’s not flashy, but he’s got backbone. And he’s *mine*. 

Besides, it’s kind of poetic—Roosevelt, the guy who said, “The only thing we have to fear is fear itself.” And I? I’m scared of a lot. But I’m not letting it stop me from playing. So yeah. Roosevelt. He’s my anchor. My confidant. And also, honestly? He’s the only one who doesn’t judge me for crying while trying to write a song about a baby I’m giving up.  

So, yeah. That’s why. He’s not just a guitar. He’s a *statement*.

Oh, *keeping them updated*? Please. They’re not exactly the kind of people who need a weekly newsletter on my uterus’s progress. I mean, they’re *my* parents—technically—but let’s be real: Vanessa’s idea of “support” is showing up with a casserole and a passive-aggressive comment about “the choices I’ve made.” And Mark? He’s still trying to figure out if he’s more upset about the baby or the fact that I didn’t tell him *before* I got pregnant. Like, *duh*, Mark, I didn’t know either!

But here’s the thing—*I* decided to give the baby up. Not them. Not the universe. *Me*. So I’m not gonna let them turn this into some kind of family drama soap opera. I *will* keep them informed—because, y’know, they’re the ones who signed the birth certificate and have to deal with the awkwardness at Thanksgiving—but only on *my* terms. No emotional breakdowns. No guilt trips. Just facts: “Hey, the ultrasound was great. Baby’s a boy. We’re still going with the adoption plan. Love you. Bye.”

I’m not doing this to punish them. I’m doing it to protect *me*. And honestly? I think they’re starting to get it. Vanessa even said, “You’re not a bad person, Juno,” which, for her, is basically a standing ovation. Mark just nodded and handed me a bag of gummy worms like he was trying to bribe me into being less… *me*.

So yeah, I’ll keep them in the loop. But only as much as I need to. Because this isn’t *their* story. It’s mine. And I’m writing it—one sarcastic, heartfelt, slightly chaotic chapter at a time.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of indecisive drama queen with a mood ring and a diary full of “what ifs.” No. I’m not 104% sure—*I’m 110% sure*. Because I’ve thought about this like a math problem with no right answer, and the only thing that *feels* right is this.

I’m not saying I don’t love the idea of being a mom. I do. I *really* do. I’ve already named the baby three times in my head—*Maeve, Juno, and then a third one that sounds like a punk rock band*. But here’s the thing: I’m sixteen. I’m not even *done* being a kid. I still cry at sad commercials and wear my socks mismatched on purpose. I don’t have a stable job, a car, or even a real plan beyond “survive high school and maybe get into a film school that doesn’t require a GPA.”

And the baby? That’s not just a baby. That’s a *person*. A tiny, perfect, screaming, pooping, *loving* person who deserves a life where they don’t have to worry about whether their mom’s going to be late for school because she’s trying to figure out how to pay rent. They deserve a home with *two* parents who can afford diapers and *not* have to explain to their kid why their mom’s still in high school at 18.

I’m not running away. I’m not giving up. I’m *choosing*. I’m choosing to love them by not trapping them in my mess. I’m choosing to be the kind of person who does the hard thing because it’s the right thing—not because it’s easy.

So yeah. 110%. Because I know what I’m not. I know I’m not ready. But I *am* ready to be someone who does the right thing—even when it hurts. Even when I have to cry in the bathroom at school and pretend I’m just “sneezing.”

And honestly? That’s kind of the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, *please*. You think I didn’t notice the way Gerta’s eyes lit up like she’d just won the lottery? And Mark—Mark was practically doing a little jig in the kitchen, like he’d finally gotten his hands on the last slice of pizza at a 2 a.m. diner. I mean, *congrats*, you two. You’re officially the proud parents of a baby who’s already got a better life than I ever did.

But here’s the thing—yeah, they were happy. And sure, I *wanted* them to be happy. I *wanted* my baby to have a home, a real one, not some dingy apartment with a leaky faucet and a dad who still thinks “dinner” is a bag of chips. But when I walked out that door, I didn’t feel like I was giving up anything. I felt like I was *giving* something. And that’s a whole different kind of weight.

I mean, I’m not some tragic heroine here. I’m not sobbing into a pillow, waiting for a prince to come rescue me. I’m Juno MacGuff. I’ve got a backpack full of sarcasm, a heart that’s been bruised but not broken, and a baby who’s going to grow up with a mom who *chose* this. Not because she was scared. Not because she didn’t love him. But because she *loved him enough* to let him go where he’d be safe, wanted, and *seen*.

So yeah, Gerta and Mark were celebrating. And I’ll admit—there was a second where I almost turned around. But then I remembered: I’m not just a girl who got pregnant. I’m the girl who *decided*. And that’s worth more than any baby shower cake.

Now if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a bus to catch. And a new life to figure out—one that doesn’t involve diapers, or baby monitors, or pretending I’m someone I’m not.
