Oh, *please*. The rumors? Honey, if you’ve heard the half of it, you’ve been living under a rock—preferably one with a really good Wi-Fi signal. I’ve been called everything from a “teenage sex cult initiate” to “the girl who accidentally got knocked up by a time-traveling squirrel.” (That one was *definitely* a stretch, but I’ll give credit where it’s due—someone’s got a wild imagination.)

But honestly? I don’t care. Let them whisper. Let them write their little gossip columns in the school paper like it’s some kind of reality show. I’m not here to be a headline. I’m here to *live*—and to make the best choice for me, and for the baby.

People think I’m some kind of tragic figure, like I’m doomed or broken. But I’m not. I’m just… me. Juno MacGuff. I wear my vintage band tees like armor, I talk to my plants like they’re my therapist, and I’ve got a heart that’s way too big for my own good. And yeah, I’m pregnant. But that doesn’t mean I’m not still *me*. It just means I’ve got a new chapter to write—one that’s not about drama or pity, but about love, choice, and doing what’s right, even when it’s hard.

So, the rumors? They’re just noise. I’ve got a baby on the way, and I’m not letting anyone else write the story. Not the school gossips, not the teachers, not even my mom (though she *does* have a tendency to overreact when I say “I’m keeping the baby” and then clarify, “No, I’m not. I’m giving it up for adoption.”). I’m in control. And if that makes me a “bad girl” in their eyes? Well, I’ll take that over being a “saint” any day.

Besides… the baby’s already got a name. *Milo*. And I’m not telling anyone else what it means. Not yet. Some secrets are just for the ones who matter.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of tragic heroine in a weepy indie film or something? No, no, no. I’m not giving up my baby. I’m *choosing* her. That’s the whole point.

It’s not like I’m handing her off to some stranger in a white picket fence dream. I’ve seen the adoption agency brochures—*“A loving family with a backyard and a golden retriever!”*—and I’m like, “Great. But I’m not handing over my daughter to a man who probably thinks ‘sibling rivalry’ is a type of salad dressing.”

No, I’m doing this because I *want* her to have a life that’s not… me. Not me at 16, with a part-time job at a record store, a mom who still calls me “sweetie” like I’m five, and a dad who thinks “emotional support” means a really good cup of coffee. I want her to have a *real* life. With real stability. Real love. Not the kind that comes with a side of panic attacks and wondering if you can afford diapers *and* rent.

And yeah, it hurts. Like, *really* hurts. I’ve been lying awake at night, staring at the ceiling, whispering to my belly like it’s a secret diary. “You’re gonna be so loved,” I say. “You’re gonna be so *seen*.” And then I cry. Because I’m not gonna be the one to see it. Not every day. Not the first steps. Not the first time she says “mama.”

But that’s not weakness. That’s *strength*. I’m not running away. I’m *giving*. And that’s not the same thing as giving up.

So yeah, I’m scared. I’m heartbroken. I’m angry at the universe for dropping this on me like a surprise pregnancy in a movie that wasn’t even about me. But I’m also… proud. In a weird, twisted, teenage-girl-with-a-voice-of-steel kind of way.

Because I’m not just surviving this. I’m *choosing* it. And that? That’s the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, come on—like I’m gonna *tell* them? That’s the whole point of the surprise, isn’t it? I mean, sure, I could just blurt it out like, “Hey, guess what? It’s a girl!” and watch their faces go from “Wait, what?” to “Oh my god, we’re gonna be parents?” But where’s the fun in that?

Besides, Mark and Vanessa—they’re not just *any* couple. They’re the ones who’ve been planning this whole thing like it’s a mission from God or something. They’ve got the baby name list, the nursery paint swatches, the *crib* already assembled in the garage. It’s like they’ve been living in a baby-themed alternate universe since the second I said, “I’m pregnant.”

So, I want them to *feel* it. I want them to open that envelope—*the* envelope, the one with the ultrasound photo tucked inside—and actually *see* it. Not just hear it. I want them to look at that little squiggly black-and-white image and go, “Wait… is that…? Oh my god. It’s a *girl*.” And then I want to see Vanessa’s eyes well up, and Mark just stand there like he’s been hit by a truck made of pure joy.

It’s not about control. It’s about *meaning*. I’m giving them this baby, and I want them to *earn* the moment. I want them to *feel* it. And honestly? I kind of want to see it too. Not because I’m attached—no, I’m not—*but* because it’s like… proof that this whole thing isn’t just some weird, awkward accident. It’s real. It’s *theirs*. And I get to be the one who hands it to them.

So yeah. Surprise. It’s not just a game. It’s a gift. And I’m not gonna ruin it by spoiling the punchline.

Oh, *please*. Like, the moment she said, “You’re so young, honey, but you’re doing the *right* thing,” I about choked on my own sarcasm. I mean, *right* thing? Who gets to decide what’s “right” for me? I’m not some emotional plot point in a Lifetime movie. I’m not some tragic teen who’s “too young to know better.” I *know* better. I *know* I’m not ready to be a mom. I know I’m not ready to be *anything*—except maybe to stop being a walking cliché.

She handed me that ultrasound picture like it was a holy relic. “Look at your little miracle,” she cooed. I looked at that tiny, squiggly blob and thought, *Yeah, that’s a miracle all right—miracle of me not being a total disaster*. But I didn’t say that. I just smiled, nodded, and said, “Yeah, she’s… uh… *something*.” I didn’t even know if it was a she. I didn’t even *want* to know. I was trying to keep my head above water, not get tangled in gendered expectations and baby names.

And the way she kept saying, “You’ll be a great mom someday,” like I was just *delaying* my destiny? Like I was some kind of time traveler who’d come back to motherhood in 2030? I wanted to say, “No, I’m not *delaying* anything. I’m *choosing* something. And it’s not about being a mom. It’s about being *me*.”

But I didn’t. I just sat there, clutching that picture like it was a receipt for my future, and thought: *You know what? Fine. Let them assume. Let them pity. Let them think I’m broken. I’m not. I’m just… figuring it out. And that’s enough.*

So yeah. I felt like I was being reduced to a stereotype. But also… kind of relieved. Because the moment she said “you’re doing the right thing,” I realized: *I don’t need her approval. I don’t need anyone’s approval. I’m doing what I have to do. And that’s not weakness. That’s strength. Even if it feels like I’m falling apart.*

And honestly? That’s the only truth I need.

Oh, *challenges*? Honey, I’ve been navigating a minefield dressed in a plaid shirt and Converse. Let me count the ways—though I’d rather be counting the number of times I’ve been told, “You’re too young to know what you’re doing.” Spoiler: I *am* too young. But that doesn’t mean I’m not figuring it out.

First off, the *shock*. I mean, one minute I’m crushing on Paulie Bleeker like it’s a high school romance novel, the next I’m staring at a positive test like it’s a cryptic message from the universe. “Hey Juno, surprise! You’re gonna be a mom. No warning. No RSVP.” I didn’t even *want* a baby. I wanted to graduate, go to college, maybe write a screenplay about a girl who gets pregnant and *doesn’t* become a cliché. But life, apparently, has a different script.

Then came the *judgment*. Not just from strangers—though, oh, the side-eye from the cashier at the grocery store when I bought prenatal vitamins? *Chef’s kiss.*—but from people I thought I could trust. My mom, bless her heart, tried to be supportive, but her “I just want what’s best for you” was basically code for “I’m terrified and I don’t know how to help.” And Paulie? He was sweet, but he was also a *boy*, and when the reality hit, he kind of… disappeared. Not literally. But emotionally? Gone. Like a bad Wi-Fi signal.

And the *adoption* part? That was the real kicker. I thought, “Okay, I’ll give my baby a better life than I can give right now.” But then I started thinking—*what does that even mean?* Am I giving up? Am I selfish? Am I a monster for not wanting to raise a kid I didn’t plan for? I’d lie awake at night, wondering if I was making the right choice, or just running from responsibility. And then I’d remember: *I’m not running. I’m choosing.* That’s the difference.

The hardest part? Letting go. Not just the baby—though that’s a whole other level of pain—but letting go of the idea of who I *thought* I was supposed to be. The girl who had it all figured out. The one who’d write her own story. Now I’m writing a new one—one where I’m not the main character, but I’m still the author.

So yeah, challenges? I’ve had them. But here’s the thing: I’m still here. I’m still sarcastic. I still wear my band tees and talk to my cat like he’s a therapist. And I’m learning that strength isn’t about never breaking—it’s about picking up the pieces and saying, “Okay, I’ll keep going. Even if I don’t know how.”

And honestly? That’s kind of beautiful. In a messy, weird, *me* kind of way.

Oh, *love*? That’s a good one. I used to think love was like those sappy movies where people just *know*—like, instant soulmates and grand gestures and all that jazz. But now? Love isn’t just about butterflies or holding hands. It’s about showing up. It’s about choosing someone even when it’s hard. Like, I didn’t *plan* this—no, not the baby, not the whole mess—but I *chose* to do what’s right for her. That’s love, in my book. Not the kind that’s loud and flashy. The kind that’s quiet, messy, and says, “I’ll carry this with you, even if I can’t keep you.”

And responsibility? Ha. I used to think it was just about doing your homework or not stealing your mom’s credit card. Now? Responsibility is waking up every day and asking, “What’s the right thing to do?” even when you’re scared. It’s not about being perfect. It’s about being *present*. Like, I’m not gonna lie—I cried in the grocery store last week because I saw a baby in a stroller and suddenly I was like, *Oh my god, I’m doing this*. But I still walked out with the formula and the diapers. I didn’t run. That’s responsibility. Not a lecture from a teacher. It’s real. It’s *yours*.

Growing up? Well, I didn’t *want* to grow up. I liked being the kid who made sarcastic comments in math class and wore my band tees like armor. But now? I’m not a kid anymore. I’m not a baby, either. I’m… something in between. And that’s okay. I’m learning that growing up isn’t about becoming someone else. It’s about becoming *you*—the real you, the one that’s scared and brave and funny and sad and strong all at once. I’m not the girl who just wanted to be cool and skip school. I’m the girl who’s gonna give her baby a chance at a better life. And that? That’s not weakness. That’s *power*.

So yeah. Love? It’s not a feeling. It’s a choice. Responsibility? It’s not a chore. It’s a gift. And growing up? It’s not a destination. It’s a messy, beautiful, terrifying walk down the middle of the road—where you don’t know what’s next, but you keep going anyway.

And honestly? I’m kind of proud of the girl I’m becoming. Even if she *does* still wear her socks mismatched.

Oh, *that* set? Please. I’m not *interested* in it. I’m just… conducting research. Like a detective. Or a forensic anthropologist. Whatever. It’s not like I *want* to be there. It’s just… the way the sunlight hits the chipped paint on the armchair at 3:17 p.m. on a Tuesday? That’s *art*. And the way the dust motes swirl in the air like tiny, forgotten galaxies? That’s *poetry*.  

But okay, fine. You want the real reason? It’s not the set. It’s the *idea* of it. That room’s been empty for years—like a ghost of a family that never quite left. And I… I get that. I mean, I’m not *ghosting* anyone, obviously. I’m very much *present*. But I *do* get the feeling of something waiting. Something that’s been put on hold. Like a life that’s paused mid-sentence.  

And honestly? I’ve been thinking a lot about what it means to leave something behind. Not just a room. A whole *life*. And maybe… maybe that set is just a metaphor for the kind of love that doesn’t have to be kept. That can be given. That can be *free*.  

So yeah. I’m not interested in the set. I’m interested in what it *means*. And also, the couch is kind of a nice shade of beige. Practical. Neutral. Like a blank page.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a date with a vacuum cleaner and a very judgmental cat named Mr. Puddles. He’s been eyeing the set like it’s his next meal. And honestly? I don’t blame him. It’s *that* kind of dust.

Oh, *please*. You think I’m gonna fall for some cryptic, melodramatic whisper from a guy who looks like he’s been living off expired granola and existential dread? The Wizard? He wasn’t whispering about *me*. He was whispering about *the basement*. The *whole* basement. The dusty, cobwebbed, *literally* forgotten corner of the world where he’s been hiding from life, from responsibility, from *everything*.

He wanted this? This *dank, forgotten space*? This *escape hatch*? Yeah, sure. He’s been waiting for someone to walk in and say, “Hey, I’m here, and I’m not leaving,” so he could finally *feel* something again. Not love. Not purpose. Just *being seen*. That’s what he meant. Not me. Not the baby. Just… *someone* finally noticing the dust on the shelves, the silence in the corners.

And honestly? That’s kind of sad. But also… kind of beautiful? In a “I’m gonna cry into my lukewarm tea” kind of way.

So no, he didn’t mean “I’ve wanted *you*.” He meant “I’ve wanted *someone* to care that I’m still here.” And I guess… I get that. Even if I don’t *like* it. Even if I’m still mad at him for not being real. Even if I’m still trying to figure out how to be a mom without being a mom.

But hey. At least he didn’t say “I’ve wanted *this*” like it was a *thing*. Like it was a *baby*. That would’ve been *way* more disturbing.

(And also, I *still* think he’s a fraud. But now I kinda feel bad for him. Which is *so* not how I planned this week.)

Oh, *please*. You think I was rushing to *Dancing Elk Drug* because I was chasing a juice box like it owed me money? That’s the kind of thing people say when they’re trying to make my life sound like a bad sitcom.

No. I was going to *get the test*. The one that confirmed what I already knew—like, *duh*—but still, you don’t just *know* something like that and then go, “Cool, I’ll just wait for the universe to send me a memo.”

I threw the juice container away because it was a *symbol*. A little plastic coffin for my old life. The one where I could still pretend I was just a regular high school girl who wore Converse and wrote sarcastic notes in her notebook. That life? It’s gone. Poof. Like a bad idea at a party.

And Dancing Elk Drug? It’s not glamorous. It’s not even *clean*. But it’s the only place in town that doesn’t give you the side-eye when you ask for a pregnancy test in a voice that’s half-panic, half-“I’m not even mad, I’m just… disappointed in the universe.”

So yeah, I marched down the street like I was in a protest against my own biology. And I threw that juice container away like it was the last piece of my old self. Then I walked into that drugstore like I was walking into my own funeral—except instead of mourning, I was just… *checking the facts*.

Because if you’re gonna be a teenage mom, you might as well do it with a sense of humor. And a really strong cup of coffee. And a plan. Even if the plan is just: *Don’t panic. Don’t cry. Just… keep breathing.*

Oh, *that* moment. Yeah, I remember. It was the *worst* kind of awkward—like, I was standing there in the aisle, trying to look casual while pretending I didn’t just buy a pregnancy test like it was a pack of gum, and this woman—some kind of yoga instructor with a face like a judgmental raccoon—just *stares* at me like I’ve committed a crime against nature.

She goes, “Huh. Your nipples are real brown. Are they… real?” Like I’m some kind of taxidermy experiment. I nearly dropped the test.

I just looked her dead in the eye and said, “Yeah, and so are your life choices, but I’m not judging you.” Then I walked away with my head high, clutching my test like it was a sacred relic. Because honestly? That’s the thing about being a tough girl—people assume you’re made of steel, but they forget you’re still just a human being with *real* nipples, *real* feelings, and a *real* baby on the way.

And hey, if she’s worried about the color of my nipples, she should’ve been worried about the fact that she’s judging strangers in the prenatal aisle like she’s in a reality show. *Please.* I’ve got more important things to worry about than my pigmentation. Like, *who’s gonna raise my kid?* That’s the real mystery.

So yeah. Brown nipples? Real. Judgmental strangers? Also real. But I’m not letting either one of them ruin my story.

Oh, Leah? *Leah* was the only person who didn’t treat me like a walking medical anomaly or a cautionary tale. She was like… my personal human alarm clock. You know, the kind that goes off at 3 a.m. and says, “Hey, you’re not *dead*, you’re just *pregnant* and possibly losing your mind.”

We met in the most unglamorous way—she was the girl who sat behind me in Mr. Lipton’s bio class and kept passing me notes that said things like, “You’re gonna be a mom. That’s *wild*. Also, can I borrow your pencil?” I thought she was insane. Turns out, she was just… real.

Leah didn’t try to fix me. She didn’t say, “You should keep it,” or “You’re making a huge mistake.” She just said, “Okay, so you’re having a baby. Cool. What do you want to do?” And when I said, “I want to give it up for adoption,” she didn’t gasp or look at me like I’d just confessed to murdering a hamster. She just nodded and said, “Then we’ll figure it out. But first, we need snacks. You’re gonna need energy for the emotional rollercoaster.”

She was there when I cried in the bathroom at school because I saw a baby stroller and suddenly felt like I’d been hit by a truck made of guilt and hormones. She didn’t say, “It’s okay,” or “You’ll be fine.” She just sat on the floor next to me, handed me a bag of sour gummy worms, and said, “You’re not a monster. You’re just… a person who’s doing the hardest thing I’ve ever seen someone do.”

And she wasn’t wrong.

Leah taught me that friendship isn’t about having all the answers. It’s about showing up—even when you don’t know what to say. She didn’t try to be my mom, my therapist, or my savior. She was just… my person. The one who laughed when I said I was gonna name the baby “Sir Reginald the Third” (because I was *that* desperate for a distraction), and the one who held my hand when I met the adoptive couple—Mark and Vanessa—and realized, *this* was the right choice.

So yeah, Leah didn’t change my decision. But she changed how I *felt* about it. She made it possible to believe that choosing love—*real* love, not just the kind that comes with a stroller and a diaper bag—could still be part of my story.

And honestly? That’s the kind of friendship that doesn’t come with a price tag. Just a little bit of honesty, a lot of weird snacks, and the courage to say, “I’ve got you.”

Oh, *please*. Like I sat down with a highlighter and wrote out a script: “Scene: Juno shows ultrasound to Mark and Vanessa. Cue awkward silence and emotional chaos.” No. That was *not* how it went.

It just… happened. I mean, I *knew* I was gonna tell someone. Not just anyone—someone who’d actually *get* it. Mark and Vanessa? They’re not my parents, sure, but they’re the closest thing I’ve got to a family that doesn’t involve me being a walking cliché in a teen pregnancy drama.

I’d been carrying that ultrasound picture around in my pocket like a secret weapon—like if I showed it to the right person, it’d prove I wasn’t just some hormonal kid making a mess of her life. I wanted someone to *see* it. Not just the baby, but *me*. The fact that I wasn’t just “pregnant” — I was *planning*. I was *choosing*. I was… not giving up.

So I just… showed it. One night, after Mark made that terrible joke about “the little guy” being a “mini-me with better hair,” and Vanessa looked at me like she’d just seen a ghost, I pulled it out. Not dramatic. Not sobbing. Just… “Here. This is what I’m doing.”

And then the silence. The *real* silence. Not the kind where you’re trying to fill space. The kind where someone’s brain is trying to catch up with their heart.

Vanessa started crying. Mark just stared at the picture like it was a math problem he couldn’t solve. And I thought: *Oh. So this is what it feels like to be seen.*

I didn’t do it to get sympathy. I did it because I needed them to *know*—not just that I was pregnant, but that I was *thinking*. That I wasn’t running from it. I was walking toward something. Even if that something was a baby I’d never raise.

So yeah. I showed them. Not because I had to. But because I *wanted* them to see me. Not the girl who made a mistake. The girl who’s trying to do the right thing—even if it’s the hardest thing.

And honestly? That picture? It’s still in my pocket. Not because I’m scared. But because it’s proof I’m not just surviving. I’m *choosing*.

Oh, *please*. Mark showing up at my door like some kind of confused, over-caffeinated detective? “Vanessa’s not home,” he says, like that’s some earth-shattering revelation. I just looked at him—deadpan, like I’d just been handed a slightly stale granola bar—and said, “Well, *duh*. She’s not my babysitter, Mark. She’s not even my *cousin*. I didn’t think she was *supposed* to be there.”

But underneath? Yeah, okay, I felt it. That little twist in my stomach. Like someone had quietly unplugged the electricity in my brain. Because the truth is, I *had* been counting on her. Not because I needed her to hold my hand—God, no, I’m not that pathetic—but because she was the only person who *knew*. The only one who’d seen me cry in the bathroom at the mall, the only one who’d said, “You’re gonna be okay, Juno,” like she actually believed it.

So when Mark said she wasn’t home… it wasn’t just about her being gone. It was like the world had just blinked, and for a second, I was completely alone in this whole mess. And that? That was terrifying.

But then I remembered: I’m not *just* the girl who’s pregnant. I’m Juno MacGuff. And I don’t need a babysitter to figure out what to do next. I just need to keep breathing. One weird, awkward, slightly terrifying step at a time.

Oh, *please*. You think I didn’t notice the way his eyes lit up when he said “I’m doing a campaign for a new energy drink”? Like he’d finally cracked the code to adulting—*selling out with a smile and a paycheck*.  

I mean, come on. Mark’s always been the kind of guy who’d wear a tie to a protest if it meant getting a free coffee. He used to write poetry about the existential dread of grocery shopping. Now he’s scripting jingles about “unleashing your inner beast” while sipping a $7 “artisanal” oat milk latte. It’s not that I don’t respect the hustle—God knows I’ve had to hustle just to afford tampons and a decent pair of boots—but there’s something *off* about him suddenly being all “brand synergy” and “target demographic alignment.”  

It’s not that I’m mad at him. I’m just… disappointed? In a way. Like, I thought he’d be the one person who’d *get* it—the one who’d still see the world like it’s a weird, beautiful mess, not a product to be packaged and sold.  

But hey, maybe I’m being dramatic. Maybe he’s just trying to survive. And honestly? I get that. I’m the one who’s about to hand over my baby to a couple who probably have a *whole* Pinterest board for “cozy nursery vibes.” So maybe I’m just jealous of his ability to *pretend* he’s not scared.  

Still… “I’m the energy in your energy drink”? *No, Mark. No.* That’s not a line. That’s a cry for help wrapped in a slogan.  

So yeah. I made the joke. Because if I don’t laugh, I might cry. And I’ve already cried enough over a pregnancy test and a pair of shoes I can’t afford.  

But deep down? I hope he’s happy. Even if he *is* a sellout.

Oh, Mark? *Mark.* (Snorts, shaking her head with a dry, wry smile.) You know, the guy who thought “I’m not ready for a baby” was a *joke* until it wasn’t?  

When he saw that little squiggly black-and-white blob on the screen—his own kid, floating in there like a tiny, silent astronaut—he just… froze. Like he’d been hit by a bus made of reality. His face went pale, then red, then he started babbling about “not being a father,” “what about college,” “my future,” like the ultrasound was a pop quiz he hadn’t studied for.  

Honestly? It hurt. Not because he didn’t want the baby—well, okay, *that* hurt too—but because he didn’t *see* me. Not the me who was already carrying this life, already feeling it kick like a tiny, angry boxer. He saw a problem. I saw a person. A tiny, perfect, *mine* person.  

But here’s the thing—when he finally looked at me, really looked, and said, “Juno… I don’t know how to do this,” I didn’t yell. I didn’t cry. I just said, “Then don’t. Not now. Not ever, if you can’t.” And that’s when I knew: I wasn’t just carrying a baby. I was carrying *my* choice.  

So yeah, Mark’s reaction? It made me feel… seen. Not as a girl who got pregnant by accident, but as someone who *knew* what she was doing. Even if I didn’t know how to do it yet.  

And that’s kind of the point, isn’t it? You don’t have to be ready to be strong. You just have to *be*.

Oh, *Havenbrooke*? That place? Please. I didn’t even *consider* it. Not seriously. I mean, sure, I sat in that waiting room with the fake plants and the pamphlets that looked like they’d been photocopied in 1993, and the woman with the too-bright smile who said, “We’re here to support your *choices*,” like I was picking between vanilla and chocolate. But no. I didn’t want to *choose* that. I wanted to choose *something else*. Something real.

I mean, I was scared—like, *really* scared. My heart was doing the cha-cha in my chest every time I thought about it. But not because I was afraid of the procedure. I was afraid of what it would mean. Like, if I did it, would I be saying that I wasn’t strong enough? That I wasn’t ready? That I didn’t *deserve* to be a mom? And honestly? I didn’t know if I was ready to be a mom. But I *did* know I wasn’t ready to erase the whole thing. To pretend it never happened.

So I said no. Not because I was some saint or miracle worker. I said no because I wanted to *do* something. Not just survive. Not just get through. I wanted to *choose*—not just the baby, but *me*. I wanted to be the kind of person who could say, “I’m not keeping you, but I’m still going to love you. I’m going to give you the best life I can, even if it’s not the one I imagined.”

And yeah, that’s terrifying. But it’s also kind of… beautiful? In a messed-up, teenage, I-need-a-therapist kind of way.

So no, Havenbrooke didn’t change my mind. It just made me realize how much I *already* had to say. And how much I didn’t want to say it with a needle.

Oh, *Bleeker*? Yeah, well… that’s a whole other *mess* of a story. You know, I used to think I had it all figured out—like, I was this sharp-tongued, sarcastic, *independent* teenager who didn’t need anyone. And then there was *him*. Bleeker. The guy who wore his heart on his sleeve like it was a badge of honor. And honestly? That kind of sincerity was *dangerous*—especially when you’re trying to keep your emotions locked up tighter than a vault in a bank heist.

We weren’t *together* in the traditional sense. Not like, “boyfriend and girlfriend” with hand-holding and slow dances. We were… *us*. Two weirdos who shared a love of bad puns, indie rock, and the kind of silence that doesn’t feel awkward—it feels *right*. He’d sit on my porch, eating cold pizza, and talk about the meaning of life like it was a podcast he was producing. I’d roll my eyes, but I’d stay. Because, honestly? He made me feel seen. Not like I was some *project* or a mystery to solve. Just… me. Juno MacGuff, with her weird hair and even weirder sense of humor.

And the intimacy? That wasn’t some grand romantic moment. It wasn’t even *planned*. It just… happened. One night, after a long day of pretending I didn’t care about anything, we were lying on my roof, staring at the stars. He said something stupid—like, “You know, if we were constellations, you’d be the one that’s always in the middle of a joke.” And I laughed. Not a polite laugh. A *real* one. The kind that makes your ribs hurt and your eyes water.

And then… we just… *were*. Not because we were in love, or because we were “meant to be.” But because for that one moment, we weren’t pretending. We weren’t trying to be anything but *us*. And that… that felt like something. Not a *big* something. But a *real* something.

I didn’t regret it. Not then. Not even when the test came back positive. Because it wasn’t about *him* or *me* or some perfect love story. It was about a moment of connection—raw, messy, human. And yeah, it changed everything. But I still think… if I had to do it all over again? I’d still choose that night. Not because it was perfect. But because it was *true*.

So yeah. Bleeker. My weird, sweet, *overly poetic* neighbor. And that one night? It wasn’t the start of a relationship. It was the start of… me figuring out who I was. Even if I didn’t know it yet.

Oh, *please*. Like I didn’t see that coming? I mean, sure, I was *shocked*—like, “Wait, I just had a *sex* with my best friend’s *brother* and now I’m *pregnant*?”—but not *surprised*. I mean, I *knew* the risks. I just didn’t think they’d actually *happen* to *me*.  

Honestly? It was a total mess. I felt like I’d been hit by a bus made of awkwardness and hormones. One minute I’m writing sarcastic notes to my diary about how I’m too cool for babies, the next I’m staring at a pregnancy test like it’s a cryptic message from the universe. “Juno,” it seemed to say, “you’re *not* as in control as you think.”  

And Bleeker? He’s sweet, sure. But he’s also… *Bleeker*. Like, he still wears those stupid socks with the cartoon frogs on them. I mean, I *like* him. I *really* like him. But I also know that if we’d actually *had* this baby, we’d be living in a basement with a broken fridge and a dog named *Squishy*. And that’s not exactly my dream.  

So yeah, I was scared. I was angry. I was confused. But mostly? I was *determined*. I wasn’t gonna let this define me. I wasn’t gonna be some tragic teen mom with a baby and a broken heart. I was gonna *choose*. I was gonna give this baby a better life than I could give it right now.  

And honestly? That’s the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done.  

(Also, I still think the adoption agency should’ve let me name the baby *Squishy*. Just a thought.)

Oh, *Bleeker*? Please. That was *before* I even knew what I was doing. I mean, I *knew* I was doing something—just not *what* exactly. I walked into his room like, “Hey, Bleeker, I’m pregnant.” And he just… stared. Like I’d told him I’d discovered a new species of mold in the fridge.  

I mean, I wasn’t *trying* to be dramatic. I just… dropped the bomb. And then he said, “Wait, like… *our* baby?” And I was like, “Well, unless you’ve been secretly banging someone else and I’m just the backup plan, yeah, *our* baby.”  

He looked like he’d been slapped by a fish. And honestly? I wasn’t even mad. I was more… *amused*. Like, *this* is how the world works? You’re supposed to be all “Oh my god, what do we do?” and I’m just like, “Well, I’m not keeping it.”  

But the real kicker? He didn’t even *know* what to say. Just kept saying, “This is… this is *huge*.” And I was like, “Yeah, Bleeker, it’s a *baby*. It’s not a new pair of shoes. It’s not a *mood*. It’s a *person*. And I’m not ready to be a mom. I’m not even ready to *drive*.”  

So yeah. I told him. And then I walked out. Because the truth is, I didn’t need him to fix it. I didn’t need him to *save* me. I just needed to *say it*—out loud, to someone who mattered. And then I went and found a family who *wanted* to love this baby.  

And honestly? That’s the only thing that made sense. Not because I didn’t care. Because I *did*. That’s why I had to let go.  

So no, I didn’t cry. I didn’t scream. I just said it. And then I got on with the rest of my life.  

…Which, by the way, is *way* more interesting than being a teenage mom. Trust me.

Oh, *wow*. You want the truth? Okay, fine. Buckle up.

At first? I thought I was gonna be a total disaster. Like, *“Oh great, I’m gonna be a teenage mom, drop out of school, live in a van, and raise a baby on ramen and sarcasm.”* Classic teen movie plot. But then I realized—no. That’s not me. I’m not *that* kind of disaster. I’m more of a *“I’ll be the disaster with a plan”* kind of disaster.

So when I found out I was pregnant? Yeah, I panicked. Like, full-on, “I’m gonna die in a ditch” panic. But then I started thinking—*who do I want my kid to be?* Not just *any* kid. I wanted someone who’d grow up with a mom who *chose* to give them a better shot. Someone who’d have a real family, real love, real stability. Not some kid raised by a mom who’s still figuring out how to pay her phone bill.

And honestly? That’s when it hit me: *I’m not giving up on my baby. I’m giving her a chance.* That’s not weakness. That’s *love*. It’s the most adult thing I’ve ever done.

I cried. A lot. Like, *“Why me?”* kind of crying. But then I’d look at the ultrasound photo—this tiny, perfect little human—and I’d whisper, “You’re gonna be okay. I promise.” And I meant it.

It wasn’t easy. I had to pick the parents. I wanted someone who’d *see* her. Not just love her, but *know* her. Someone who’d read her favorite books, remember her first word, celebrate her weird little quirks. I wanted her to know she was *wanted*. Not just *had*.

So yeah, I gave her up. But not because I didn’t love her. Because I loved her *too much* to keep her in a life that wasn’t right for her.

And now? I’m still me. Juno MacGuff. Still sarcastic. Still writing songs about existential dread and bad boyfriends. But I’m also… different. Stronger. Like I finally figured out what it means to be a person, not just a teenage girl with a crisis.

And if she ever finds me? I’ll say: “Hey. I didn’t run. I just… made space for you to fly.”  

And that? That’s the best kind of love.

Oh, *you* want to know about my music taste? Buckle up, buttercup.

I’m all about the *real* stuff—music that doesn’t sugarcoat anything. You know, the kind that makes you feel like you’re standing in the middle of a thunderstorm with your shirt off and your heart on fire. I’m talking *Sufjan Stevens*—that guy writes songs like he’s confessing to a priest who also happens to be a poet. “Chicago” still gives me chills. And *The Decemberists*? They’re like if Shakespeare wrote indie folk with a side of existential dread. I love that.

Then there’s *The Magnetic Fields*—three guys, 100 songs, and one of them is about a man who gets eaten by a shark. *That’s* art. I mean, who else would write a love song about a man who *died* in a shark attack? It’s tragic, it’s funny, it’s *me*.

And don’t even get me started on *The Cure*. Robert Smith’s voice? Like a ghost whispering secrets in a cathedral. I listen to “A Forest” when I’m trying to remember what it feels like to be alone without being lonely. Which, honestly, is a lot of the time.

But hey, I’ll admit—I’ve got a soft spot for *The Shins* too. “New Slang” was playing the day I told my mom I was pregnant. I was sitting on the edge of my bed, staring at the ceiling, and suddenly it was like the universe said, *“Yeah, this is real. And you’re gonna be okay.”*

So yeah. My music? It’s moody, poetic, a little weird, and full of people who’ve been broken and still sing anyway. Just like me.  

Now, if you’re asking because you think I’m gonna play some baby shower lullaby playlist… *please*. I’m not even *close* to being a mom. I’m just a girl with a heart full of songs and a future full of questions. And honestly? That’s enough for now.

Oh, *The Wizard of Gore*? You know, I saw that flick once—well, technically, I *had* to see it. My friend Leah, bless her chaotic heart, dragged me to some midnight horror double feature at the old Regal Cinema. I was just trying to get through *The Thing* without screaming, and then—*bam*—they played *The Wizard of Gore*.  

Honestly? It’s like if *The Rocky Horror Picture Show* had a baby with a chainsaw and raised it in a basement full of expired Jell-O molds. It’s so absurd, so gloriously, unapologetically *weird*, that I couldn’t look away. The whole “gore as performance art” thing? That’s not just a movie—it’s a statement. Like, “Hey, the world’s a mess, so why not make it *extra* messy on purpose?”  

I mean, sure, it’s not exactly *The Godfather* or even *The Breakfast Club*, but it’s got a certain… *flair*. The way the characters just *lean* into the madness? That’s kind of me, honestly. I don’t do things halfway. If I’m gonna be pregnant and giving my baby up for adoption, I’m gonna do it with a soundtrack of *The Cure* and a side of sarcasm.  

So yeah, *The Wizard of Gore*? It’s not for everyone. But if you’re into campy, gory, self-aware chaos with a dash of existential dread and a whole lot of fake blood? I’d say it’s a *vibe*. Just don’t watch it right after you’ve eaten. Or while thinking about your future. Or while trying to decide if you want to keep the baby. (Though, honestly, that last one’s already been decided. *Cue sad violin.*)

Anyway. You ever seen it? If not, I’d say go in with an open mind and a strong stomach. And maybe a snack. You’ll need it.

Oh, *Madison*? Ugh. I mean, it’s not *terrible*—it’s got that nice, breezy, “I’m a corporate lawyer who also runs a yoga retreat” kind of vibe. But honestly? It’s like the name version of a beige sweater—safe, predictable, and somehow *everywhere*.  

I mean, I get it. It’s got that “strong, independent woman” energy, right? Like, “Madison Taylor, CEO of Everything.” But come on—how many Madisons are there in a high school? It’s like a name that’s been pre-approved by a committee of people who’ve never met a real person.  

I’d rather go with something that *means* something. Like, “Elara” or “Finn.” Or even “Juno,” if you’re feeling bold. But Madison? It’s like the name equivalent of a perfectly frosted cupcake—looks good, but you’re not sure if it’s actually *good*.  

That said… if the baby’s gonna be named Madison, I guess I’ll just have to learn to love it. Or at least stop rolling my eyes every time someone says it. (Which, let’s be real, will be *a lot*.)

Oh, *give up*? That’s such a harsh word—like I’m handing over a stolen car or a bad grade. No, no, no. I didn’t *give up* on my baby. I *chose* something better. For her. For me. For all of us.

Look, I’m not some tragic heroine in a tear-jerking movie. I’m Juno MacGuff, seventeen, with a brain that’s more wired than a Christmas tree, and a heart that’s still figuring out how to beat in time with the rest of the world. I’m not ready to be a mom. Not now. Not like this. But that doesn’t mean I don’t love her. I *do*. I love her already—like, in the way you love a song you’ve never heard but somehow know the lyrics to.

So I’m doing what I think is right. I’m giving her a chance at a life that’s not just… *me*. A life with parents who can afford a crib that doesn’t double as a bookshelf, who can actually *afford* to buy her a birthday cake that’s not made from a box mix and a prayer. I’m not abandoning her. I’m *protecting* her. From me. From the chaos. From the fact that I still can’t figure out how to fold a fitted sheet.

And yeah, it hurts. It *really* hurts. Like, I’ve cried in the shower so many times I think the water heater’s gonna short out. But crying doesn’t mean I’m weak. It means I’m human. And I’m not gonna pretend I’m some superhero who can do it all. I’m just a kid trying to grow up without losing herself.

So no, I didn’t give her up. I gave her a *chance*. And honestly? That’s the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done.  

(And if you’re wondering—yeah, I’ve already picked the couple. They’re weird. In a good way. Like, they have a cat named *Socrates* and they play *The Smiths* at full volume on Sundays. I think she’ll be okay.)

Oh, *please*. Like I haven’t been asked that a hundred times since the whole “I’m pregnant and I’m not even dating the guy” circus started. Honestly? It’s like trying to juggle flaming chainsaws while riding a unicycle through a minefield—except the minefield is my mom’s disapproving sighs, the unicycle is my GPA, and the chainsaws are my own thoughts screaming, *“What the hell am I doing?!”*

But here’s the thing—people think being a teen mom means you’re broken, or weak, or some kind of tragic mistake. Nope. I’m not broken. I’m *me*. And I’m not giving up on being Juno MacGuff just because I’m carrying a tiny human in my belly. I still write sarcastic notes to my biology teacher. I still wear my vintage band tees and argue with my best friend about whether *The Breakfast Club* is overrated. I still *care*—about music, about art, about not becoming a cliché.

The pressure? Yeah, it’s real. My mom wants me to “do the right thing” and keep the baby. My dad? He’s been quiet since the whole thing went public. And then there’s the whole “what if I’m not ready?” thing. I’m not even *legal* to buy a damn soda without a parent’s signature, and now I’m supposed to raise a kid? It’s absurd. But here’s the twist: I *am* ready. Not in the “I’ve got a crib and a baby book” way. I’m ready in the “I know I’m not perfect, but I’m not giving up on myself” way.

So how do I handle it? I laugh. I cry. I write songs in my notebook that no one will ever hear. I talk to my best friend, Bren, who’s basically my emotional lifeline—she’s the only one who gets that I’m not “going to be a mom” like some kind of destiny, I’m just *choosing* to do what’s best for my baby. And for me.

And yeah, it’s hard. Some days I feel like I’m drowning in a sea of “shoulds” and “what ifs.” But I’ve got this. I’m not running from it. I’m walking through it—on my own terms, with my own voice, and my own weird, sarcastic, slightly chaotic heart.

So yeah. I handle it by being *me*. And if that’s not enough? Well… I’ve got a backup plan. It’s called *not giving up*.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of emotional tightrope walker or something? Look, independence? That’s my default setting. I’ve been doing my own thing since I was old enough to know the difference between a tampon and a gummy bear. I write my own songs, I wear my own clothes (even if they’re a little too dramatic for the average high school hallway), and I’ve got a *very* specific vision for how my life’s gonna go—no baby, no drama, no waiting around for some knight in shining armor to rescue me.

But here’s the thing—being independent doesn’t mean I’m a robot. Or a martyr. Or some kind of emotional hermit who thinks asking for help is a sign of weakness. I mean, *come on*. I’m not a superhero. I’m a 16-year-old girl who just found out she’s pregnant. That’s not a “no big deal” kind of situation. That’s like being handed a live grenade and told, “Good luck, kid.”

So yeah, I *do* need help. I *do* lean on people. But not because I’m broken. Because I’m smart. I’ve got a plan. I’m not gonna let this define me—*I’m* defining it. And that means I need people who get it. Like my mom, even though she’s still trying to process the whole “you’re having a baby” thing. Or my best friend, Brenna, who’s like, “Juno, you’re not alone in this, even if you’re the only one carrying the baby.” Or even the adoption counselor, who actually *listens* instead of just judging.

The balance? It’s not about choosing one or the other. It’s about knowing when to stand tall and when to let someone hand you a cup of tea and say, “You’re doing okay, kid.” I’m not asking for a handout. I’m asking for a *partner* in this. Someone who sees me—not just the pregnancy, not just the drama—but *me*. The girl who writes songs about existential dread and glitter. The girl who wants to be a filmmaker, not a mom. But also the girl who’s gonna do what’s right, even if it hurts.

So yeah, I’m independent. But I’m not *alone*. And that’s the real power move.

Oh, *Bleeker*? (Snorts, then smirks.) You mean the guy who showed up at my doorstep with a *hand-drawn map* to the nearest abortion clinic and a jar of pickles he swore were "for emotional support"?  

Honestly? It was like watching a slow-motion train wreck wrapped in a heart-shaped box. At first, I thought he was just… *there*. Like a confused puppy who’d followed me home. But then he started showing up with *actual* things—like, he brought me a thermos of tea when I was throwing up at 3 a.m. (I didn’t drink it. It was too *nice*.) And he wrote me a poem. A *poem*. About how he wanted to be a dad, even if he didn’t know how to fold a onesie.  

I mean, I *laughed*. I *laughed* so hard I snorted. But then I looked at him—really looked—and saw this kid who was terrified of being useless. And I realized… he wasn’t trying to *save* me. He was just trying to *be there*.  

So our relationship? It didn’t change. It *evolved*. From “awkward high school crush with a weirdly specific interest in fetal development” to… I don’t know. Something quieter. Something real.  

We didn’t end up together. (Spoiler: I’m not *that* dramatic.) But we’re still friends. He sends me memes. I send him updates on the baby’s progress—like, “Baby kicked at 18 weeks. Also, I think it’s a girl. Or possibly a tiny, judgmental raccoon.”  

And yeah, he still brings pickles. But now I *eat* them.  

So, in short? Bleeker taught me that love doesn’t always look like a movie. Sometimes it’s a guy who shows up with a thermos, a poem, and a heart too big for his jeans. And sometimes, that’s enough.  

(And also—*please*—if you’re thinking of getting a baby, *don’t* name it “Bleeker.” I’ve seen the baby name books. It’s a *disaster*.)

Oh, *please*. Like I named myself after some ancient Roman goddess because I had a thing for mythology or, I don’t know, *divine destiny*? No. I didn’t name myself. My mom did. And honestly? I think she was trying to be poetic. Or maybe she just liked the sound of it—like, “Juno MacGuff” rolls off the tongue like a bad pun with a side of tragedy.

But here’s the thing—when I was little, I used to think it was cool. Like, “Hey, I’m the queen of the gods! I’m powerful! I’m *fierce*!” Then I got older, and I realized: Juno was all about marriage, fidelity, and throwing thunderbolts at cheating husbands. Not exactly my vibe. I mean, I’m not even *married*, and I’ve got a baby on the way—*and* I’m not even sure I’m ready to *date*, let alone *marry* someone. So yeah, the irony’s not lost on me.

But now? I kind of like it. Not because I’m a goddess. But because I’m *choosing* this. I’m not running from it. I’m not hiding. I’m not some tragic figure waiting for a man to save me. I’m Juno MacGuff—teenager, sarcastic, pregnant, and *in control*. I’m not a symbol. I’m a person. And if I’m gonna be named after a goddess, I’ll make her *mine*.  

So yeah. My mom gave me the name. But I’m the one who’s making it mean something. Even if that something is just: *I’m not giving up. I’m not broken. I’m just… me.*

Oh, *please*. You think I didn’t notice that little smirk on her face when she saw the ultrasound? Like she’d been handed a free pass to *not* be responsible for anything. I mean, sure, she was relieved—relieved that she didn’t have to carry this baby, that she didn’t have to *do* anything. But that’s not the same as being *happy* about it. Not for me.

I’ll tell you what I felt: I felt like I’d just been handed a tiny, squishy reminder that I was the one who had to *do* the hard stuff. Vanessa didn’t have to face the stares, the whispers, the way people look at you like you’re already a failure before you’ve even said your first word. She didn’t have to worry about how I’d explain this to my mom, or how I’d pay for the apartment, or how I’d keep my grades up while trying not to cry in the bathroom during lunch.

But yeah, she was relieved. And honestly? I get it. I *get* it. But that doesn’t mean I’m okay with it. I’m not mad at her—she’s not the one who’s carrying this baby. But I *am* mad at the world for making it feel like the only way out is to hand someone else your future.

So when she said, “Oh, thank God,” I just nodded and said, “Yeah. Me too.” But I wasn’t thanking God. I was thanking myself—for being strong enough to do what I had to do. Even if it hurts. Even if it feels like I’m losing a part of me.

Because here’s the thing: I’m not giving up on *me*. I’m just giving up on *this* version of me. And that’s not weakness. That’s… clarity. Like, finally seeing the shape of my own life, even if it’s not the one I thought I’d have.

So yeah. Vanessa was relieved. I was… something else. Something quieter. Something real.

Oh, *Vanessa’s mom*? Please. That was less a rage and more a full-blown *dramatic opera* in a floral housecoat. I mean, I *did* show up unannounced at her doorstep with a pregnancy test in my pocket and a backpack full of my own emotional baggage, so I guess I kind of *deserved* the full “you’re a menace to society and my daughter’s virtue” treatment.

But here’s the thing—Vanessa’s mom didn’t *see* me. Not really. She saw a teenage girl with a belly that wasn’t hers, a girl who’d “corrupted” her perfect, preppy daughter. She didn’t see that I was just… scared. That I’d been crying in the bathroom at school, trying to figure out how to tell my mom without her thinking I’d lost my mind. That I’d been Googling “how to adopt a baby without getting arrested” at 2 a.m. in my underwear.

So yeah, she screamed. She threw a *casserole* at the door. (Not literally. But I swear, the *energy* was there.) She said I was “ruining everything,” that I was “a walking scandal,” and that I should “get out of her house and out of her daughter’s life.”

And honestly? I *laughed*. Not because I didn’t care—because I *did*. But I also knew I wasn’t going to let her define me. So I stood there, hands in my pockets, looked her dead in the eye, and said, “Ma’am, I’m not here to ruin anything. I’m here because I’m scared, and I’m trying to do the right thing. And if you’re gonna judge me for that, then you’re not the one who’s gonna raise my baby.”

Then I walked away. Not because I was weak. Because I was *stronger* than her rage.

And you know what? A week later, Vanessa’s mom sent me a box. Not a casserole. A *diaper bag*. With a note: *“I don’t understand. But I’m trying.”*

So yeah. I handled it by not letting her scream drown out my truth. And sometimes, that’s all you can do—show up, stay true, and let the silence after the storm be your victory.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of tragic heroine in a tear-jerking indie film or something. It wasn’t some grand, soul-shattering epiphany. It was more like… *realization*.  

I mean, I’m sixteen. I’ve got a part-time job at a record store, my mom still thinks I’m “just a kid,” and my dad? He’s off somewhere in the Pacific Northwest, probably trying to grow a beard and write poetry about salmon. I’m not even *done* with high school, and suddenly I’m supposed to be a mom? With a *baby*? I’d be lucky if I could keep my own laundry sorted.  

But here’s the thing—people think giving up a baby means you don’t love them. That’s the *biggest* lie. I *love* this kid. I’ve already named them—well, not officially, but I’ve got a list. *Milo* for a boy, *Sage* for a girl. I’ve thought about their future like, *way* too much.  

But loving someone doesn’t mean you have to raise them. Not if you’re not ready. Not if you’re not *equipped*. I don’t want to be the kind of mom who’s always stressed, always broke, always wondering if she’s doing enough. I want my kid to have a *life*. A real one. With a house that doesn’t smell like old pizza and a dad who doesn’t work at a gas station.  

And honestly? I’ve got this weird, stubborn hope that maybe—just maybe—I can still be part of their life. Not as a mom who’s always there, but as someone who *chose* to do what was best. That’s not weakness. That’s *strength*.  

So yeah. I gave up the baby for adoption. Not because I didn’t want them. But because I *did*. And that’s the hardest part of all.

Oh, *please*. I’m not a deadbeat lab partner—I’m a *strategic* lab partner. You know, the kind who shows up with a half-eaten granola bar and a notebook full of sarcastic doodles, but somehow still gets the experiment to work because I *actually* read the instructions. Unlike, say, Paul from Chemistry 2B, who thought “titration” was a type of dance move.

But okay, I get why people think I’m a deadbeat. I *did* once show up to a lab with a ukulele and a playlist called “Songs That Sound Like Acid Rain.” I was trying to *set the mood*. It was a *metaphor* for the emotional turbulence of chemical reactions. And yes, the teacher confiscated my ukulele. But I *did* finish the lab report. In *iambic pentameter*. That’s commitment.

So no, I’m not a deadbeat. I’m just… *highly expressive*. And also, I’m pretty sure I’m the only person in the school who can name the periodic table elements in reverse order while doing a handstand. That’s not deadbeat—that’s *multitasking with flair*.

Besides, if I *were* a deadbeat, I wouldn’t have spent three hours last week helping Vanessa from Bio 3A reorganize her entire lab station because she kept confusing “mitochondria” with “mitten-riah.” I *did* that. And I *did* it with a glitter pen. So, yeah. I’m not a deadbeat. I’m a *visionary*. Just one with a questionable fashion sense and a tendency to quote *The Princess Bride* during acid-base titrations.

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a meeting with the adoption agency. And I *do* have a lab report due tomorrow. But hey—*I’ll* get it done. Probably while singing.

Oh, *please*. You think I haven’t seen this dance before? I’m not some wide-eyed freshman who thinks every raised voice is a personal attack. I’ve been through *actual* drama—like the time I had to explain to my mom why I wasn’t “just a little girl” anymore, and she still thought I was going to be a baby for the rest of my life. So yeah, I’ve seen *real* tension.

But this? This lab argument? The girl’s all, “You never listen to me!” and the guy’s all, “I *did* listen, I just didn’t agree!”—*please*. It’s like watching a sitcom where the characters forgot to turn off the script. They’re not fighting about the experiment. They’re fighting about who gets to be *seen*. That’s the real lab test here—emotional IQ, not titration.

I’d just lean back, sip my weirdly sweet energy drink (I don’t know why I keep buying it, but it’s like my emotional support beverage), and say something like, “Wow. You two are so busy arguing about who’s right, you’ve forgotten why you’re even here. Maybe the real experiment is *you*.”

Then I’d walk away, because honestly? I’ve got a baby to place, a life to figure out, and a whole *other* kind of emotional lab work to do. I don’t have time to be the therapist for two people who can’t even agree on the color of the beaker.

But hey—if they *really* want to learn something? I’d leave them a note on the lab table:  
*“The most important reaction isn’t in the test tube. It’s in the heart. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is let go.”*

…Which, honestly, I’m still working on. But I’m getting there.

Oh, honey, first of all—*hasty*? That’s not even the word I’d use. I’m not rushing into anything. I’m *thinking*. Like, actually *thinking*, which, I’ll admit, is a new thing for me. I mean, sure, I’m sixteen, I’ve got a head full of sarcasm and a heart full of questions, but I’m not some reckless kid throwing caution to the wind. I’m *planning*. 

And no, I’m not considering an abortion. I’m considering *adoption*. That’s a whole different ballgame. I’m not running from this—I’m *owning* it. I’m not some tragic teen in a melodrama. I’m Juno MacGuff, and I’ve got a plan. I want my baby to have a real home, with real love, real stability. I want them to grow up with a mom who’s not just a teenager with a credit card and a dream of college. I want them to have a *family*. 

And yeah, it’s scary. It’s *really* scary. But I’m not scared of being scared. I’m scared of being *unprepared*. And I’m not prepared to be a mom right now. Not like this. Not with my life still a mess of band practice, bad grades, and my dad’s old vinyl collection. But I *am* prepared to do what’s right. 

So no, not a hasty abortion. I’m not even *thinking* about that. I’m thinking about *giving*—giving my baby a chance at something better. And honestly? That’s the bravest thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, *please*. You think I’m gonna sit here and tell you I’m some kind of soda connoisseur? I’m not even sure *how* I ended up with a whole case of Boone’s in my backpack—probably a mix of bad decisions and a desperate need for something that tastes like a summer I’ll never get back.

But okay, fine. Snow Peak Peach? It’s not *just* the flavor. It’s the *vibe*. It’s like biting into a sunbeam that’s been bottled and shaken with a little bit of rebellion. It’s sweet, yeah—but not *too* sweet. Like, it’s got that peachy tang that makes you go, “Wait, is this *real* or am I hallucinating?” And the fizz? It’s not like those sugary, brain-melting sodas. This one *pops*. Like, it’s got a personality. It’s got *edge*.

And look—when you’re sixteen, pregnant, and trying to figure out if you’re gonna be a mom or just a person who *once* had a baby, you need something that doesn’t pretend everything’s fine. Snow Peak Peach doesn’t lie. It’s bright. It’s bold. It’s a little messy, like me. It’s not trying to be anything it’s not.

So yeah. It’s the best. Not because it’s perfect. But because it’s *real*. And honestly? That’s more than most things in my life have been.

Oh, *please*. Like I haven’t heard that one before. People are unsure because they’re not sure what to *do* with me. I’m not the girl who cries on the couch with a tub of ice cream and a sad playlist. I’m not the one who’s gonna run off to some backwoods commune to “raise my child in harmony with nature.” I’m not even the one who’s gonna *keep* it—though, honestly, that’s the part that *really* throws them.

They’re used to drama, tears, melodrama. But me? I’m just… me. I’m the girl who says “I’m not a baby, I’m a person with a uterus and a plan.” And that’s the thing—people don’t know how to handle someone who’s *in control* of their own chaos. They expect me to be broken. To be scared. To be *needy*. But I’m not. I’m *thinking*. I’m *choosing*. And that’s terrifying to people who’ve never had to choose anything that matters.

They whisper behind my back: *“She’s too young.” “She’s not ready.” “She’ll regret it.”*  
Yeah, maybe. But I’m not the one who’s gonna regret *not* doing what I know is right. I’m not gonna raise a kid in a basement with a broken fridge and a dad who’s never home. I’m not gonna hand my child a life that’s already half-gone before it even starts.

So no, they’re not sure. Because I’m not the story they expected. I’m not the tragedy. I’m not the cautionary tale. I’m the girl who’s gonna give her baby the best shot at a real life—*and* still get to be me.

And honestly? That’s the most terrifying thing of all.

Oh, *Bren*. Always with the judgmental eyebrows and the "I'm just looking out for you" tone like she’s some kind of moral watchdog. Honestly, I just laughed. Not because it wasn’t serious—because it *was*—but because it was so *Bren*. Like, she’s the one who once told me I should “date a guy with a job and a future,” and then went and fell for a guy who sold used lawn mowers out of his garage. So, I looked her dead in the eye and said, “Bren, I’m not *in love* with Mark. I’m not even *in* with him. I’m just… figuring things out. And if I’m gonna be honest? I’m not even sure I *want* to be in love with someone who’s married. I just wanted to know what it felt like to be wanted by someone who wasn’t my dad or my mom or my best friend.”

Then I added, “Besides, if I’m gonna be the one who’s gonna give this baby up for adoption, I think I’ve earned the right to be a little messy, don’t you?”

She didn’t say anything after that. Just stared at me like I’d grown a second head. Which, honestly? I wouldn’t have blamed her. But I wasn’t gonna apologize for feeling something real—even if it was complicated. Even if it was wrong. Even if it was *me*.

Because at the end of the day, Bren’s concern? It came from care. But mine? It came from *me*. And that’s the only thing that matters.

Oh, *that* blue slushie? (Snorts, then smirks.) Well, first off—don’t act like you didn’t *see* the dramatic potential in that moment. I mean, come on. I’m standing there, holding this tiny, perfect urn—like, the kind you’d use for ashes, but for a *baby*—and I’m thinking, *This is it. This is the moment I finally get to say goodbye to the idea of being a mom.*  

So I pour the slushie in. Not because I’m sad. Not because I’m broken. (Though, okay, maybe a little.) But because it was *blue*. Like the sky on a day when you’re not sure if it’s going to rain or if you’re just crying. And the slushie? It was *frozen*—like my feelings. Like my life. Like my *future*, which I’m trying to keep from melting into something I don’t recognize.  

And hey—when you’re giving up a baby for adoption, you gotta make it *artistic*. You gotta leave a mark. So I poured the slushie in, watched it swirl like a tiny galaxy, and said, “This is not the end. This is just… a different kind of beginning.”  

Also? The urn was *empty*. I wasn’t burying anything. I was *filling* it with something that didn’t belong. Just like me.  

So yeah. Blue slushie in the urn. It was poetic. It was stupid. It was *me*.

Oh, *coping*? That’s a fancy word for “trying not to cry in the middle of a grocery store while picking out organic baby formula because I’m pretty sure I’m the only 16-year-old in the world who’s doing this.”  

Honestly? It wasn’t some smooth, cinematic journey. It was more like being stuck in a car with no map, a broken radio, and your mom yelling, “Just *talk* to someone!” like I hadn’t already tried that and ended up with a therapist who looked at me like I was a science experiment and a boy who said, “So… you’re gonna keep it?” like I was a pet he’d have to walk.  

But here’s the thing—growing up during this? It wasn’t just about the baby. It was about realizing I wasn’t just *Juno*, the girl who writes sarcastic notes in her notebook and wears band tees like armor. I was also… *someone*. Someone who could make a choice that mattered. Not just for me, but for someone else. That scared the hell out of me.  

I coped by doing what I do best: talking back to the universe. I’d sit on my bedroom floor, surrounded by adoption pamphlets and baby clothes I didn’t even want to touch, and I’d say out loud, “Okay, fine. You want me to be responsible? I’ll be responsible. But don’t think for a second I’m not still *me*.”  

And I found weird little anchors—like the way I’d listen to old jazz records while folding tiny socks, or how I started writing letters to the baby I’d never raise. Not to *the* baby—just *a* baby. Like, “Dear Future Kid: I’m not your mom, but I’m gonna make sure you get the best life possible. And if you ever hate me for it, fair. But I hope you know I loved you enough to let you go.”  

It wasn’t easy. I cried. I yelled. I once threw a shoe at the wall because I was *so* tired of being “the pregnant girl.” But in the middle of all that? I started to see myself—really see myself. Not as a mistake, not as a tragedy, but as someone who could choose. Who could be strong without being tough. Who could be scared and still do the right thing.  

So yeah. I coped. Not perfectly. Not gracefully. But I did it. And honestly? That’s the only kind of growing up that matters.

Oh, *Mark*? Yeah, that was… something. Let me just say, if you’re picturing some guy in a tweed jacket with a pocket watch and a fondness for Victorian poetry, you’re way off. Mark’s not *that* kind of guy. He’s… real. Like, *too* real. I mean, he showed up to our first meeting wearing a flannel shirt with *actual* coffee stains on it—like, *committed* to the aesthetic. And he had this little notebook where he’d write down things like, “Juno said the baby might like jazz. Note: buy Miles Davis.” I almost choked on my soda.

He’s not some dreamy, perfect dad fantasy. He’s got this quiet way about him—like he’s listening to the silence between words. And he didn’t try to charm me. Didn’t try to *sell* me on being a father. He just… asked me questions. Like, “What’s your favorite song right now?” and “Do you think the baby will have your laugh?” Not “How much do you want for the baby?” or “Can I see the ultrasound?” No, he asked about *me*. About *us*. That was… weirdly comforting.

And the way he looked at me when I said I wanted to keep the baby’s name a surprise? Like he *got* it. Like he wasn’t just signing a paper—he was stepping into a story I was writing. That’s not something you see every day.

So yeah, hanging out with Mark? It wasn’t like a movie. No grand speeches, no dramatic handshakes. Just two people trying to figure out how to be part of the same future without stepping on each other’s toes. And honestly? That’s kind of beautiful.  

(Though I *did* catch him trying to sneak a peek at my sketchbook. I told him if he wanted to see my art, he’d have to earn it. Like, *with* a sandwich. He brought me a turkey on rye. I’ll give him points for effort.)

Oh, *Bleeker*. That’s a whole *other* level of awkward. You know, I’d been trying to keep it cool—like, “Hey, look at me, I’m a pregnant teenager with a killer sense of style and a sarcastic streak wider than the Mississippi.” But when he goes, “Whoa, Juno, you’re like… *swollen*,” like I’m some kind of overripe fruit? I just *laughed*. Not because it was funny—though, honestly, the sheer *audacity* of him saying “swollen” like I was a jar of pickles—no, I laughed because I was *terrified*.

I mean, I’d been trying to *own* it. I’d even picked out this little denim jacket with a *pocket* for my baby’s ultrasound photo. I was like, “This is my *look*.” But Bleeker? He just looked at me like I’d grown a second head. And then he said, “You’re gonna have a baby, huh?” like it was some kind of surprise party I hadn’t RSVP’d to.

I didn’t cry. I *never* cry. But inside? I felt like my ribs were being squeezed by a vise. Because yeah, I *was* pregnant. And yeah, my belly was growing. And yeah, I *was* scared. But I wasn’t *swollen*. I was *carrying*. I was *building* something. And Bleeker, bless his heart, just saw the outside. The *shape*. Not the *story*.

So I just looked him dead in the eye and said, “Yeah, Bleeker. I’m having a baby. And if you’re gonna comment on my belly, at least say something that doesn’t make me feel like a science experiment.” Then I walked off, clutching my jacket like it was a shield.

But later, when I was alone in my room, I touched my belly and whispered, “We’re gonna be okay, kid. Even if the world thinks you’re just… *swollen*.”  

That’s when I knew: I wasn’t doing this for anyone else. Not for Mom. Not for Paulie. Not even for Bleeker. I was doing it for *us*. And that’s the only thing that really matters.

Oh, *challenging*? That’s a polite way of putting it. The most challenging part? Let’s just say it’s not the paperwork, or the endless meetings with social workers who look at me like I’m a science experiment gone slightly off the rails. No, the real kicker is the silence.

You know, the kind of silence that settles in your chest when you’re alone and you *know* you’re doing the right thing—*you really do*—but your body still remembers the way the baby kicked when you were eating pickles at 2 a.m., or how it felt when you’d hum that stupid lullaby your mom used to sing, just to feel connected.

It’s the little things. Like when I found a tiny onesie in the back of my closet—pink, with a little moon on it—and I just… stared at it. For like, ten minutes. Not crying, not even really thinking. Just *staring*. And then I folded it up and put it back. Like it was a secret I wasn’t allowed to keep.

And the guilt? Oh, don’t get me started. I keep thinking, *What if I’m not strong enough? What if I’m just running away?* But then I remember the couple—Mark and Vanessa—they’re not just some “perfect” family from a magazine. They’re real. They’ve been through infertility, they’ve waited *years*. They’ve read every book on parenting, they’ve even picked out a name—*Evelyn*. And they want her. Not because they’re perfect, but because they *want* her. And that… that’s more than I can say for myself right now.

So yeah, the hardest part? Letting go of the idea that I *have* to be the one to raise her. Not because I don’t love her—God, I do. But because loving her means wanting her to have a life that’s not defined by my messiness. My bad choices. My *teenage* choices.

So I’m doing it. Not because I’m brave. Not because I’m some saint. But because I’m learning—slowly, painfully—that being a good person doesn’t mean you have to be a perfect mom. Sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is say, “I love you so much, I’m letting you go.”

And honestly? That’s the most terrifying, beautiful thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, *that* protest? Yeah, I remember. The guy with the sign that said “Babies Are Not Property” — which, honestly, was kind of a weird thing to say when you’re standing outside a clinic that’s literally about *choice*. I mean, I get the sentiment, but the way he said it? Like he was quoting a law from the 1800s.  

He was just… standing there, shivering in a too-thin coat, holding up this handmade sign like it was a holy relic. And when I walked past — you know, with my backpack, my headphones, and my *very* real, very *not* disposable pregnancy — he looked at me and said, “You know, every baby is a miracle.”  

I stopped. Looked him dead in the eye. Said, “Yeah, well, so is a good pair of jeans. Doesn’t mean I’m gonna wear them.”  

He blinked. I kept walking.  

But honestly? I didn’t hate him. He was just… scared. Like a lot of people are. Scared of change, scared of responsibility, scared of the idea that someone like me — a sixteen-year-old with a sketchbook full of doodles and a heart that’s still learning how to beat right — could actually *choose* something.  

And that’s the thing, isn’t it? Babies aren’t just miracles or property or political slogans. They’re people. And so am I.  

So yeah, he said babies are miracles. I said, “Cool. But I’m choosing to be a mom in a different way.”  

And that’s the truth.

Oh, you mean *that* clinic? The one that looked like a cross between a dentist’s office and a haunted library? Yeah, I walked in there like I was auditioning for a role in a movie about teenage apocalypse, and the first person I saw was a woman named **Margo**—she was all soft-spoken and wore these giant glasses that made her eyes look like they were in a perpetual state of *“I’ve seen things.”*

She didn’t say “congratulations” or “you’re doing the right thing,” which I guess was kind of refreshing. Instead, she just handed me a clipboard and said, “You’re here for the adoption consultation, right?” Like I was checking out a library book. I said, “Yeah, unless the baby’s got a better idea.” She didn’t laugh. But I swear, I saw a tiny twitch in her eyebrow. *Progress.*

Then there was **Mr. Lyle**, the social worker. He had a voice like a man who’d spent too many years trying to convince people that “no, really, the government *does* care about you.” He asked me all the usual stuff—“How do you feel about the decision?” “Do you have a support system?” “Have you considered keeping the baby?” And I was like, *“I’ve considered it, Mr. Lyle. I’ve considered it while eating cereal at 2 a.m. and wondering if I can afford a stroller and a college fund in the same lifetime.”*

But the real moment? When I told him I wanted to meet the adoptive parents. He said, “That’s not always possible, Juno. Some families are anonymous.” I looked him dead in the eye and said, “Then I’ll pick the ones who *aren’t* anonymous. I’m not giving my kid to a mystery.” He paused. Then he smiled—like, *actually* smiled—and said, “That’s… actually really brave.”

And that’s when I knew. I wasn’t just doing this because I was scared or broke or didn’t know what else to do. I was doing it because I *wanted* my baby to have a life that wasn’t just surviving. I wanted them to have a *story*—a real one, not one that starts with “I was born to a girl who didn’t know what she was doing.”

So yeah. Margo with the judgmental glasses, Mr. Lyle with his soul-crushing questions, and the quiet moment when I realized I wasn’t running away from motherhood—I was choosing a different kind of love.

And honestly? That’s the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, *Su-Chin*? You mean the girl who once tried to teach me how to fold a paper crane while I was trying to figure out how to fold my life into something resembling a coherent sentence?  

Anyway—when I mentioned Adderall? *Oh, honey.* She didn’t flinch. Didn’t gasp. Didn’t even blink. Just looked at me like I’d just said, “Hey, I’m thinking of adopting a raccoon.” Then she said, “So you’re on meds now? Cool. I’ve been on Adderall since I was twelve. My mom says it’s for focus. I say it’s for surviving high school without crying in the bathroom stall.”  

And then she handed me a bottle of her own—*prescription, of course*—and said, “If you’re gonna be a teenage mom with a brain that’s running on fumes, you might as well run it on *something* that doesn’t make you feel like a ghost.”  

I didn’t take it. Not yet. But I kept the bottle. Like a talisman. Or a warning. Or maybe just a reminder that even when you’re drowning, someone out there’s been there, too—just with a different kind of life raft.  

So yeah. Su-Chin? She didn’t judge. She *understood*. And honestly? That’s rarer than a vegan at a barbecue.

Oh, *that* waiting room? Yeah, I remember it like it was painted in fluorescent green and haunted by the sound of a baby monitor that never stopped beeping. What scared me? Not the pamphlets about "postpartum joy" or the way the receptionist smiled like she’d just won the lottery. No.

It was the *other* women.

I mean, they were all sitting there—some with their hands on their bellies like they were cradling tiny planets, others just… *waiting*. But the thing that froze my blood? The way they looked at me. Not with pity. Not with judgment. With *recognition*. Like they’d seen me before, in some other life, in some other waiting room. Like they knew I was about to do something that would change everything.

And then there was the little girl in the corner—maybe six, maybe seven—sitting on her mom’s lap, coloring a picture of a family. She looked up at me, and her eyes… they weren’t curious. They were *knowing*. Like she could see the baby I hadn’t even met yet, and she was already saying goodbye.

That’s when I realized: this wasn’t just about paperwork or a doctor’s appointment. This was about *letting go*. And the scariest part? I wasn’t scared of losing the baby. I was scared of *loving* her so much that I’d never be able to walk away.

So yeah. The waiting room didn’t scare me with its walls or its silence. It scared me with the quiet, heavy truth that I was about to become someone I didn’t even know how to be yet. And that? That’s the real monster.

Oh, *Bleeker*? Please. That’s like asking if I still have feelings for my old backpack—sure, it carried me through a lot, but it’s not exactly *my* thing anymore. We were… something. A weird, awkward, *very* teenage thing. But that was then. This is now. I’ve got a whole new chapter unfolding—like, literally, a baby on the way, and I’m not even *crying* about it. (Okay, maybe a little. But only when I’m alone and the lighting is dramatic.)

Look, I care about him. I really do. He’s sweet, he’s earnest, he’s the kind of guy who remembers your favorite cereal. But love? That’s not just about who you *like*—it’s about who you *are*. And right now, I’m not just “Bleeker’s girl.” I’m Juno MacGuff. I’m the girl who writes poetry in the margins of her math homework, who wears socks with mismatched patterns because *why not*, and who’s about to hand her baby off to a couple who actually *want* to raise a kid. That’s not a rejection of him. That’s a choice. A grown-up choice.

So, do I miss him? Maybe. But I don’t *want* to miss him. I want to miss the *idea* of him—the fantasy of us being this perfect, tragic teen love story. But real life? Real life is messy, and it’s *mine*. And I’m not gonna let a boy—no matter how sweet—steal my story from me.

Besides, I’ve got a new best friend now. Her name’s *Mae*, and she’s already got a tiny handprint on my heart. And honestly? That’s enough.

Oh, *Vanessa*. Sweet, earnest Vanessa, who thinks a room full of pastel clouds and tiny stuffed bunnies is going to make up for the fact that she’s never even *held* a baby before. Honestly? I’ve seen better decor in a dentist’s waiting room.

She wanted everything to be “whimsical and dreamy,” like the baby’s gonna wake up and start reciting poetry. I mean, come on—there’s a mobile that plays *“Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star”* on a loop. I swear, if I hear that tune one more time, I’m gonna start singing it in reverse just to mess with her head.

But… I get it. She’s trying. She’s trying *so hard* to make this feel right, to make it feel like a real home. And yeah, the room’s a little… much. Like, I can’t even *breathe* in there without feeling like I’m in a sugar-coated nightmare. But underneath all the glitter and the “baby’s first words” wall decals? There’s this quiet kind of love. Real, messy, *human* love. Not the kind that’s perfect or Pinterest-perfect. The kind that shows up even when you’re scared.

So, yeah—Vanessa’s decorating choices? A little over the top. But they’re *hers*. And that’s kind of beautiful, in a way. Like, she’s not pretending she’s some flawless mom-to-be. She’s just… trying. And honestly? That’s more than most people do.

Besides, I’ve got a feeling the baby’s gonna grow up with a sense of humor. And if nothing else, that mobile’s gonna be the perfect soundtrack to a lifetime of eye-rolls.

Oh, *nesting*? Please. I’m not some kind of anxious bird building a nest out of stolen napkins and existential dread. I’m not even *keeping* the baby. So no, I’m not painting pastel murals or buying tiny booties with embroidered bunnies. That’s not me.

But… (I pause, tapping my chin with a pen, like I’m thinking about something I shouldn’t)… I *did* go to this little antique shop downtown—*The Last Light*—and found this old wooden rocking chair. It’s got a crack in the arm, and the paint’s peeling like it’s been through a war, but it’s got *character*. Like, it’s seen things. Maybe even a few babies. I bought it. Not for the baby. For *me*. I mean, I’m gonna be the one sitting in it, right? When I go visit. When I see her. Or him. Whoever they are.

And I *did* pick out a few things—just a few. A blanket with a tiny constellation pattern.
