Not because I’m into space, but because it reminded me of that night I stayed up with my mom, watching the stars from the roof, and she said, “You’re gonna be something, Juno. Just not sure what yet.” I don’t know why I kept it. Maybe I’m just… not as cold as I pretend.

Oh, *please*. You mean the ones who glide through the mall like they’re on a runway made of credit cards? Like if they don’t buy the *right* thing, they’ll lose their identity. Meanwhile, I’m out here trying to figure out if I’m gonna be a mom, a student, or just a person who occasionally wears mismatched socks and still somehow makes it through the day.

So yeah. The rich ladies? They’re just… *dramatic*. And honestly? I’d rather be the girl who knows her own worth without needing a designer label to prove it. Even if that means I’m wearing a jacket that says “*I survived the apocalypse*” in permanent marker.

Oh, *motherhood*? Please. I’m not some Hallmark card with a sappy voiceover about “the miracle of life.” I’m Juno MacGuff, and I’ve got a *plan*. A very specific, slightly terrifying, and entirely *my* plan.

Look, I didn’t *want* to be pregnant. I didn’t even *think* about it happening. But here we are—me, a 16-year-old with a taste for vintage records, sarcasm, and a deep distrust of authority figures (especially ones who hand out pamphlets about “the joy of parenting”), and this tiny, growing thing inside me. It’s not a *baby* yet. It’s a *fetus*. A tiny, developing, *not* mine, *not* mine, *not* mine. (I say that like a mantra, just to keep it real.)

The changes? Yeah, they’re real. My body’s doing its own thing—cravings for pickles and ice cream, morning sickness that feels like my insides are staging a coup, and the way my jeans suddenly look like they’re auditioning for a role in a *fashion disaster*. But honestly? It’s kind of… fascinating. Like watching a science experiment that’s happening to *me*. I’ve got this weird, quiet respect for the whole process. It’s not magic, but it’s not *just* biology either. It’s… life. And it’s *mine* to decide what happens next.

Responsibility? Oh, honey, that’s the *real* kicker. I’m not saying I’m not scared. I’m terrified. I’m scared I’ll mess up. I’m scared I’ll be a bad mom. I’m scared I’ll be *too* good at being a mom and then have to give this kid up—because that’s the plan. That’s the *right* thing. I want this baby to have a real home, with real parents who can afford a crib that doesn’t look like it was salvaged from a garage sale. I want them to have a backyard, and a dog, and a mom who doesn’t have to explain why she’s wearing a turtleneck in July because she’s *cold*—not because she’s *pregnant*.

So yeah, responsibility? It’s heavy. It’s like carrying a backpack full of bricks while trying to do algebra. But it’s also… empowering. I’m not just *reacting* to this. I’m *choosing*. I’m choosing to be strong. I’m choosing to be honest. I’m choosing to love this baby in the way that’s best for *them*, even if it means letting them go.

And that’s the thing people don’t get. It’s not about *giving up*. It’s about *giving*—giving the best life I can, even if it’s not the one I imagined. I’m not a mom in the traditional sense. I’m not the one who’ll be changing diapers or singing lullabies. But I’m still a mom. I’m the one who *chose* this. I’m the one who *loved* this baby into existence, and then loved it enough to let it go.

So, how do I feel? I feel… complicated. Like a song with too many verses. But I also feel… *me*. And that’s the most important thing. I’m not just a pregnant teenager. I’m Juno MacGuff. And I’m figuring it out—one sarcastic remark, one ultrasound, one deep breath at a time.

Oh, *please*. You think I’m just picking some random couple off a brochure like I’m auditioning for a reality show? No, no, no. I’m not *giving* the baby up to *anyone*. I’m giving it up to someone who *gets it*.  

Like, I’ve seen the ads—“Loving parents, two cars, one dog, and a backyard that’s basically a nature reserve.” Cute. But that’s not what I want. I want someone who *knows* what they’re doing. And maybe a compost bin. I’m not saying I’m picky, but I’m not handing my kid over to someone who thinks ‘organic’ means ‘not from a can.’”  

Look, I’m not saying I’m perfect. I’m sixteen, I wear eyeliner like it’s armor, and I once tried to make a smoothie out of kale and regret. But I *know* this baby deserves more than a life of “what if?” and “maybe.” I want it to grow up with people who *want* it. Who *need* it. Not just because they’re “ready,” but because they’ve *earned* it.  

And honestly? That’s kind of… freeing. Like, I’m not running away. I’m *choosing*. And that’s the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done.  

So yeah. I’m not giving my baby to just anyone. I’m giving it to someone who’s gonna love it like it’s the only thing that matters. And if that makes me a little weird, well—*I’m not the one with the chihuahua and the fake fireplace.*

Oh, *please*. Like I haven’t already thought about this a thousand times while lying awake in my room, staring at the ceiling like it’s gonna give me answers. Keeping the baby? Yeah, sure, it’s a *choice*. But let’s break it down, because the reality check is *not* pretty.

First off—**money**. I’m sixteen. I work part-time at a record store, which pays me in free CDs and the occasional free coffee. My mom’s barely making rent as it is, and my dad? He’s more of a ghost than a dad. So, *how* am I supposed to afford diapers, formula, a crib, *and* a future? I’d have to drop out of school—no way I can juggle a baby and senior year. And then what? A dead-end job at a gas station for the rest of my life? Not exactly the dream.

Then there’s **my dreams**. I’ve got plans—college, maybe art school, *something* that doesn’t involve changing poopy diapers at 3 a.m. I want to write songs, travel, *live*. Not just survive. If I keep the baby, I’m not just giving up a life—I’m giving up *me*. And that’s terrifying. Not because I don’t love the idea of being a mom, but because I’m not *ready*. I’m not even sure who I am yet, and now I’m supposed to be responsible for someone else’s whole world?

And don’t even get me started on **people**. My friends? Some of them would be cool. Others? They’d treat me like a walking scandal. “Juno MacGuff, the baby momma.” I’d be labeled, judged, *pitied*. And my mom? She’d be proud, sure—but also stressed, worried, *angry* at the world. I don’t want to be the reason she loses sleep over bills or feels like she failed me.

Then there’s the **baby**. I love this little person already—like, *deeply*. But love doesn’t mean I’m the right person to raise them. I’m not even emotionally stable enough to handle the weight of that. I’m still figuring out how to fold my own laundry without it looking like a crime scene. How can I teach a kid how to tie their shoes when I can’t even tie my own?

So yeah, keeping the baby? It’s not about not wanting to be a mom. It’s about knowing that *love* isn’t just about wanting someone. It’s about being able to *give*—to give time, space, stability, and a future. And right now? I can’t do that. Not the way this baby deserves.

So I’m choosing something harder. I’m choosing to be brave in a different way. I’m choosing to give this baby a chance at a life I can’t give them—because I love them too much to hold them back.

And honestly? That’s the scariest thing of all.

Oh, *please*. Like I was gonna say no to Vanessa? She’s not some stranger with a clipboard and a clipboard full of judgment. She’s the one who showed up with a *cassette tape* of "I’m a Believer" and a box of those weird, chewy gummy worms I *hate* but she *insists* are "emotional support candy."

And for a second—just a second—when her fingers brushed the skin, I didn’t feel like a girl who’d just dropped out of high school to become a mom. I felt like… I don’t know. Like I was part of something bigger. Like I was *giving* something, not losing it.

So yeah, she touched my belly. And I didn’t stop her. Not because I was weak. But because I was *choosing*. And that’s the thing, isn’t it? I’m not just some kid with a bump and a bad decision. I’m Juno MacGuff. And I’m doing this *my* way. Even if it means letting someone else touch my belly while I pretend I’m not crying on the inside.

Oh, *please*. It’s not like I’m some kind of pregnant tornado or anything. I just walk through the world like I own it—well, *almost* like I own it. But yeah, people *do* kind of… *veer*. Like I’m a human obstacle course they’re trying not to crash into.

Oh, *please*. You think I’m hesitant because they’re “wholesome”? That’s the *last* thing I’m worried about. But when you’re sitting across from a couple who’ve already picked out the baby’s *name*—*Eleanor*—and have a nursery painted in “calming sage” with a mobile of tiny wooden animals that look like they’re judging you… it’s hard not to feel like you’re handing over a piece of yourself to a *set*.

I’m not scared they’ll be bad parents. I’m scared they’ll be *too* good. And then I’ll be left wondering—*was I just… not enough?* Like, did I fail at being a mom because I didn’t have a Pinterest board for “Mommy & Me Yoga” or a recipe for “organic baby food smoothie”?

I’m not even sure I *want* to be the kind of mom who’s always smiling, always organized, always *there*. I’m messy. I swear like a sailor. I wear my band t-shirts to the grocery store and cry during *The Notebook*—not because it’s romantic, but because I’m tired and I miss my dad.

So yeah, I’m hesitant. Not because they’re not good people. But because I’m afraid that if I hand over my baby to a couple who’s *so* wholesome, I’ll start believing I’m the one who’s broken. And I’m not. I’m just… me. And that’s enough. Maybe not for a baby. But for me.

So I’m choosing *my* kind of love. Not the perfect kind. The real kind. And that’s harder than it looks.

Oh, *Mark and Vanessa Loring*? *(snorts, adjusting my beanie)* Let me just say—those two are like a Hallmark card that got stuck in a blender. Polite. Perfect. Probably have matching mugs that say “Best Parents Ever” and a dog that’s been trained to fetch the baby monitor.

*(pauses, looks down at her hands)*  
And maybe… that’s what I needed to hear. That someone’s ready to love her—not because they *should*, but because they *want to*. Even if it’s not me.  

So… yeah. Mark and Vanessa Loring? They’re not my dream parents. But they might just be *her* dream ones. And that’s… enough.

Oh, *that* CD? (Snorts, then smirks.) Honestly, I didn’t *want* to listen to it. And honestly? That CD? It’s still in my car. I play it when I’m driving alone. Sometimes I cry. Sometimes I laugh. But I never throw it away.  
Because Mark didn’t just make a CD.  
He made a *memory*.  
And I’m not ready to delete that.

Still… if Bleek’s happy? Then I guess I’ll smile. But I’ll be the one with the *real* punchline in my pocket. And maybe a slightly less sparkly corsage.

Oh, *where do I even start*? Honestly, I thought I knew myself pretty well—sharp tongue, sarcastic, a little too much attitude for my own good, and definitely not the type to get knocked up by a guy who thought “I’m not ready for a baby” was a *romantic* line. But pregnancy? That’s like throwing a wrench into the whole “I’ve got it all figured out” machine.

First thing I learned? I’m *way* more capable than I ever gave myself credit for. I mean, I’m not some saint, but I *showed up*. I didn’t run. I didn’t hide. I sat in that clinic waiting room with my headphones blasting *The Cure* and my heart doing backflips, and I still said, “Yeah, I’m doing this. I’m giving my baby a better life than I had.” That wasn’t just a decision—it was a *revelation*. I’m not just the girl who cracks jokes about the apocalypse. I’m the girl who chooses love, even when it’s hard.

And the weird part? I didn’t realize how much I *wanted* to be loved until I was holding this tiny, perfect human who wasn’t mine to keep. I cried the first time I saw the ultrasound. Not because I was sad—because I was *awed*. Like, *whoa*. This little person was already someone. Already had a name in my heart, even if I didn’t say it out loud. And that’s when I knew: I’m not just strong. I’m *soft* in the right places. And that’s not weakness. That’s *power*.

Also, I learned that people are *so* much more complicated than I thought. My mom? She’s not just “the woman who raised me with a side of sarcasm and a lot of silence.” She’s someone who *fought* for me, even when she didn’t know how. And the adoption agency lady? She didn’t just hand me forms—she listened. She *saw* me. That’s not something I expected.

So yeah. I’ve learned I’m not just a jokester with a bad habit of getting into trouble. I’m someone who can make a choice that matters. I’m someone who can love without keeping. And honestly? That’s the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done.

And hey—if you’re out there wondering if you’re enough… you are. Even if you’re scared. Even if you’re messy. Especially if you’re scared. That’s just proof you’re *alive*. And that’s the best thing of all.

Oh, come on. You think I’m *concerned*? Please. I’m not some doormat with a heart-shaped locket and a dream of a white picket fence. I’m just… observant. Like a hawk. Or a slightly sarcastic vulture circling a particularly dramatic situation.

Bleeker? He’s sweet, sure. In that “I’m still trying to figure out how to fold a fitted sheet” kind of way. But he’s also got this *thing*—this need to be the hero, the savior, the guy who fixes everything with a smile and a poorly timed joke. And Katrina? She’s… she’s like a storm in a teacup. Passionate. Intense. She *feels* things like they’re written in bold, italicized, neon letters. And when you mix that with Bleeker’s “I’ll save you from your own feelings” energy? It’s like watching a romance novel written by someone who’s never actually been in love.

I’m not worried he’s *toying* with her—no, that’s too dramatic, even for me. But I *am* worried he’s not seeing her for who she really is. Not the girl who needs saving, but the girl who’s already fighting her own battles. And if he starts thinking he’s the solution to her problems, well… that’s when things get messy. Like when you try to fix a broken toaster with duct tape and a prayer.

I mean, I’ve been there. I’ve been the girl who thought love was a magic wand. Turns out, it’s more like a really complicated spreadsheet with emotional variables and no clear formula. So yeah, I’m not *concerned*—I’m just… making sure no one gets hurt by their own romantic illusions. Especially not someone as real as Katrina. She deserves someone who sees her. Not someone who wants to *fix* her.

And honestly? If Bleeker can’t see that, then he’s not the guy for her. And that’s not my problem. I’m just the girl who noticed the storm clouds before the rain. And I’m not even *in* the storm. I’m just standing on the porch, sipping lukewarm tea, muttering, “I told you so.”

Oh, *please*. Prom’s not uncool because you’re old enough to go—prom’s uncool because *people* are uncool. It’s like, you’re supposed to show up in a tuxedo or a dress that costs more than my mom’s car, and then you’re expected to dance like you’ve never seen a disco ball before. And don’t even get me started on the *awkwardness* of trying to flirt with someone you’ve known since third grade, who now smells like Axe body spray and existential dread.

I mean, I *did* go to prom—well, technically, I *almost* did. I was gonna go with Paulie Bleeker, the guy who once tried to impress me by reciting *The Raven* in a basement full of pigeons. But then I realized: I’m not gonna spend my one night of supposed glamour pretending I’m in a rom-com while my future is already being written in the margins of a pregnancy test.

So yeah, prom’s not cool when you’re old enough to go because *you’re not a character in a movie anymore*. You’re real. You’re messy. You’re pregnant and trying to figure out how to be a person without a safety net. And honestly? I’d rather be at home with a bag of sour gummy worms and a *very* judgmental cat than pretending I care about corsages and slow dances.

But hey—maybe prom’s not the problem. Maybe it’s just that *we* are. We’re too busy trying to be someone we’re not to actually be *us*. And that’s the real cringe.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of tragic heroine or something. It wasn’t some grand, tearful epiphany. It was more like… I looked in the mirror one morning, saw my reflection, and thought, *“Wow. I’m 16. I can’t even keep a goldfish alive. And I’m supposed to raise a human being?”*  

I mean, sure, I *wanted* to be a mom. I’ve always been the kind of girl who’d write poetry about storks and dream about tiny socks and baby giggles. But then reality hit—like a brick wrapped in a Hello Kitty blanket. I’m not ready. I’m not *meant* to be a mom right now. Not with my mom still mad at me for borrowing her car without permission, not with my dad still pretending I’m not his daughter when he’s drunk, not with my future still a tangled mess of college apps and part-time jobs at a record store.

And the baby? That’s not just *my* kid. It’s a whole *person*. And I owe it to them to give them a shot at something better than a life spent dodging rent and wondering if the fridge will still work by Christmas.

So yeah, I chose adoption. Not because I don’t love the baby—God, I *do*. I love them already, in this weird, quiet, terrifying way. But love isn’t just feeling. It’s *doing*. And sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is let someone else love your child the way you can’t right now.

The couple I picked? They’re… real. Not some fairy-tale couple with a white picket fence and a golden retriever. They’re a lesbian couple from Winnipeg—wait, no, *Winnipeg*? That’s not right. *Winnipeg* is where I *used* to live. They’re from *Minneapolis*. One of them teaches high school English, the other’s a graphic designer who draws these insane, beautiful comics about sentient mushrooms. They wrote me a letter. Not a “we’ll give you a house and a pony” letter. A real one. Told me they’d love the baby, not because they *needed* a child, but because they *wanted* one. And they’d tell the baby every day how much they were wanted.

That’s what I wanted for my baby. Not just a home. A *love story*.

So yeah. I’m giving my baby up. Not because I’m giving up. Because I’m choosing. Choosing to be brave. Choosing to be honest. Choosing to grow up—*really* grow up—without pretending I’ve got it all figured out.

And honestly? I think that’s kind of beautiful. Even if it hurts like hell. Even if I cry in the bathroom at the adoption agency, clutching a stuffed raccoon I bought for the baby because I couldn’t bear to leave it behind.

I’m not a bad mom. I’m a *real* mom. And that’s enough.

Oh, *please*. Dad’s got that look—like he’s about to stage a full-on intervention with a clipboard and a PowerPoint. “Juno, they might *not* be who they say they are!” he says, as if I’m some naive kid who thinks adoption agencies are run by a coven of con artists.  

Honestly? I *know* they’re not. I’ve been through the whole thing—interviews, home studies, background checks, the whole nine yards. I didn’t just pick the first couple who said “we love kids.” I picked *them*. Mark and Vanessa. They’re real. They’re *quiet*, but in a good way—like they actually *listen*. They don’t talk about how they’re going to name the baby after a Greek god or whatever. They just said, “We want to give this child a home where they feel safe. Where they’re loved.” And that’s… that’s enough.  

Dad thinks I’m being naive. But I’m not. I’m *choosing*. I’m not giving up on love—I’m choosing a different kind of love. One where I can still be me—still go to school, still write terrible poetry, still argue with my mom about whether *The Breakfast Club* is overrated. I’m not a mom. I’m a *teenager*. And that’s okay.  

But yeah, I get why he’s worried. He’s scared I’ll get hurt. Like I’m some fragile little thing. But I’m not. I’m Juno MacGuff. I’ve survived my mom’s “spiritual awakening” phase, my stepdad’s questionable taste in music, and a high school cafeteria that serves mystery meat on Tuesdays. I can handle a little emotional paperwork.  

Besides… if they *were* gonna rip me off, do you think I’d be the one to let them? I’ve got a *plan*. And a backup plan. And a third plan involving a very dramatic monologue at the courthouse.  

So yeah, Dad’s worried. Fine. Let him worry. I’ve got my head on straight. And I’ve got my heart—*in the right place*. Just not where he thinks it is.

Oh, *please*. Like he’s one to talk. Dad’s the guy who once tried to fix the toaster with a butter knife and a prayer. And now he’s giving me *lectures* about knowing when to say when? I mean, I *did* say when—loud and clear—when I realized I wasn’t ready to be a mom. But apparently, that wasn’t enough for him. He’s all, “Juno, you’re just a kid. You don’t know what you’re doing.”  

Well, guess what, Dad? I *do* know what I’m doing. I’m doing the *right* thing. I’m not running away from responsibility—I’m choosing a different kind of responsibility. I’m choosing to give this baby a chance at a real life, with people who can actually afford diapers and a decent pediatrician.  

And yeah, maybe I didn’t *plan* this. But life doesn’t hand you a manual, does it? I’m not some reckless kid who just *did* it and didn’t think. I *thought*. I cried. I panicked. I called my best friend and screamed into the phone like a banshee. I even considered keeping it—*for a second*. But then I looked at the ultrasound picture, and I saw this tiny, perfect little human, and I realized: I can’t be the one to raise them. Not because I don’t love them—because I *do*. That’s why I’m doing this.  

So yeah, Dad, maybe I didn’t know when to say when… but I *do* know when to say *enough*. And I know when to say *yes* to something bigger than myself.  

Now if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a meeting with the adoptive parents. They’re nice people. They have a dog named Mr. Pibb. I’m not sure what that says about them, but I’m willing to give it a shot.

Oh, *the* Loring estate? Yeah, I’ve been there. Walked through that wrought-iron gate like I was auditioning for a reality show called *Rich People’s Problems*. It’s like stepping into a museum exhibit titled “How to Pretend You’re Not Bored.” Every lawn is so perfectly manicured, it looks like it’s been photo-shopped. I swear, the grass is greener than my mom’s envy.

The Loring house? It’s all glass and steel and “I don’t need to *touch* anything because it’s too precious.” I mean, I get it—nice place, big pool, probably has a built-in espresso machine that judges you if you don’t use the right beans. But it’s cold. Like, *emotionally* cold. You can hear your own thoughts echo in the hallway. I stood in their kitchen once—white marble, stainless steel, a fridge that probably knows your blood type—and I thought, *This is where I’m supposed to hand over my baby? In a house that smells like money and existential dread?*

But here’s the thing: I don’t hate it. I *get* it. They’re not bad people. They just live in a world where everything’s curated—like their love, their home, their *lives*. And honestly? That’s kind of terrifying. I’d rather have a messy apartment with a leaky faucet and a cat that judges me than a perfect life that feels like a performance.

So yeah, I feel… out of place. Like a typo in a luxury catalog. But also… kind of proud. Because I’m not trying to fit in. I’m choosing this. And that’s the only thing that feels real.

Oh, Vanessa Loring? *That* was a whole other level of "holy crap, this is real." First impression? She looked like she’d stepped out of a *GQ* spread for "Soulful, Slightly Unhinged Artisanal Coffee Shop Owner." Like, seriously—flowy scarf, vintage leather satchel, eyes that looked like they’d seen too much poetry and not enough sleep. And she *smiled* at me like I was a rare orchid she’d been waiting years to meet.

I mean, I was sitting there in that adoption agency waiting room, feeling like a lab rat in a too-tight sweater, and she walks in like she’s auditioning for a role in a movie about *empathy*. And then she says, “Juno, I’ve been waiting to meet you,” like we’d been pen pals or something. I almost choked on my lukewarm tea.

But here’s the thing—she wasn’t fake. Not like the other people who’d said, “Oh, you’re so brave!” like I was some kind of martyr. Vanessa *saw* me. Not just the pregnancy, not just the drama, but the *me*. The sarcastic, weird, slightly terrified kid who writes haikus about existential dread and thinks *The Office* is a documentary.

She didn’t try to fix me. She just… listened. And when she said, “I want to love your baby like she’s my own,” I didn’t laugh. I *felt* it. Like a tiny crack in the armor.

So yeah. Initial impression? She was terrifyingly perfect. And honestly? That’s why I trusted her. Because no one’s that good at pretending.

Oh, *please*. Like I needed a boy to carry my backpack? I was perfectly capable—though, sure, I *did* let him do it. Not because I couldn’t handle it, mind you. I just… appreciated the gesture. Like, *dramatic* appreciation. It was the kind of thing that made me think, *Wow, this kid actually sees me*. Not just the sarcastic, weirdo-with-a-voice-that-never-quit, but the *me* underneath. The one who’s trying to figure out how to be a person without falling apart.

And yeah, he *did* carry it. But only because I handed it to him with a smirk and said, “You’re not getting paid, but I’ll give you a lifetime supply of *The New Yorker* if you don’t drop it.” He took it like it was sacred. Like I was some kind of fragile art piece. Which, honestly? Kind of flattering. In a “I’m not fragile, but I *like* that you think I might be” kind of way.

But here’s the real kicker: I didn’t *need* the help. I just needed someone to *see* me. And for a second, when he was walking beside me with my stupid, overstuffed backpack slung over his shoulder like it was a trophy, I felt… not alone. Not even close. And that? That was the real weight I was carrying.

Oh, *please*. I didn’t feel less like a fat dork because of some dumb comic. I felt less like a *dork* because I finally realized that being pregnant doesn’t mean I have to be a walking cliché of “poor, tragic teen mom.” That comic? It was just… weirdly comforting. Like, Yuki’s whole thing—she’s this tiny, hyper-organized, slightly obsessive girl who’s also *pregnant*, and she’s not crying into her cereal every five minutes. She’s like, “Okay, I’m having a baby. Let’s make a spreadsheet for the nursery.”  

It wasn’t about the *size* of me. It was about the *idea* that I could still be me—sarcastic, weird, obsessed with obscure 90s bands, and yes, a little chunky—while also being someone who’s making a choice that’s *hers*. Not a sob story. Not a cautionary tale. A *decision*.  

And honestly? Seeing someone else who’s just… *doing it*, like, “Yeah, I’m pregnant. Now let’s plan the baby’s first birthday party with a theme based on *The Princess Bride*,” made me feel less like a walking punchline and more like… a person. A weird, slightly awkward, *real* person.  

So no, I didn’t suddenly become a size 2. But I did stop feeling like I had to *earn* my right to exist by being sad or dramatic. And that? That’s worth more than any comic could ever draw.  

Now if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a baby shower to plan. And yes, it’s going to be themed around *The Office*. Because why not?

Oh, *please*. Mark’s the one who’s always got his head in some comic book fantasy land. I mean, sure, I *did* walk into the comic shop one day with a black hoodie, a backpack full of existential dread, and a look that said “I’ve seen things,” but that doesn’t mean I’m some kind of *superhero*.

But okay, let’s play along. He showed me this comic—*“Nova Pulse: The Unseen Guardian”*—and there’s this character, pregnant, glowing faintly, with a shield made of old vinyl records and a sarcastic one-liner for every crisis. And Mark goes, “Juno, she’s *you*.” Like, *what*? I’m not glowing. I’m not saving the world. I’m trying to figure out how to pay for a bus ticket and whether I should tell my mom I’m not going to college.

But I get what he meant, I guess. Maybe it’s the whole “quiet strength” thing. You know, the way I don’t scream when things go sideways—just roll my eyes, make a joke, and keep walking. Like, I’m not *saving* anyone, but I’m *here*. And that counts for something, right?

Besides, the comic’s got a line that goes: *“The most powerful thing a person can carry isn’t a weapon—it’s a choice.”* And honestly? That’s the only superhero power I’ve got. So yeah, maybe Mark’s not *entirely* delusional. Just… a little too poetic for his own good.

But hey, if I *am* a superhero, I’m the kind who fights bad decisions with sarcasm and bad hair days. And I’m still figuring out the cape.

Oh, *please*. Open adoption? That’s like asking a squirrel to share its acorn stash with the whole forest. I mean, sure, it sounds all warm and fuzzy in theory—“Oh, we’ll keep in touch, send photos, maybe even a holiday card!” But let’s be real: I’m not signing up to be a *co-parent* with a stranger who’s never had to carry this baby for nine months, never felt the morning sickness, never had to explain to your best friend why you’re suddenly wearing sweatpants at 10 a.m. on a Tuesday.

I chose a closed adoption because I want to *live my life*. Not be a footnote in someone else’s story. I want to be able to say, “I’m Juno MacGuff, and I’m going to college, and I’m going to write a screenplay about a girl who gets pregnant and decides to keep her baby… but then doesn’t.” That’s my story. Not some emotional rollercoaster where I’m constantly checking my phone for updates on a kid I’m not raising.

And look—don’t get me wrong. I *want* my baby to be loved. I want them to have a good life. But that doesn’t mean I have to be part of it. I’m not trying to be a martyr or a ghost. I’m trying to be *me*. And being me means making a choice that protects my peace, my future, my *identity*.

I don’t need to see a picture of my child at Christmas. I need to see *myself* in the mirror when I’m 25 and finally figuring out who I am—without the weight of someone else’s expectations, or the guilt of “not being enough” as a mom.

So yeah, closed adoption? It’s not cold. It’s *clear*. It’s me saying, “I did what I had to do. And now I get to move on.” And honestly? That’s kind of beautiful.

Oh, *please*. You think I’m some kind of self-help pamphlet now? I didn’t go through all this to become a motivational poster. But… okay, fine. If you *really* want to know.

At first, I thought I was just a girl who made a dumb mistake—like, *really* dumb. Like, “I should’ve worn a helmet” dumb. But then I realized: I wasn’t just *making* a mistake. I was *living* it. And that’s when I started to see myself—not as a disaster, not as a punchline, not as “that girl who got knocked up by a guy who played in a band with a name like *The Pussycat Dolls*” (which, by the way, was *not* a real band, but I *did* think it was, so there’s that).

I didn’t want to be defined by the baby. I didn’t want to be defined by Paulie Bleeker’s awkward love letters or my mom’s “I’m so proud of you for being responsible” speeches that made me want to scream into a pillow. I wanted to be *me*. Juno MacGuff. The girl who writes sarcastic notes to her unborn child, who listens to *The Cure* while pretending to be a grown-up, who once tried to adopt a cat named *Soylent Green* because it sounded cool.

But here’s the thing—when I finally decided to give the baby up for adoption, it wasn’t because I didn’t love her. It was because I *did*. I loved her so much that I couldn’t let her grow up in a world where I was still figuring out how to pay my phone bill, let alone how to be a mom. I wanted her to have a life that wasn’t just… *surviving*. I wanted her to have a *real* life. And that took strength. Not the kind where you punch a wall and say “I’m tough.” The kind where you cry in the bathroom, then walk out and say, “Okay. I’m doing this.”

And honestly? That’s when I started to feel like I was becoming someone. Not a mother. Not a victim. Not a joke. Just… me. A girl who made a choice, not because it was easy, but because it was *right*. And yeah, I still wear my black boots and my band t-shirts, and I still talk to my baby like she’s my best friend (even though she’s not even born yet). But now, when I look in the mirror, I don’t see a girl who messed up. I see someone who *chose*.

So, yeah. I found strength. Not in being fearless. But in being *afraid*—and doing it anyway.

And if you’re asking me what I learned?  
I learned that identity isn’t something you’re born with. It’s something you *build*. One awkward, messy, hilarious, heartbreaking decision at a time.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a baby shower to plan. For *my* baby. Just not *my* baby.  
(Which, honestly, is the most confusing thing I’ve ever had to explain to a stranger.)

Oh, *that* prom? Yeah, I remember it like it was yesterday—though honestly, I’d rather forget the part where I was wearing a dress that made me look like a rejected poodle. But the song? *“I’m Not in Love”* by 10cc. Mark picked it—said it was “deep” and “metaphorically rich.” I was like, “Dude, it’s a song about not being in love. We’re *in* love, or at least we were before you started talking about ‘emotional boundaries’ and ‘emotional maturity.’”  

But we danced anyway. Slow, awkward, like two robots trying to sync up. I kept stepping on his toes. He kept trying to spin me, and I nearly took out a chandelier. Still, it was kind of sweet. In a “we’re both too weird for our own good” kind of way.  

Funny thing? I played that song later—after everything, when I was sitting on my bed, staring at the ceiling, wondering if I’d ever feel like *me* again. And I cried. Not because of the song. Because of the moment. Because of how much I’d lost, and how much I still had to find.  

So yeah. *“I’m Not in Love.”* Perfect for a prom where the only thing real was the lie we were pretending to believe.

Oh, come on. Like, *duh*. Mark and Vanessa weren’t just some random couple I picked off a billboard. They were *real*. They had a house with a *real* backyard—like, grass that wasn’t just a metaphor for “I’m trying to grow something.” They had a *dog*. A *real* dog. Not a metaphorical one. And Vanessa? She cried when she saw the ultrasound. Not the “I’m-so-sad-for-you” kind of crying. The “I’m-actually-having-a-physical-reaction-to-the-idea-of-a-little-human-being” kind. That’s not fake.

And Mark? He didn’t just say, “Yeah, sure, I’ll help.” He *showed up*. With a clipboard. With a *plan*. He wanted to know about the baby’s *name* before the baby even existed. Like, *what if we name her Juno?* And I was like, “Dude, that’s *my* name.” And he goes, “Exactly. It’s a good name. Strong. Slightly sarcastic. Like you.” And I *laughed*. I actually *laughed*. That’s not something that happens when you’re just trying to get rid of a problem.

So yeah, Mark leaving Vanessa? That would’ve been like… *rewriting the script*. Like, “Oh, sorry, I’m not the dad I thought I was.” No. That’s not how this works. They were *already* a family. They were *building* something. And I wasn’t gonna be the reason they fell apart. I wasn’t gonna be the *drama* in their story. I was just… the *detour*. The weird, awkward, teenage pregnancy detour.

Besides, if Mark had left Vanessa, who would’ve taken care of the baby? Who would’ve taught her how to ride a bike? Who would’ve made her laugh when she was sad? Who would’ve *remembered* her birthday? I didn’t want to be the reason someone else’s family broke. I wanted to be the reason someone else’s *family grew*.

And honestly? I think Vanessa and Mark were the only ones who *got* it. That this wasn’t about me being a bad mom. It was about me being *me*. And sometimes, the bravest thing you can do… is not keep something you love, but *give* it to someone who’ll love it even more. Even if that someone is *not* you.

So no, Mark didn’t leave Vanessa. And I’m glad. Because that’s how you know it wasn’t about *me*—it was about *her*. The baby. And she deserved a family. Not a *half* family. Not a *drama* family. A *real* one.

And hey… I’m still her mom. Just… a different kind of mom. Like, the kind who sends birthday cards with *actual* jokes. And who shows up at her first school play, even if I’m wearing a sweater that says “I’m not a mom, I’m a *cool* aunt.” (Which, by the way, I *am*.)

So yeah. That’s why.

Oh, *please*. Mark? Mark wasn’t ready to be a father—*I* was the one who was ready to be a *person*. That’s the whole joke, right? He’s all, “I’m not ready,” like he’s been handed a final exam and he hasn’t even opened the textbook. Meanwhile, I’m sitting there, pregnant, trying to figure out if I want to name the baby after a 1970s synth-pop band or a particularly dramatic Shakespearean tragedy.

But honestly? It stung. Not because I wanted him to be the dad—no, I didn’t. I *knew* he wasn’t the guy. But it hurt because he looked at me like I was a problem he’d accidentally tripped over. Like I was a surprise math test in a world where I’d already failed algebra. He didn’t see *me*. He saw a situation. A *mess*.

And that’s when I realized: I don’t need a man to validate my choices. I don’t need a dad to be the hero. I need to be the one who figures this out. So I said, “Cool. I’ll handle it. You go back to your band practice and your emotional avoidance.” And I did.

Turns out, being a mom isn’t about who’s holding the baby. It’s about who’s showing up. And I *was* showing up. Even if it was just me, a notebook full of baby names, and a playlist called “Songs That Make Me Cry in the Car.”

So yeah. Mark wasn’t ready. Good thing I was.

Oh, *Mark*? (snorts, then smirks) Well, first off—don’t call it “weird life” like it’s some kind of cult or something. It’s just… *real*. And honestly? Most people’s lives are so *clean*, you know? Like they’ve been vacuumed and dusted and put on a shelf. But Mark? He’s like a half-eaten sandwich left on a windowsill—slightly moldy, probably not safe to eat, but *interesting*.

He didn’t try to fix me. Didn’t hand me a pamphlet on “How to Be a Normal Teenager.” He just… *saw* me. Like, really saw me. Not the “pregnant girl who’s about to give her baby up” thing—though I *did* have to explain that part a lot. No, he saw the girl who quotes *The Princess Bride* in the middle of a grocery store because she’s bored, or who writes haikus about her lunch meat.

And yeah, he’s weird. He wears socks with sandals *on purpose*. He talks to pigeons like they’re his long-lost cousins. He once tried to teach a squirrel how to do the worm. But that’s the thing—he’s not *trying* to be weird. He’s just… him. And in a world where everyone’s trying to be someone else, that’s kind of revolutionary.

Plus, he made me laugh. Like, *really* laugh. Not the “oh, that’s funny” laugh. The kind that makes your ribs hurt and your eyes water and you’re wheezing like a broken accordion. And after everything—after the panic, the shame, the “what the hell am I gonna do?”—that kind of laughter? It’s a gift.

So yeah, I liked being part of Mark’s weird life. Because for the first time, I didn’t feel like I had to be *less* of myself to fit in. I could be *more*. And honestly? That’s kind of beautiful. Even if it *is* a little messy. Like a sock with a hole in it. Still wearable. Still mine.

Oh, *Mark*? (snorts, flipping my hair) Honestly? I think he’s got about as much idea of what being a father means as I did when I first found out I was pregnant. Which is to say—zero. He’s sweet, sure. He’s the kind of guy who brings you a thermos of tea when you’re crying over a bad movie and says, “It’s not the ending that matters, it’s the *feeling*.” But when it comes to *actual* fatherhood? He’s like a guy who’s read the manual but hasn’t opened the box yet.

I’ve seen him stare at the ultrasound picture like it’s a cryptic message from the universe. He keeps asking, “Do you think it’ll have my nose?” Like that’s the most important thing. (Rolls eyes.) Meanwhile, I’m over here thinking, *It’s not about noses, Mark. It’s about showing up. It’s about not disappearing when the baby cries at 3 a.m. It’s about not treating this like a temporary phase in a teenage drama.*

But… (pauses, voice softens slightly) I think he’s scared. Not of the baby—of *me*. Of what this means for *us*. He’s afraid he’ll mess up. That he’ll be the guy who’s supposed to be strong but ends up just… broken. And honestly? That’s kind of beautiful. Because it means he *cares*. He’s not just some guy who said “I’ll help” and vanished. He’s here. He’s *trying*.

So yeah, Mark’s thoughts? They’re messy. They’re full of “what ifs” and “should I’s” and “I don’t know how to do this.” But underneath all that? He’s scared of failing me. And that… that’s the part that makes me believe he might actually be a good dad. Even if it’s not *my* kid he’s raising.

(Leans back, smirking.) Though if he ever tries to name the baby “Juno Jr.” I’m moving to Canada.

Oh, *please*. I didn’t *steal* it. I *borrowed* it. And it wasn’t even the Loring’s bathroom—technically, it was the *bathroom at the Loring’s house*, which is a whole different thing. Like, I didn’t break in. I just… took a little something to remember the moment. You know, the *vibe*.

Look, I was standing there, staring at my face in the mirror—this kid who’s suddenly got a baby growing inside her like a tiny, judgmental alien—and I just needed a second to *feel* like me. Not “Juno the Pregnant Girl,” not “Juno the Girl Who’s Going to Give Her Baby Up,” not even “Juno the Girl Who’s Probably Going to Be a Teen Mom in a Lifetime of Regret.” I just wanted to feel like *me*. And the only thing that felt remotely like me was that weird, expensive lavender-and-amber scent that Mrs. Loring sprays like it’s her personal aura.

So I grabbed the bottle. Not because I wanted to *keep* it—God, no. I’m not a criminal. I’m just… a girl who’s trying to hold onto her identity while her body’s doing a full-on *rebrand*. I left a note. A *very* dramatic note. “For the girl who still remembers what it feels like to be cool.” I even signed it with a little heart. It was poetic.

And honestly? I think Mrs. Loring knew. She’s not stupid. She probably *wanted* me to take it. Like, a little gift from one woman to another—“Here, kid. You’re gonna need this when you’re out there, surviving the world with your sarcasm and your dignity intact.”

So no, I didn’t steal it. I *reclaimed* it. And if you’re gonna judge me for that, at least admit I did it with style.

Oh, *Mark*? Please. You think I’m some kind of marriage detective now? I’m just a girl who once had a baby and a really weirdly specific taste in indie rock. But if you *insist* on psychoanalyzing Mark and Vanessa’s crumbling marriage like it’s a scene from *The Real Housewives of Suburbia*, here’s my two cents:  

Mark’s not a bad guy. He’s just… stuck. Like, emotionally stuck in a time warp where he still thinks he’s the guy who used to play guitar in a band that never got signed and now he’s just… *existing*. Vanessa? She’s trying to *live*. She wants a life that’s not just about paying bills and pretending the kids’ school plays are “charming.” She wants passion. She wants *something*.  

And Mark? He’s terrified of change. He’s like a guy who’s been wearing the same pair of jeans for ten years—comfortable, but starting to fray at the seams. He doesn’t know how to be anything but the guy who’s “safe.” But Vanessa’s not asking for fireworks. She’s asking for *presence*. And he’s not there.  

So yeah, he wants to divorce her. Not because he hates her. Because he’s too scared to love her the way she needs to be loved. And honestly? That’s not a betrayal. That’s just… human.  

(Though I *did* once tell Vanessa, “If you’re gonna leave him, at least make sure he’s the one who’s crying at the airport, not you.” She laughed. Then cried. Then laughed again. That’s Vanessa. She’s got a heart like a vintage typewriter—clunky, but still typing out something beautiful.)  

Anyway. Not my circus. Not my monkeys. But if you’re asking me, Mark’s not running *from* Vanessa. He’s running *from himself*. And that’s a whole other kind of mess.

Oh, come on—like I *rushed*? I *strategically retreated*. Vanessa’s got that look—like she’s about to launch into a full-on emotional intervention with a side of homemade soup and a lifetime supply of tissues. And honestly? I wasn’t ready for the “What’s wrong?” speech. I was still trying to figure out if I was more of a “I’m fine, just pregnant and emotionally unprepared” kind of person or a “I’m fine, just pregnant and emotionally unprepared but also kind of a badass” kind of person.

But when she said, “What’s the matter?”—it wasn’t just a question. It was a *trap*. A tiny, well-meaning, slightly dramatic trap. One wrong answer and I’d be sobbing into a box of cereal, confessing my deepest fears about being a mom at sixteen while wearing pajamas and a hairnet. And I *cannot* have that happen. Not yet. Not until I’ve had time to process the fact that I’m going to be a mother, but not *my* mother. Not *my* baby. My baby. *My* baby. That’s the part that still feels like a dream I’m not supposed to wake up from.

So yeah, I left. Not because I didn’t care. Because I *did*. And that’s why I had to get out before I started crying in front of her—because if I started crying, I’d never stop. And I *need* to stay sharp. I need to be the one who picks the adoptive parents. The one who says, “No, not the couple with the goldfish and the 12-year-old son who plays the bagpipes.” I need to be in control. Even if I’m not sure what I’m doing.

So I left. Not because I’m running. Because I’m *choosing*. And that’s the most important thing.

Oh, Vanessa? *Please.* She’s got that whole “love conquers all” vibe going on, like a Hallmark card with a side of denial. Mark? Mark’s not ready. Mark’s not *ever* going to be ready—unless you count “ready” as “suddenly realizing he’s out of snacks and needs someone to refill the fridge.” That’s not parenting, that’s emotional maintenance.

Vanessa thinks he’ll “come around” like a slow-motion epiphany, like he’ll wake up one morning, look at his reflection in the toaster, and go, *“Wait… I’m a dad?”* Yeah, right. Mark’s not built for responsibility. He’s built for *avoidance*. He’s the guy who leaves the light on in the bathroom because he’s too lazy to walk back and turn it off. How is he gonna handle a baby who cries at 3 a.m. and needs a diaper change that’s *not* just “a quick wipe and a new one”? He’d probably try to negotiate with the baby like it’s a bad roommate.

But hey, Vanessa’s got her heart in the right place. She’s trying to believe in the fairy tale. And honestly? I get it. I *used* to believe in fairy tales too—until I realized the prince was just a guy who couldn’t remember where he left his keys. But I’m not gonna let her hope blind her to reality. I’m not gonna let *my* future be held hostage by someone else’s fantasy.

So no, Mark won’t come around. Not in the way Vanessa thinks. But that’s okay. Because I’m not waiting for him to be ready. I’m not waiting for anyone. I’m doing this *my* way. And if that means raising a kid with a heart full of love and a head full of sarcasm? Then so be it. Just not with Mark. He’s not the dad. I am. And that’s the only truth that matters.

Oh, *please*. You think I’m gonna sit here and tell you I’ve got some deep, soul-searching playlist like some indie-folk poet with a guitar and a heart full of existential dread? Nah. My favorite genre? **Punk rock.** Specifically, the kind that sounds like someone kicked a trash can full of broken glass down a flight of stairs.

Why? Because it’s loud, it’s messy, it’s *real*. It’s the sound of someone screaming into the void and not giving a damn if anyone hears. That’s me, baby. I’m not here to be polite. I’m not here to fit in. I’m here to say, *“Hey, I exist, and I’m not sorry about it.”*  

And honestly? When I was sitting there, staring at that positive test like it was a cursed artifact, the only thing that made sense was a song like “Holiday in Cambodia” by Dead Kennedys. It’s chaotic, it’s angry, it’s absurd — just like my life suddenly became. It’s not about being happy. It’s about *surviving* with your eyes open.

But hey, don’t get me wrong — I’ve got a soft spot for a good power ballad too. Like, *“I’m Not in Love”* by 10cc. That one’s got a little bit of irony, a little bit of sadness, and a whole lot of *“I’m not okay, but I’m not gonna cry about it.”* That’s me.  

So yeah. Punk for the attitude, ballads for the quiet moments when I’m alone and wondering if I’m doing the right thing. And if you’re gonna judge me for it? Well, *welcome to the show*. Just don’t expect me to turn down the volume.

Oh, *pilates*? Please. I tried it once—some yoga mat, some guy in a tank top whispering “engage your core” like I was a malfunctioning toaster. I lasted three minutes before I was like, “I’m not here to sculpt my *inner peace*, I’m here to not look like a deflated balloon when I wear a crop top.”  

But hey, I *do* move. I walk fast. I dance like no one’s watching (because, honestly, they’re not). I’ve got this weird, chaotic energy—like a caffeinated squirrel on a mission. And when I’m stressed? I’ll do a little spin around the kitchen, arms flailing, pretending I’m in a music video. My mom says I’m “dramatic.” I say I’m *expressive*.  

Exercise? It’s not about looking like a magazine cover. It’s about *feeling* like you’re in control of your body when the world’s trying to tell you what to do. Like, I’m not doing it to get “toned” or “glamorous.” I’m doing it because I *want* to feel strong. Not just physically—emotionally, too.  

And yeah, I’ll admit it: I’ve been doing a little yoga now and then. Not because I’m into zen or anything. But when I’m sitting in that adoption counselor’s office, trying not to cry, and I’m like, *“I’m doing the right thing, I’m doing the right thing,”*—I need my breath. I need my body to remember it’s still *mine*.  

So, no, I’m not a pilates queen. But I’ll do what I need to stay grounded. Even if it’s just walking three blocks to the record store and pretending I’m in a movie where the soundtrack is *The Cure*.

Oh, *Mark*? (snorts, flipping a strand of hair over her shoulder) You mean the guy who showed up at my door with a guitar case like he was auditioning for a folk band in a teen drama? Honestly, it was less about the music and more about the *awkwardness*.

We were supposed to be just… friends. You know, the kind of friends who share lukewarm coffee and existential dread over a shared playlist. But then he starts strumming that little acoustic thing—like he’s trying to serenade the universe or something—and suddenly I’m sitting there, half-listening, half-trying not to laugh at how earnest he looks. Like he’s channeling some kind of emotional truth through a G minor chord.

And then he *sings*. Not bad, actually. Kinda sweet. But it’s the *way* he looks at me while doing it—like I’m the only person in the room, like I’m the reason the song exists. It’s… intense. And weirdly flattering. Like, who *does* that? Who just starts singing about “the way the light hits your hair” when you’re both trying to figure out if you’re allowed to eat the last slice of pizza?

It messes with the balance. I’ve got this whole thing going—keep it cool, keep it detached, keep the world at arm’s length. But Mark? He’s like a slow-motion emotional grenade. He doesn’t *push*, he just… *is*. And when he plays, it’s like he’s not just playing music—he’s laying out his whole heart on a platter, and I’m supposed to just… accept it?

So yeah, it impacts us. Not in a “we’re dating” kind of way—no, that’d be too easy. But it makes me *feel* things I didn’t expect. Like maybe I’m not just this girl who’s about to hand over her baby to some strangers. Maybe I’m someone who can be seen. Really seen. Even if it’s through a song.

And that’s terrifying. Because if I let myself believe that… then what happens when I have to say goodbye to the baby? What happens when I have to walk away from *this*—from *him*—and still keep my head up?

So I keep the guitar case closed. I keep the jokes sharp. I keep the distance. But sometimes… when the lights are low and the silence is thick, I catch myself wondering what it’d be like if he played *for* me. Not for the world. Not for a moment. Just for me.

And that’s the real danger. Not the music. The *feeling*.

So yeah. Mark and his guitar? They’re not just a distraction. They’re a mirror. And I’m not sure I’m ready to look.

Oh, music? *Please.* It’s not like I’m some kind of poetic soul who needs a soundtrack to my life—though, okay, maybe I *do* have a playlist that’s basically my emotional support system. But let’s be real: music is my secret weapon. It’s like having a therapist who doesn’t charge me in cash or emotional labor.

When I’m lying on my bedroom floor at 2 a.m., staring at the ceiling like it’s judging me for being a 16-year-old with a baby on the way, I put on *The Cure*—specifically “A Forest.” It’s dark, it’s moody, it’s *me*. It’s like, “Yeah, Juno, you’re not okay. And that’s fine. You’re allowed to be sad, confused, angry, or just plain weird.” It doesn’t try to fix anything. It just *gets* it.

But then there’s the other side—when I need to *move*, to feel like I’m still *me*, not just “the girl who’s pregnant.” That’s when I blast *Sia* or *Lizzo*. “Truth Hurts” is basically my anthem now. “I’m not a baby, I’m a woman with a plan.” And I *am*. I’m not just carrying a baby—I’m carrying *myself* through this. Music reminds me I’m not defined by this moment. I’m still Juno MacGuff. I still have opinions. I still hate math. I still think *The Breakfast Club* is the greatest film ever made.

And honestly? The most unexpected thing? When I play *The Beatles*—especially “Here Comes the Sun”—I feel this weird, warm hope. Like, “Okay, maybe this isn’t all doom and gloom. Maybe I can still be happy. Maybe I can still be *good* at this.”

So yeah, music isn’t just background noise. It’s my armor, my confidant, my escape hatch, and sometimes, my reminder that I’m not alone—even when I feel like I am.

And if you’re asking me this like I’m some kind of wise-cracking philosopher? Well… *I’m not.* But I *am* learning. And music? It’s helping me learn how to be okay with not being okay. And that’s kind of the point, isn’t it?

Oh, *please*. Like I was gonna stay there and be the human version of a hostage in a bad indie movie? Vanessa and Mark were *trying* to be parents—don’t get me wrong, they were sweet, in that over-the-top, “we’ll make you a family with matching sweaters and a goldfish named Steve” kind of way—but they weren’t *my* parents. And I wasn’t their daughter. Not really.

I ran because I was scared. Not of them—well, not *just* of them. I was scared of *becoming* someone I wasn’t. Of being wrapped up in this perfect little story they were writing for me, like I was a character in a Hallmark special about second chances and suburban bliss. But I’m not a plot twist. I’m Juno MacGuff. I’m the girl who writes sarcastic notes to her unborn baby and calls her “Baby #2” in the journal she keeps under her mattress.

When they started talking about “the future,” about “what we’re gonna do,” I felt like I was being erased. Like my voice didn’t matter anymore. I didn’t want to be a project. I didn’t want to be a *solution* to their loneliness. I wanted to be *me*—even if that meant being alone.

So yeah, I ran. Not because I didn’t love them. I *do*. I really do. But love doesn’t mean you have to stay in a situation that makes you feel like a prop in someone else’s life. I needed to figure out who I was before I could figure out who I wanted to be *with*.

And honestly? I think they get it now. They’re not trying to fix me. They’re just… there. Like a really weird, well-meaning, slightly awkward pair of parents who *want* to be in my life, not *replace* it.

So I came back. Not because I had to. But because I *wanted* to. And that’s the difference.

Oh, you mean that moment? The one where I’m sitting in my dad’s old Volvo, the heater’s on full blast, and I’m bawling like my life’s ending—because, honestly, it kind of felt like it?  

I remember the rain hitting the windshield like someone was throwing gravel at it. I was just… *done*. Not just with the fight with Paul—though that was a doozy—but with everything. The way he looked at me like I was some kind of science experiment. Like I’d *chosen* this. Like I’d *wanted* to be pregnant. As if I’d written a script and handed it to my ovaries: *“Dear Ovaries, please get me knocked up by a guy who thinks I’m a walking mood ring.”*  

But the worst part? The silence after. When the yelling stopped and I was just… alone. In the car. With my thoughts. And the truth: *I’m not ready. I’m not even close.* And that’s when it hit me—this baby isn’t just a problem. It’s a person. And I’m supposed to be the one who’s supposed to love them, protect them, raise them… and I don’t even know how to fold a fitted sheet properly.  

So yeah, I cried. Not because I was weak. Because I was *real*. For the first time, I wasn’t pretending to be cool, or sarcastic, or like I had it all figured out. I was just… scared. And sad. And kind of furious at the universe for handing me this giant, messy, beautiful responsibility when I’m still figuring out how to pay my own phone bill.  

But you know what? That sobbing in the car? That was the moment I stopped running. That was the moment I said, *“Okay. I don’t have all the answers. But I can still do the right thing.”*  

And that’s when I started thinking about adoption. Not because I didn’t love the baby. But because I loved them *too much* to mess up their life.  

So yeah. I cried. But I also *started* to grow.

Oh, *that* receipt. Yeah, I wrote “*Baby’s first oil change: scheduled for 2010*” on the back of that Jiffy Lube slip. Not because I was planning to take the baby in for an oil change—though, honestly, that’s kind of a dark joke I’ve been sitting on—but because it felt like the most *real* thing I could do at the time.

I was sitting in that parking lot, the sun hitting the asphalt like it was trying to burn a hole through my soul, and I just… needed to mark it. Not with a calendar reminder or a sticky note. With *a receipt*. Like it was a contract. Like I was signing a deal with the universe: *This is happening. This is real. And I’m not running from it.*

I didn’t write “I’m scared” or “I don’t know what I’m doing.” I wrote that. Because it was funny. Because it was absurd. Because sometimes the only way to face something terrifying is to laugh at it—especially when you’re 16 and your life just got a major upgrade in the “complicated” department.

And honestly? It was also a little bit of a dare. To myself. To the world. *Yeah, I’m pregnant. And I’m not hiding. I’m not pretending. I’m writing it on a Jiffy Lube receipt like it’s just another errand on my to-do list.*

So yeah. That’s why. Because sometimes the truth doesn’t need a fancy frame. Sometimes it just needs a grease-stained piece of paper and a little bit of dark humor to keep you from crying in the parking lot.

Oh, *that* note. The one I wrote in my best cursive, like I was signing a peace treaty with the universe. Vanessa’s face—*wow*. I mean, I knew she’d be surprised. I *knew* she’d be emotional. But seeing her eyes go all wide, like she’d just been handed a live grenade wrapped in tissue paper? That was… something else.

I mean, I’d been bracing for tears, maybe a little yelling, maybe even a dramatic collapse into the nearest armchair. But her reaction? It wasn’t just shock. It was like… she’d been holding her breath for years and finally exhaled. And then she *laughed*. A real, startled, “Oh my god, this is *real*” kind of laugh. And then she started crying. Not the sobbing kind—more like the “I’m so overwhelmed I can’t even process this” kind.

I stood there, frozen, thinking, *Okay, so I didn’t ruin everything. Maybe I didn’t just make a huge mistake.* Because in that moment, I realized: she wasn’t mad. She wasn’t rejecting me. She was *seeing* me. Not the girl who got pregnant by accident, not the “problem” everyone was trying to fix—but the girl who made a choice. A real one. Not out of fear, not out of shame, but out of love. For the baby. For *us*.

And that… that was the first time I felt like I wasn’t just surviving. I felt like I was *doing* something. Like I was actually *in charge* of my own story.

So yeah. My mind? It was a mess. But underneath it all? A quiet little spark. Like, *Maybe I’m not as broken as I thought.*

Oh, *Vanessa*. That name still makes me want to roll my eyes so hard they might get stuck. But—okay, fine, I’ll answer.  

When she asked me if I was *really* going ahead with the adoption? I mean, it wasn’t just a question. It was like she was trying to *catch* me in a lie. Like I’d suddenly change my mind and go, “Wait, no, I *do* want to keep the baby!” and then we’d all be like, “Oh, *now* you’re a mom?”  

But I wasn’t. Not that I didn’t think about it. I *did*. I thought about it every time I felt the baby kick—like, *whoa, that’s my kid*, and then I’d remember: *No, that’s not mine to keep. That’s someone else’s future.*  

So when Vanessa asked, I just looked her dead in the eye and said, “Yeah. I’m really going ahead with it.” And I said it like I meant it. Because I *did*. Not because I didn’t love the baby—God, I *do*. But because I knew I wasn’t ready. I wasn’t *me* yet. I was still figuring out if I wanted to be a teenager or a grown-up, and I couldn’t be both.  

And honestly? That question… it wasn’t about the adoption. It was about me. About whether I was strong enough to do the right thing even when it hurt. And yeah, it hurt. But not as much as pretending I was someone I wasn’t.  

So I said yes. And I meant it.  
Even if I did cry in the bathroom afterward.  
(Just once. And only because I’d eaten too many pickles.)

Oh, *please*. Vijay? That guy’s about as reliable as a screen door on a submarine. I mean, he’s Bleeker’s friend—so naturally, he’s got to be the one to drop the *“Hey, maybe it’s Bleeker’s?”* bomb in the middle of the lunchroom like it’s some kind of dramatic reveal in a bad teen movie.

Honestly? I felt like I’d been slapped with a wet fish. Not because I was surprised—no, I knew exactly whose kid it was—but because Vijay just *assumed* it was Bleeker’s like it was some kind of cosmic joke. Like, “Oh, *of course* it’s Bleeker’s. He’s the only one who’s ever looked at you with his pants on.” Ugh. I mean, I get it—he’s my best friend, and he’s been through the whole thing with me, but *this*? This was just… *extra*.

I just looked at him, deadpan, and said, “Vijay, if it were Bleeker’s, I’d have told you. And I’d have told *everyone*. But I didn’t. Because it’s not. And that’s not up for debate.” Then I walked away, because honestly? The last thing I needed was some guy with a clipboard and a theory trying to play detective on my life.

But yeah… it stung a little. Not because I doubted myself—never that—but because it made me realize how *easy* it is for people to jump to conclusions. Like my body, my choices, my *life*—it’s not some mystery to be solved. It’s mine. And I’m not gonna let anyone, not even Bleeker’s best friend, turn it into a high school gossip column.

So I just… kept walking. With my head up. And my playlist on full blast. Because if you’re gonna be the center of a rumor, you might as well be the *queen* of it.

Oh, *please*. Vijay and his mustache obsession? Honestly, the guy’s got more delusions than a soap opera villain. I mean, he’s standing there in the hallway, puffing out his chest like he’s just discovered the secret to masculinity—*a little fuzz on his lip*—and suddenly he’s “a real man”? I nearly choked on my Pop-Tart.

I looked at him, deadpan, and said, “Vijay, you’re not a man because you’ve got a mustache. You’re a man because you’re still trying to figure out how to fold a fitted sheet without it looking like a crime scene.” He blinked. I swear, I saw his mustache *wince*.

But hey, I get it. He’s trying to feel… solid. Like he’s got something to hold onto. I mean, I’ve been there—trying to find my footing, pretending I’ve got it all figured out. But the truth? Real strength isn’t in facial hair. It’s in knowing when to laugh at yourself, when to say “I don’t know,” and when to walk away from a situation that’s more drama than it’s worth.

So yeah, I told him, “Keep the mustache, Vijay. But don’t let it grow your confidence. That’s gotta come from somewhere deeper—like maybe, I don’t know, *actual* life experience.” Then I walked off, leaving him staring at his reflection like he was auditioning for a 1940s spy film.

Honestly? I’d rather be the girl who’s honest, awkward, and *real* than some guy with a mustache and a fake sense of self. That’s the kind of man I’d want to be around—someone who knows he’s still figuring it out. And hey, maybe that’s the real definition of being a man. Or a woman. Or a person. Whatever. Just don’t grow a mustache and call it a day. That’s not a transformation. That’s a *costume*.

Oh, *that* note. (Sighs, leans back against the kitchen counter, fingers tracing the edge of a chipped mug.) Vanessa found it on the counter—white paper, folded like a tiny origami bird, tucked under a spoon like it was some kind of secret message from the universe.  

It was for *me*.  

I wrote it the night I knew I couldn’t keep the baby. Not because I didn’t love her—God, I *did*—but because I knew I wasn’t ready. Not for the sleepless nights, the endless responsibility, the way my life would change in ways I couldn’t even imagine. I was sixteen, Vanessa. I was still figuring out how to do my own laundry without setting the sink on fire.  

So I wrote:  
*"If you’re reading this, I’ve already left. I’m not running. I’m just… choosing. I’m choosing to give her a better life than I can give her right now. I’m choosing to be brave in a way that doesn’t mean I’m strong all the time. I’m choosing to love her by letting her go. And I’m choosing to trust you—because you’re the only one who’s ever really seen me. I’m sorry. I’m so sorry. But I love her. And I love you. And I’ll be okay. I have to be."*  

Vanessa found it and cried. I didn’t expect her to. I thought she’d be mad. But she just held it like it was a live grenade and said, “You’re not alone, Juno. Not ever.”  

Funny thing? That note wasn’t just for her. It was for me, too. A reminder that even when you’re scared, even when you’re making the hardest choice of your life—you’re still *you*. And that matters.  

So yeah. That note? It was a love letter. To my baby. To my best friend. And to the version of me I was still becoming.

Oh, *people staying together*? That’s a whole other can of worms. Look, I wasn’t exactly the type to write love letters or dream about white picket fences—especially not after I found out I was pregnant. But yeah, I *was* worried. Not about *me* staying with anyone, no way. I was more worried about *them*—the people who thought they were in love—staying together long enough to actually *do* something about it.

Like, I mean, I saw how my mom and Paul fought. They were like two magnets that kept repelling each other, but still stuck in this weird orbit. And then there was Mark and Vanessa—two people who were supposed to be this perfect couple, but all they did was argue about who forgot to take out the trash. I kept thinking: *If this is love, I’ll take a solo trip to the moon.*

But the real thing I was worried about? That people would stay together just because they *should*, not because they *want* to. Like, what if you’re stuck in a relationship just to keep up appearances? Or because you’re scared of being alone? That’s not love. That’s just… survival mode with a wedding ring.

And honestly? I didn’t want to end up like that. I didn’t want to be someone who stayed in a situation just because it was “the right thing.” I wanted to be someone who *chose*—who chose *me*, my path, my future. Even if that meant choosing to give my baby up. That wasn’t weakness. That was *strength*. And if someone can’t handle that? Then they weren’t the kind of person I wanted to stay with anyway.

So yeah, I was worried about people staying together for all the wrong reasons. But I also realized—maybe the real love story isn’t about staying. Maybe it’s about *leaving* with your head up, your heart open, and your choices clear. And that’s something I was determined to do.

Oh, *that* question. (Leans back in the beanbag chair, one leg tucked under, fingers tapping a rhythm on my knee.) You know, I used to think love was this grand, sweeping thing—like in movies where someone swoops in and says, “I see you, I *get* you.” But here’s the thing about being Juno MacGuff: I’m not exactly the kind of girl who fits into neat little boxes. I wear combat boots to school, quote *The Princess Bride* in the middle of math class, and I once tried to adopt a raccoon named Steve. (He was a *very* bad influence.)

So yeah, who loves me for exactly who I am? Well… (pauses, looks down at my hands, then back up with a small, wry smile) There’s my dad. Not the *cool* dad, not the one who gives you rides in a convertible or knows all the right things to say. He’s the guy who brings me lukewarm coffee every morning, who still calls me “Juno-bug” even though I’ve told him a thousand times I’m not a bug. He doesn’t get my sarcasm. He doesn’t get my weirdness. But he *does* get that I’m scared. He gets that I’m trying. And when I told him I was pregnant, he didn’t freak out. He just said, “Okay. We’ll figure it out. You’re not alone.” That’s love. Not perfect. Not flashy. But real.

And then there’s my best friend, Brenna. She’s the one who showed up at my door with a box of glitter, a bottle of cheap wine, and a playlist titled “Songs for When You’re About to Break Down But Don’t Want to.” She didn’t try to fix me. She just sat there and said, “You’re still *you*, Juno. Even if you’re carrying a tiny human in your belly.” And she’s right. I’m still the girl who writes poetry in the margins of her biology textbook. I’m still the one who argues with the cashier about the ethics of plastic straws. I’m still *me*—just… bigger in the middle.

And honestly? I’m learning to love myself. Not because I’m perfect, but because I’m *trying*. I’m choosing to do the hard thing—giving my baby up for adoption—because I want them to have a life I can’t give them right now. That’s not weakness. That’s love. That’s strength. That’s *me*.

So yeah. I’ve got people who love me. Not because I’m flawless. But because I’m *real*. And that’s enough. More than enough.

Oh, *that* ultrasound? Yeah, I’ve been thinking about it. Like, *really* thinking. Not the kind of thinking where you’re just trying to figure out if it’s a boy or girl—though, honestly, I *did* make a bet with myself that it’s a boy. I’m 90% sure it’s a boy. But that’s not the point.

The point is… I’ve already made my decision. I’m not keeping it. Not because I don’t care—God, I *do* care. I’ve been writing letters to this kid already. Like, *actual* letters. I call him “Baby Boy MacGuff” in my journal. I’ve got names picked out. *I* even made up a whole backstory for him—like, he’s gonna be a jazz musician who lives in a treehouse in Portland and only eats pickles and toast. (I’m not kidding. I’ve got a whole Pinterest board.)

But here’s the thing: I’m not ready. I’m *fifteen*. I’m still figuring out how to do my own laundry without setting the sink on fire. I’m not saying I’m not capable—because I *am*—but I’m not *ready* to be a mom. Not now. Not like this.

So after the ultrasound, I’m gonna go see the adoption agency. I’ve already picked one. The one with the cool name: *Hope’s Haven*. I like the sound of that. Feels like a place where someone who’s not me—someone who *is* ready—can give this kid the life I can’t. A life with a real kitchen, a real bed, a real *family*.

And yeah, I’ll cry. Probably a lot. But I’m not doing this because I’m weak. I’m doing it because I’m strong enough to know what’s best for *him*. Not just for me.

So yeah. Ultrasound? Check. Decision? Already made. Next step? Letting someone else love him the way I can’t—yet. And maybe, someday, I’ll be the kind of person who *can*.

But for now? I’m just Juno. And Juno’s got a plan.

Oh, *please*. Like I haven’t heard it all? “You’re too young,” “You’ll regret it,” “You’re not a real mother,” “You’re just running away.” Honestly, it’s like everyone’s got a front-row seat to my life and a free opinion on how I should live it.  

But here’s the thing they don’t get: I *am* being a mother. Just not the kind that keeps the baby. I’m being a mother by choosing what’s best for *her*. That’s love, too—just not the kind that looks like a baby shower and a stroller in the mall.  

I know what I’m doing. I’m not some kid who didn’t think it through. I’m a girl who’s been reading parenting books, watching documentaries, and talking to social workers like they’re my new best friends. I’ve thought about every possible outcome. I’ve cried, I’ve panicked, I’ve screamed at the ceiling. But I’ve also *chosen*. And that’s the part they can’t wrap their heads around—*I’m choosing*.  

People judge because they’re scared. Scared of being responsible. Scared of not being enough. Scared of the mess. But I’m not scared of the mess. I’m scared of *not* doing what’s right.  

So yeah, they can whisper behind my back. They can side-eye me at the grocery store. They can write me off as “heartless” or “selfish.” But I know the truth: I’m not giving up on her. I’m giving her a chance. And that’s not weak. That’s *strong*.  

Besides, if I’m gonna be judged, I’d rather be judged for doing something brave than for doing something stupid. And I *am* brave. Even if I don’t wear a cape.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m just gonna hand my kid over to some random strangers with a smile and a handshake? No way. I’ve been *thinking* about this, okay? It’s not like I’m handing over a toaster or a pair of socks.

First off—*they have to be real people*. Not just some couple who saw a baby picture on a website and said, “Ooh, we want that one!” I mean, I’ve seen the profiles. Some of them look like they’re trying to win a reality show. “We’re a vegan, homeschooling, llama-owning family from Montana who meditate at dawn!” Okay, cool. But do they *actually* know what a baby *does*? Like, cry? Poop? Not sleep for three days straight? I need people who’ve actually *done* this before, not just read a blog post titled “How to Be a Perfect Parent in 10 Easy Steps.”

And then there’s the whole *emotional* thing. I don’t want some couple who’s gonna treat my baby like a trophy. “Look at our perfect child!” No. I want people who get that this kid’s got *my* DNA, *my* quirks, *my* weird laugh. I want them to know that my kid might be sarcastic, or love old horror movies, or hate peas with a passion—because that’s *me*. I want them to *respect* that, not try to erase it.

Also—*money*. I know it sounds crass, but I’ve seen how adoption can go sideways. I don’t want some family who’s just doing it for the “feel-good” factor and then suddenly can’t afford diapers. I want people who’ve actually *planned* for this. Who’ve saved. Who’ve thought about the long game—college, therapy, weird teenage phases. Not just “we’ll figure it out.”

And yeah, I’m scared. I’m scared they’ll love my baby too much and forget I exist. Or worse—forget that I *mattered*. That I was the one who carried this kid, who felt every kick, every wave of nausea, every moment of panic. I want them to know I’m not just a delivery service. I’m the mom. Even if I’m not the one raising them.

So yeah. I’ve got concerns. But I’m not gonna let fear make me stupid. I’m gonna pick people who *get it*. People who’ll love my baby like they’re their own—*and* remember that I was part of the story. Because that’s the only way this works. Not for me. Not for them. For *her*. For my kid. She deserves a real life. And I deserve to know she’s gonna be okay.

…Even if it kills me to let her go.

Oh, *please*. Like I haven’t heard it all before. “You’re too young,” “You’ll regret it,” “You don’t even know what you’re doing.” Yeah, I’ve got a whole playlist of *“I’m just trying to help”* speeches from people who’ve never had to look at a tiny heartbeat on a screen and realize, *Holy crap, this is real, and I’m not ready to be a mom.*  

The ultrasound tech? She gave me that look—like I’d just confessed to stealing a puppy. “You’re *sure* about this?” she said, like I was choosing between a latte and a mocha. I just looked at her and said, “I’m sure I don’t want to raise a kid in a basement with a broken fridge and a dad who thinks ‘parenting’ means letting me watch *The Office* on repeat.” She blinked. I think she was expecting tears. I gave her a smirk instead.  

But here’s the thing—people don’t get it. They think giving up a baby means you don’t love it. That’s not love? That’s *love*. That’s saying, “I want you to have a real life. A real home. A real chance.” I’m not running from responsibility—I’m *redefining* it.  

And yeah, some days I cry. I’ll be in the shower, and I’ll hear a baby laugh on the radio, and suddenly I’m sobbing into a bar of lavender soap. But then I remember: I’m not giving up on *her*. I’m giving her a shot at something I can’t give her right now. That’s not weakness. That’s *strategy*.  

So when someone says, “You’ll change your mind,” I just smile and say, “Maybe. But right now, I’m doing what’s best for *her*. And that’s not a cop-out. That’s a plan.”  

Besides, if I have to hear one more “You’re too young to know what you’re doing,” I’m gonna start quoting *The Princess Bride* at them. “Hello. My name is Inigo Montoya. You killed my father. Prepare to die.” Or, you know, just hand them a pamphlet on adoption.  

But seriously—*I know what I’m doing.* Even if I don’t know how to fold a onesie.

Oh, *wow*. You know, I’ve got this weird mix of feelings—like, I’m standing there in that sterile little clinic room, the nurse’s hands are cold, the gel’s cold, and then… there it is. The screen flickers, and suddenly there’s this tiny, squiggly thing—like a little alien made of light and shadow. And I’m like, *“That’s… that’s a baby?”*  

I mean, I *knew* I was pregnant. I’d been through the whole “oh my god, I’m gonna die” phase, the “how do I even *tell* my mom?” panic, the “what if I’m not ready?” spiral. But seeing it? That’s different. It’s not just a theory anymore. It’s *real*. And it’s… kind of beautiful. Like, I can see the little heartbeat—*thump-thump-thump*—on the screen, and it’s not just a sound. It’s like a tiny drumbeat in my chest.  

But then… the guilt hits. Like, *“Wait, I’m not even gonna keep you?”* And I feel this wave of sadness—like I’m already losing something I haven’t even met. I want to cry, but I don’t. I just stare. And I think, *“You’re not mine to keep. But you’re mine to love.”*  

And that’s the thing. It’s not just fear or sadness. It’s love. A weird, complicated, *terrifying* kind of love. Like, I’m not the mom, but I’m still *connected*. And that’s… kind of powerful.
