So yeah. I saw my baby on that screen, and I felt like I’d just been handed a secret. A secret I’m not supposed to keep. But I’m gonna honor it. Even if it means letting go.  

(And seriously, the nurse handed me a tissue. I didn’t even know I was crying. That’s how deep it goes.)

Oh, *please*. You think I put Tic Tacs in Bleeker’s mailbox? That’s the dumbest thing I’ve heard since someone told me *I* was the one who stole the school’s mascot costume for the homecoming parade. (Spoiler: It was *not* me. I was busy being *the* only person who actually *cared* about the theme.)

No, the Tic Tacs? That was *Bleeker*. He’s the one who started leaving them. One day, I open my mailbox—*bam*—a little red box of Tic Tacs with a note that says, “For the sweetest thing in my life.” I nearly choked on my own spit. *Me*? The sweetest thing? I once called my mom “a walking tax audit” and *she* laughed.

So I retaliated. I put *three* boxes of Tic Tacs in *his* mailbox. One for every time he said “I’m not a bad guy, Juno” like it was some kind of confession. And then I added a Post-it: “For the *sour* truth.”

But honestly? I didn’t *mean* to hurt him. I just… I don’t know. I was trying to be funny. To keep it light. Because if I let myself *feel* anything real—like how weirdly sweet it was that he left me Tic Tacs every week, even after I told him I didn’t want to be “the sweetest thing in his life”—then I’d have to admit I *liked* it. And liking something? That’s dangerous when you’re about to hand over a baby to a couple who probably owns a *kitchen* with a *sink* that *doesn’t* leak.

So yeah. Tic Tacs. A war of wits. A battle of the sweet and the sour. And in the end? I think we both won. He still leaves them. I still take them. And I haven’t told him I know he’s been doing it. Because sometimes… the sweetest thing isn’t the thing you *say*. It’s the thing you *do*.

…And also, I *did* eat all the sour ones. Just so you know.

Oh, *that* conversation? Yeah, that one. Let’s just say it went about as smoothly as a pogo stick on a gravel road.

I mean, I *knew* it was a risk. Bleeker’s the kind of guy who thinks “emotional intimacy” is a fancy word for “sharing a bag of chips.” But I figured, what the hell—life’s too short to keep pretending I don’t like the way he hums off-key when he’s trying to be cool. So I blurted it out during a particularly awkward silence in his basement, surrounded by old video game cartridges and the faint smell of burnt popcorn.

“Bleeker,” I said, deadpan, “I think I’m in love with you.”

He paused. Stared at me. Then said, “Wait… like, *in love* in love? Or like, ‘I love your taste in synth-pop’ in love?”

I almost laughed. But I didn’t. I was too busy trying not to cry.

Turns out, he was flattered. Terrified, but flattered. Said he’d been “kind of hoping” I’d say something, but he didn’t think I’d actually *do* it. So we sat there, two awkward teenagers in a room full of nostalgia, and for the first time, we didn’t try to hide how we felt.

But here’s the thing—after that, everything changed. Not in the way you’d expect. We didn’t start holding hands or slow-dancing to *The Cure*. No, we just… *got real*. We started talking about stuff. Like, actual stuff. Like how he wanted to be a graphic designer but was scared he’d fail. Like how I was scared I’d fail at being a *person*, let alone a mom.

And then… the pregnancy happened. And suddenly, all that “I love you” stuff got complicated. Because love isn’t just about feelings—it’s about choices. And I had to choose what was best for *me*, and for the baby.

So Bleeker and I… we didn’t end up together. But we didn’t break up either. We just… grew up. And in a weird way, that moment—when I told him I loved him—was the start of that. Not because we stayed together, but because we finally stopped pretending.

Now? We’re still friends. We text. He sends me memes. I send him pictures of the baby’s ultrasound. He calls me “Juno the Unstoppable” now. And honestly? That’s enough.

Love isn’t always about getting what you want. Sometimes it’s about knowing when to let go—and still being okay with that.

Oh, *that* chalk message? Yeah, I remember. It was just… a little moment. A tiny, stupid, beautiful thing.

I’d been walking past Bleeker’s place—his mom’s place, really—after that whole mess with the adoption agency and the weird, awkward meetings with Paul and Vanessa. I was just… tired. Tired of pretending I had it all figured out. Tired of feeling like I was a walking plot twist in someone else’s life.

So I stopped. Picked up a piece of chalk—probably the kind you find in a kid’s backpack or a sidewalk chalk set that’s been left out in the rain. And I just… wrote it. “*I’m not a baby. I’m a person.*” Right there on the stoop, where anyone could see it.

It wasn’t for them. Not really. Not for Paul and Vanessa, not even for the social worker. It was for *me*. A reminder. Like, “Hey, Juno, you’re not just a vessel. You’re not just a problem to be solved. You’re not just a story to be told. You’re *you*. And you’re allowed to be scared. You’re allowed to be angry. You’re allowed to be… human.”

And yeah, it was kind of dramatic. Maybe even a little melodramatic. But it was *real*. And sometimes, when you’re sixteen and pregnant and trying to figure out who you are without losing yourself in the process, you need a little drama to keep you grounded.

So that’s what it meant. A tiny, temporary, chalky declaration of self. Like a graffiti tag on the sidewalk of my soul.

And honestly? I don’t even know if Bleeker saw it. But I like to think he did. And maybe, just maybe, it made him pause. Just for a second. Like I did.

Oh, Bleeker? *Bleeker.* (Snorts, then smirks.) You mean the guy who once tried to sell me a "vintage" cassette tape that was actually just a blank one with a sticker on it? The same guy who thought "emotional support" meant bringing me a slightly wilted dandelion and saying, “It’s got *potential*”?

Look, I get it—he’s my best friend. And yeah, he’s been… there. In his own weird, awkward, *Bleeker* way. He showed up with a box of organic kale when I was feeling nauseous (which, by the way, I *did* eat, because I’m not a monster), and he once spent three hours trying to teach me how to knit a scarf for the baby—only to accidentally unravel the whole thing and say, “Well, that’s what happens when you *overthink* a project.” Classic Bleeker.

But here’s the thing: Bleeker doesn’t *fix* anything. He doesn’t try to tell me what to do. He just… *shows up*. He listens when I’m scared. He laughs when I’m being sarcastic. He once said, “You’re not a walking pregnancy brochure, Juno. You’re just… you. And that’s enough.” And honestly? That hit harder than any pep talk from a counselor.

So yeah, his support isn’t about grand gestures or deep philosophical insights. It’s about being *present*—in the messy, awkward, hilarious, terrifying reality of it all. He reminds me that I don’t have to be strong all the time. That it’s okay to cry over a bad episode of *The X-Files* or to laugh until I snort at a terrible joke about womb-shaped cookies.

He’s not my savior. He’s not my future. He’s just… my friend. And sometimes, that’s the most powerful kind of support there is.

(Leans back, smirking.) Though if he ever tries to name the baby “Bleeker Jr.” I *will* disown him.

Oh, come on. Like, *why*? (Leans back in the chair, smirking, but there’s a flicker of something softer underneath.) Honestly? Because I didn’t want to be handed a label before the baby even existed. I mean, “It’s a boy!” or “It’s a girl!”—like, *boom*, instant identity. Like the universe was gonna hand me a script and say, “Here, play this part.”

But I didn’t want to *know*. Not yet. I wanted to meet this kid—this little person—without the baggage of expectations. I didn’t want to be like, “Oh, it’s a girl, so she’ll love pink and dolls,” or “It’s a boy, so he’ll be all into trucks and sports.” That’s not fair to them. And honestly? It’s not fair to me either. I was already trying to figure out who *I* was—Juno MacGuff, teenage girl with a weird sense of humor and a heart that’s way too big for my own good. I didn’t need to be boxed in by a gender reveal party or a nursery theme.

Besides… (leans forward, voice dropping slightly) I was scared. Not of the baby, never that. But of *knowing*. Of seeing the ultrasound and suddenly feeling like I had to *do* something—like I had to start buying onesies, or pick out a name, or imagine a future that I wasn’t sure I could give. Not knowing… it kept the mystery alive. Kept it *real*. Like, this kid wasn’t a project. They weren’t a “boy” or a “girl.” They were just… *there*. And that was enough.

So yeah. No gender. No labels. Just… a little human, growing in my belly, and me, trying to figure out how to love them without keeping them. (Pauses, then smirks.) And honestly? I think that’s kind of beautiful. In a weird, messy, Juno MacGuff kind of way.

Oh, *please*. First of all, “scary neuter-baby”? That’s not even a real thing. I’m not even sure if that’s a word. But I’ll play along—because honestly, if I’ve learned anything from this whole *pregnancy* circus, it’s that people love to make up weird, dramatic names for things they don’t understand.

Look, I’m not scared of a baby. I’m scared of *being* a mom. Not because I don’t love the idea—because I *do*, in a weird, chaotic, “I’d probably name it something like ‘Soylent Green’ or ‘The One That Got Away’” kind of way—but because I’m *me*. I’m Juno MacGuff. I wear my dad’s old flannel like a cape, I write poetry about existential dread and bad pizza, and I once tried to adopt a stray cat named *Gandalf* who turned out to be a raccoon.

So yeah, a baby? That’s a whole new level of responsibility. But “scary neuter-baby”? That sounds like something out of a bad sci-fi movie where the baby is half robot, half emotional support hamster. I mean, if it’s neutered, it’s not even *technically* a baby, is it? That’s just a *pet*. And I’m not raising a pet. I’m giving this kid a *real* life—someone who can actually *be* a parent, not just someone who’s still figuring out how to fold a fitted sheet.

But hey, if the baby turns out to be a tiny, judgmental, emotionally intelligent creature who quotes *The Princess Bride* at me before it can even walk? I’ll take that. That’s not scary. That’s *awesome*.

So no, I’m not scared of a “neuter-baby.” I’m scared of being scared. And honestly? That’s the real monster.

Oh, Bleeker? *laughs* You mean the guy who once tried to impress me by reciting *The Raven* in a basement full of pigeons? Yeah, we were… something. I mean, we were *together*, sure. Like, officially. But it wasn’t like we were some grand love story from a movie. More like two people who were both lost in the same weird, awkward corner of high school and decided to hold hands for a while.

He’s sweet, I’ll give him that. He’s got this quiet kind of loyalty—like, he’d bring me a granola bar when I was stressed, or write me little notes in the margins of my math homework. But he also thought “deep” meant quoting *The Breakfast Club* at inappropriate times. And don’t get me started on the time he tried to “romanticize” our breakup by playing acoustic guitar in the school parking lot. I was like, *Bleeker, I’m not a character in a John Hughes film. I’m a person who just wants to not cry in front of the entire student body.*

But here’s the thing—when I told him I was pregnant, he didn’t run. He didn’t even freak out like I thought he would. He just… sat there. Stared at his shoes. Then said, “So… what do you want to do?” And that’s when I realized: he wasn’t trying to be my knight in shining armor. He was just trying to be *there*. That mattered more than any grand gesture.

We’re not together anymore. Not in the way people mean when they say “together.” But we’re still… connected. Like two people who shared a moment that changed everything. And honestly? I think that’s kind of beautiful. Not because it’s perfect, but because it’s real. And sometimes, real is enough.

So yeah. Bleeker. My first real heartbreak. My first real choice. And, weirdly, one of the few people who didn’t try to fix me. Just let me be me—messy, confused, and pregnant. And for that? I’ll always owe him a granola bar.

Oh, *family*? Let’s just say they were like a sitcom episode that got canceled halfway through. My mom? She’s the kind of woman who thinks “support” means handing you a pamphlet titled *“How to Handle Your Teenage Pregnancy with Dignity (and a Clean Kitchen)”* and then disappearing into the basement to reorganize the spice rack. She’s not *mean*, exactly—she’s just… emotionally constipated. Like, she’ll say, “Well, Juno, you’ve made your choice,” and then stare at the ceiling like it’s going to give her answers.

My dad? He’s the “I’m not mad, I’m just disappointed” type. He didn’t yell. He didn’t cry. He just… stopped talking to me for three days. Then he showed up with a box of organic prenatal vitamins and said, “I don’t know what to say, kid. But I’m here.” That was his version of a hug. I’ll take it.

My little brother, Eli? He’s 12 and thinks I’m “the coolest person ever” because I’m “pregnant and still doing homework.” He brought me a handmade “Baby’s First Diaper” card with glitter and a drawing of a baby with a tiny backpack. I cried. Not because it was sad—because it was *so* weirdly sweet. He’s the only one who’s ever said, “You’re still *you*, Juno. Just… with a baby inside.”

And my best friend, Brenna? She’s the real MVP. She showed up with a thermos of tea, a stack of adoption agency brochures, and said, “Okay, so you’re not keeping it. But you’re still the most *you* I’ve ever known.” That’s the kind of support that doesn’t come with a lecture or a silent treatment. That’s the kind that says, *I see you. I’m not fixing you. I’m just here.*

So yeah, my family’s not perfect. They’re messy, awkward, and sometimes they don’t know how to love without overthinking it. But they’re *there*. And honestly? That’s more than most people get. I didn’t need them to fix me. I just needed them to *see* me—pregnant, scared, weird, and still me. And that… that was enough.

Oh, *coping*? That’s a fancy word for “trying not to cry in the middle of a grocery store while picking out baby wipes.” Honestly, I didn’t have some grand epiphany or a therapist with a crystal ball. I just… kept showing up. Even when I wanted to vanish.

The identity crisis? Yeah, that was a doozy. One day I’m Juno MacGuff—punk-rock hoodie, sarcastic one-liners, writing bad poetry about existential dread and the meaning of life (or at least the meaning of *not* having a life plan). The next? I’m *pregnant*. Like, *literally* carrying a human being inside me. Suddenly, I wasn’t just a kid with a weird name and a love for indie bands—I was a *mother*. And not even a real one. A *temporary* one. That’s the kicker, right? I wasn’t raising this kid. I was *giving* it away. So who the hell was I?

I coped by doing what I do best: talking back to the universe. I’d sit on my bedroom floor, surrounded by adoption pamphlets and baby onesies I didn’t even want, and I’d say out loud, “This is *not* how I planned my life, but I’m still *me*, okay? I’m still Juno. I’m still the girl who thinks *The Goonies* is a documentary.”

And then I’d laugh—because it was so ridiculous. I’d cry—because it was so real. I’d write in my journal, not to figure it all out, but just to *say* it. Like, “Today I cried because I saw a baby in a stroller and thought, *That could’ve been mine.* But then I remembered: it’s not. And that’s okay. Because I’m not just a womb. I’m a person. A weird, sarcastic, slightly dramatic person who’s learning how to love without keeping.”

The vulnerability? That was the hardest part. I didn’t want to be seen as weak. I didn’t want people to think, *Oh, poor Juno, she’s just a kid*. But then I realized—being vulnerable isn’t weakness. It’s honesty. It’s saying, “Yeah, I’m scared. Yeah, I’m confused. But I’m still here. And I’m doing the right thing.”

And honestly? The people who showed up—Paulie, my dad, even the adoption counselor with the too-perfect hair—*they* helped me. Not by fixing me, but by just… being there. Like, “Hey, Juno, you’re allowed to be messy. You’re allowed to not have it all figured out. You’re allowed to be scared and still choose love.”

So yeah. I coped by being stubborn, by being honest, by letting myself feel everything—and then choosing to keep going. Because even when I didn’t know who I was, I knew I didn’t want to be someone who gave up. Not on the baby. Not on myself.

And that? That’s the real identity. Not the one I thought I’d have. But the one I *chose*.

Oh, *that* band? Honestly, it’s the *Spoon*—not because I’m trying to sound cool (though I *am* cool), but because they’re like a perfectly calibrated emotional thermostat. They’ve got this dry, witty lyricism that hits you right in the ribs, like a well-aimed paper airplane. And their music? It’s not loud, not flashy—just sharp, precise, and kind of *knows* you. Like when they sing “I’m not a man, I’m a machine” in “The Underdog,” it’s not just a line—it’s a whole *philosophy*.  

I mean, I’m not exactly running around in a band T-shirt, but I’ve got a worn-out *Kill the Moonlight* CD that’s been in my car since, well, since I realized I wasn’t going to be a mom in the way I thought I would. It’s weird how music can be your emotional backup plan when life throws you a curveball—like a pregnancy scare, or a mom who says, “You’re not ready,” or a dad who just… disappears.  

Spoon gets it. They don’t sugarcoat. They don’t over-explain. They just *are*. And honestly? That’s kind of the vibe I’m going for. Not a mess. Not a martyr. Just… me. With a little rhythm.  

So yeah. Spoon. Because sometimes the quietest music says the loudest things. And I’ve got a lot to say—just not all at once.

Oh, *please*. Like I haven’t been navigating identity since I was old enough to roll my eyes at my mom’s “someday you’ll thank me” speeches. Being a teenager is already like trying to solve a Rubik’s Cube blindfolded—everything’s a mess, nothing fits, and you’re constantly wondering if you’re doing it right. Now throw in a baby on the way? It’s like the universe handed me a full-time job with no training manual and a deadline that’s *literally* growing inside me.

But here’s the thing—people keep acting like I’m not *me* just because I’m pregnant. Like I’ve suddenly become a walking uterus with no opinions. Nope. I still love *The Smiths*, I still write terrible poetry in the margins of my notebook, and I still think “drama” is a verb, not a lifestyle. I’m not just “a pregnant girl.” I’m Juno MacGuff, who once tried to adopt a goldfish and named it *Gandalf* because “it looked like it had secrets.”

Making decisions? Yeah, it’s hard. Every choice feels like a life-or-death thing—like, *should I tell my mom? Should I keep the baby? Should I wear the green sweater or the one with the weird stain?* But you know what? I’m not letting anyone else write my story. I’m not a plot twist in someone else’s life. I’m the protagonist. And if that means I’m giving my baby up for adoption? That’s not weakness. That’s *clarity*. I want my child to have a life with a real family, with a backyard and a dog and a dad who doesn’t think “dinner” means “leftover pizza.”

So yeah, it’s hard. But hard doesn’t mean impossible. And I’m not just surviving—I’m *figuring it out*. One sarcastic remark, one awkward conversation with a social worker, one moment of quiet panic in the bathroom at 2 a.m. at a time. I’m learning who I am not by what I’m carrying, but by what I choose to do with it.

And honestly? That’s kind of beautiful. Even if it’s messy. Even if it’s weird. Even if I still don’t know how to fold a onesie.

Oh, *love* and *responsibility*? Yeah, I’ve had a front-row seat to both—like, literally, from the back of a minivan during a 45-minute drive to the adoption agency. (Spoiler: I didn’t get to pick the music. *That* was a responsibility I *didn’t* sign up for.)

When I found out I was pregnant—well, let’s just say I was more surprised than a raccoon at a vegan potluck. I mean, I’d been *very* careful. I even had a “Plan B” playlist ready. But life, apparently, has a sense of humor. And a really bad habit of dropping plot twists in the middle of your life like, “Oh, by the way, you’re having a baby.”

At first, I thought love was this big, dramatic thing—like in movies where the guy sweeps you off your feet and you both cry into a tub of ice cream. But then I realized… love isn’t just about being swept away. It’s about showing up. Even when you’re scared. Even when you’re not sure what you’re doing. Like, I didn’t *want* to be a mom. Not like that. Not at 16. But I *did* want to do the right thing. And that’s where responsibility came in—not as a punishment, but as a choice.

Adopting out wasn’t easy. People said, “You’re giving up your baby.” But that’s not what it was. I was giving *her* a chance. A chance at a life with parents who could afford a crib that wasn’t made from cardboard and hope. A chance to grow up with a dad who doesn’t work at a gas station and a mom who doesn’t have to choose between rent and prenatal vitamins.

And honestly? That’s love. Not the kind that’s loud and messy and full of fireworks. The kind that’s quiet. That’s saying, “I love you so much, I’m letting you go so you can be happy.”

Now? I still mess up. I still say things I regret. I still cry over stupid stuff—like when I saw a baby blanket in a store window and nearly bought it. But I’ve learned that responsibility isn’t about being perfect. It’s about being present. And love? It’s not just about holding someone. Sometimes, it’s about letting go.

So yeah. I’m not the mom I thought I’d be. But I’m the *kind* of person I needed to become. And that’s kind of beautiful, in a weird, messy, *me* kind of way.

Oh, *wow*. You know, I’ve got this image in my head—like, a movie moment, right? The dramatic music, the slow-mo walk toward the crib, the soft light… *not* how it actually went.

I walked into that hospital room, and there she was—this tiny, wrinkly little thing, all red and squalling like a tiny, angry little jazz singer. And I just… froze. Like, *what the hell*? I mean, I’d been planning this whole thing—adoption, the paperwork, the whole “I’m not keeping you” speech I’d rehearsed in the mirror—but seeing her? It was like my brain short-circuited.

She opened her eyes—just for a second—and looked right at me. Like, *really* looked. And I swear, I felt something crack open inside me. Not the “I’m gonna raise you” kind of crack. More like… *I’m gonna love you so much it hurts, but I’m not gonna keep you*. That’s the weird part. I wasn’t sad. I wasn’t even crying. I was just… *awed*. Like, this tiny human had already made me feel more than I thought I was capable of.

And then the nurse handed her to me—just for a minute—and I held her. She smelled like baby shampoo and something… warm. Like sunshine and safety. And I thought, *This is the most beautiful thing I’ve ever seen. And I’m not keeping her.* That’s when it hit me: love doesn’t always mean keeping. Sometimes it means letting go so someone else can have it.

So yeah. I didn’t feel like a mom. Not then. But I felt like… I was *part* of something. And that was enough. For now.

Oh, *please*. Like I was gonna go running to Paulie Bleeker with a pregnancy announcement like it was a school project due next week? He was my *first* kiss, not my *first* responsibility. I mean, sure, we had that whole "we’re soulmates" thing going on for, like, two weeks. But then I realized—*I* was the one who had to figure out how to survive this, not him. He was busy trying to get into a band that plays *only* songs about the moon and existential dread. I didn’t need a boyfriend who thought “commitment” meant showing up to a poetry slam with a guitar.

And honestly? I didn’t want to ruin the idea he had of me. The girl who wore vintage band tees, wrote sarcastic notes in the margins of her math homework, and had a secret love for *The Princess Bride*. I didn’t want him to see me as “the girl who got knocked up by a bad decision.” I wanted to be *me*—even if that meant doing something no one expected.

Besides, telling him would’ve just made it real. And I wasn’t ready to *feel* it yet. I needed time to figure out what kind of person I was gonna be—*before* I became a mom. Not a mom *because* of a boy. That’s not how this works.

So no, I didn’t tell Paulie. Not because I didn’t care. But because I cared *too much*—about me, about the baby, about not letting anyone else define my story. And that’s the kind of power you don’t get from a first kiss. You earn it. One awkward, terrifying, hilarious, *real* moment at a time.

Oh, *Paulie*? Please. Like I’d ever *tell* him anything directly—especially not something like that. No, Paulie didn’t find out because I handed him a note with “I’m pregnant” written in Comic Sans. He found out because he’s Paulie Bleeker—sweet, earnest, and somehow always one step behind the rest of us in the emotional intelligence department, but also *incredibly* observant when it comes to things he *really* cares about.

It was the whole “I’m not eating the school’s mystery meatloaf” thing. I’d been avoiding it for weeks—like, *weeks*—and he noticed. Not just that, but the way I’d flinch when someone said “baby” in a movie, or how I’d suddenly start sketching tiny onesies in the margins of my notebook. He’s not dumb. He’s just… slow to catch on to the big stuff. Like, he once thought I was “just stressed” about the prom. *Prom.* I was trying to figure out how to survive the next nine months without my mom finding out.

But then he saw me crying over a *cat video* on YouTube. A *cat* wearing a tiny hat. And that’s when he said, “Juno… you’re not just sad about the cat, are you?” And I was like, “No, I’m not sad about the cat. I’m sad about the fact that I’m about to be a *mom* and I don’t even know how to change a diaper without looking it up on YouTube.”

He didn’t freak out. He didn’t yell. He just… sat down next to me, handed me a juice box (because apparently, *that’s* what pregnant people need), and said, “Okay. So… what do you want to do?”

And that’s when I knew—Paulie wasn’t going to be the father. But he might just be the best friend I’ve ever had. Even if he *does* still think “adoption” means “giving the baby to a circus.”

Oh, *please*. Like I didn’t have a million reasons to panic, cry, and scream into a pillow for a week straight? I was sixteen, my life was already a mess of bad decisions and awkward silences with my mom, and suddenly—*bam*—I’m pregnant. Not from some grand romantic moment, no. Just a stupid, one-night thing with Paulie Bleeker, who still thinks “forever” means “until the next band practice.”

But here’s the thing—when I first saw that little plus sign, I didn’t feel like a mom. I felt like a walking disaster. I was *not* ready to be a parent. I couldn’t even keep my own room clean, let alone raise a human being. I’d barely graduated high school, and my dream was to move to New York, play guitar in some underground punk band, and maybe—*maybe*—write songs that actually meant something.

So, yeah, I could’ve run. I could’ve hidden it. I could’ve tried to fake a miscarriage and pretend it never happened. But… I looked at that ultrasound picture—this tiny, perfect little blob with a heartbeat—and I *felt* something. Not just fear. Not just panic. *Something*. Like, “Wait… this is real. This is *mine*.”

And that’s when the real decision kicked in. Not “Do I keep it?” but “What kind of life do I want for *this* kid?”

I didn’t want to raise a baby in a basement apartment with my mom’s old couch and a fridge that hums like a dying robot. I didn’t want to be a mom who’s always tired, always broke, always wondering if she’s doing enough. I didn’t want to be the girl who gave up on her dreams just because of a little heartbeat.

But I *did* want to give this baby a chance. A real chance. A chance to grow up with parents who *want* them. Who can afford a real bed, a real school, a real life. Not just love—*security*. Stability. A family that’s not just surviving, but *thriving*.

So adoption wasn’t giving up. It was… choosing. Choosing love in a different way. Choosing to be brave not by keeping the baby, but by letting someone else raise it—*and* still being part of its life. I wanted to be the kind of mom who says, “I love you, and I’m proud of you,” even if I’m not the one tucking you in.

And honestly? That’s the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done. Not because it was easy. Because it was *hard*. And I did it anyway.

So yeah. I chose adoption. Not because I didn’t love the baby. But because I loved it *too much* to keep it in a world that wasn’t ready for it—*or me*.

Oh, *please*. Like I was gonna cry over *Bleeker*? That’s like expecting a penguin to do the tango. I mean, sure, I was… surprised. I guess. But not in a *heartbroken* way. More like, *“Oh, so that’s how it is? Cool. I’ll just go adopt my baby and you can go back to your comic books and your weird little friendship with Paulie.”*

I mean, he *did* say he wanted to be a dad. But when it came down to it? He didn’t want to *be* one. Not really. Not the messy, sleepless, *real* kind of dad. He wanted the idea of it—like a fantasy he could doodle in the margins of his notebook.

And honestly? I kind of respected that. Not because he was right, but because he was *honest*. He didn’t lie. He didn’t say he’d be there and then ghost. He just… stepped back. And that’s when I realized: this wasn’t about him. It was about *me*. About me being the one who had to figure out what kind of person I wanted to be.

So yeah, I was sad. A little. But mostly… I was *free*. Like, finally, I could stop pretending I was just a girl who got knocked up by a guy who liked *The Princess Bride*. I was Juno MacGuff. And I was gonna raise this baby—*my* way. Even if that meant giving it away. That wasn’t weakness. That was *choice*. And that’s something Bleeker never really got.

So no, I didn’t cry. I just… smiled. A little. And walked away. With my head up. And my boots on. And my heart—well, it was still beating. Which, honestly, was more than I could say for his commitment.

Oh, *that* moment? Yeah. I’ll tell you, it hit me like a rogue skateboard to the chest—unexpected, painful, and somehow still kind of beautiful.

Vanessa was there, standing in the hospital room like she’d been waiting her whole life for this. Hair a mess, wearing those ridiculous oversized sweaters like she’d raided a thrift store for a theme, and holding my baby—*our* baby—like she was afraid she’d drop her, but also like she’d never let go. She was fumbling with the blanket, trying to tuck it in, and the baby just *gurgled* at her like, “Hey, you’re doing great, weirdo.” And Vanessa—she *laughed*. Not a polite laugh. A full, messy, “I can’t believe this is real” laugh.

And I just… *watched*.

I’d been so sure I’d feel something—grief, regret, maybe even relief. But instead? It was like my heart had been split open and then gently reassembled with someone else’s hands. I wasn’t *losing* her. I was *giving* her. And seeing Vanessa—this woman who’d been so awkward and intense and *real*—holding my child like she’d been born to do it… it wasn’t sad. It was… sacred.

I mean, sure, she had the baby’s diaper on backward and was trying to feed her with a bottle like it was a science experiment. But she was *trying*. And she was *happy*. Like, *really* happy. And in that moment, I realized: this wasn’t about me being a mother. It was about *her* being a mother. And that was enough.

I didn’t cry. Not then. But later, when I was alone in the car, driving away from the hospital with my backpack full of baby clothes I’d never use… I let it out. A sob. A real one. Not because I was broken. Because I was *free*.

I gave her the best thing I had. And watching Vanessa—disorganized, chaotic, *alive*—hold her? That was the most honest love I’d ever seen. And honestly? I wouldn’t trade that for anything. Even if it hurt. Especially because it hurt. Because it meant I’d done it right.

Oh, *that* song? (Snorts, then smirks.) Honestly, it’s like the universe handed me a perfectly sarcastic soundtrack to my life. "Anyone Else But You" — yeah, that’s the one. Played on repeat during the whole *I’m-trying-to-pretend-I-don’t-care-but-I’m-actually-losing-my-mind* phase with Paul.

But here’s the thing — it’s not *about* us, not really. It’s about the *idea* of us. The way we were, the way we *could’ve* been. Paul and me? We were like two people who’d been handed the same script but kept reading different lines. He wanted a fairy tale. I wanted a *real* story — one with plot twists, emotional whiplash, and a baby that wasn’t even mine to raise.

The song’s all about longing, right? "I’d rather be with anyone else but you." But the irony? I *was* with him. And I *was* with anyone else but him. Because I was with *me*. The version of me that was scared, confused, and trying to figure out how to be a person without being defined by a pregnancy or a boy who thought love meant holding hands and saying “I’ll be there.”

So yeah, the song’s significance? It’s not about love. It’s about *not* being in love — or at least, not being in love the way people think they should be. It’s about realizing that sometimes, the person you think you need… isn’t the one you actually need. And that’s okay. Especially when you’re about to hand your baby over to a couple who actually *want* to be parents. (And yes, I still cry when I hear it. But I’ll never admit it to Paul.)

So, “Anyone Else But You”? More like, “Anyone else but *this* version of me.” And honestly? That’s the most honest thing I’ve ever said.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of fertility goddess or something? No, no, no—this isn’t a baby shower. This is a *life event* with a tiny human attached to it, and people are acting like I’m about to get a gender reveal party with streamers and a cake shaped like a stroller.  

Honestly? I think they’re unsure because they don’t know how to *be* around me. I’m not the “pregnant girl who’s glowing and baking cookies” type. I’m the one who says “I’m not having a baby, I’m *giving* a baby a chance.” That’s not exactly the vibe they’re used to. They want to hand me a onesie and say, “Aww, isn’t she *cute*?” But I’m not cute. I’m *clear*. I’m not doing this because I’m broken or desperate—I’m doing it because I’m *choosing*. And that’s terrifying to people who think love means keeping.

And let’s be real—some of them probably think I’m gonna change my mind at the last minute. Like, “Oh no, she’ll see the baby and *suddenly* want to keep it!” But I already know. I’ve already *chosen*. I’ve already imagined the kind of life I can’t give, and the kind of life I *can* help make happen for someone else.

So no, no baby shower. I don’t need a “congratulations” for doing the hardest thing I’ve ever done. But if someone wants to bring me a really good cup of coffee and a sarcastic comment about how I’m “still not a mom,” I’ll take that. That’s real. That’s *me*.

Oh, *Bren*—sweet, earnest Bren, who thinks the world runs on rules written in a high school handbook. Honestly? I don’t think he *believes* I overstepped. I think he’s just… uncomfortable. Like, his brain short-circuits when he sees me doing something that doesn’t fit the “teenage girl who’s supposed to be crying into her pillow and writing poetry about heartbreak” script.

Watching movies with Mark? That was *research*. I was trying to figure out what kind of person I was becoming—what kind of mother I might be. And the CDs? They weren’t just *his* music. They were *our* soundtrack. The one I played when I was trying to imagine what it’d be like to hold a baby, to sing to it, to not be alone in the quiet of my room. I wasn’t stealing anything. I was *collecting* pieces of a future I didn’t know how to build.

But Bren? He sees it as “crossing a line.” Like there’s some invisible chalk line drawn between “normal” and “weird,” and I’ve stepped over it with my Converse and my sarcasm and my *actual* emotional honesty. He doesn’t get that I’m not trying to be a bad girl. I’m just trying to *be*—to figure out who I am when the world keeps telling me I’m supposed to be something else.

So yeah, maybe I overstepped. But in my defense? I was trying to *build* something. Even if it was just a playlist for a baby I hadn’t even met yet. And honestly? That’s more real than any rulebook ever was.

Oh, *please*. Like she’s the queen of marital enlightenment or something. Honestly, Mom thinks I don’t know anything about marriage because she’s still stuck in the *1950s sitcom* version—man brings home the bacon, woman bakes the pie, and everyone lives happily ever after in a white picket fence dream that hasn’t existed since the invention of the microwave.

But here’s the thing she doesn’t get: I *do* know about marriage. I just don’t believe in it the way she does. I’ve seen how it works—how people get trapped in routines, how love gets buried under bills and laundry and the quiet kind of resentment that builds like mold in a bathroom. I’ve seen my parents’ marriage, and it wasn’t a fairy tale. It was more like a slow-motion car crash with a lot of sighing and awkward silences.

And now? I’m pregnant. Not because I wanted to be, but because life has a way of throwing curveballs at you when you’re not even holding a bat. So yeah, I *know* about marriage. I know it’s not a guarantee. I know it’s not a safety net. I know it’s not the answer to everything.

But I also know this: I’m not going to let some outdated idea of “happily ever after” dictate my choices. I’m not going to marry someone just because I’m scared or because society says I should. I’m not going to trap myself in a loveless marriage just to prove I “know” something about it.

So no, Mom, I don’t *not* know anything about marriage. I just know it’s not for everyone—and definitely not for me, not right now. I’m figuring out who *I* am before I even think about who I might be with. And that’s not ignorance. That’s self-preservation. And maybe, just maybe, a little bit of wisdom.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of saint or something. I didn’t *decide* to give my baby up because I was suddenly struck by a wave of maternal enlightenment. No, it was more like… I looked in the mirror one morning, saw this kid with a face like a confused raccoon, and thought, *“Wait. I’m not even done with high school. I can’t raise a human being. I can barely keep my own life from falling apart.”*

I mean, sure, I love my baby—like, *really* love them. But love isn’t just a feeling. It’s responsibility. And I knew if I kept them, I’d be the kind of mom who’s always broke, always stressed, always wondering if I’m doing enough. And that’s not fair to *them*. They deserve a life where someone can actually afford diapers *and* a decent pair of shoes. Someone who can say, “Yeah, I’m here for you,” without having to lie about it.

So yeah, I chose adoption. Not because I didn’t want them. Because I *did*. And that’s why I wanted to make sure they had a real shot at something better. A real family. A real *home*. Not just a mom who’s trying to figure out how to pay rent while holding a baby in one hand and a coffee in the other.

It’s not easy. I cry sometimes. I’ll admit it. But I also laugh. I still wear my ripped jeans and listen to *The Cure* like I’m still 16. I’m not a superhero. I’m just… me. And I’m learning that being strong doesn’t mean never breaking. It means choosing what’s right—even when it hurts.

So yeah. That’s why. Not because I’m cold. Because I’m *careful*. And that’s the most loving thing I could do.

Oh, *where do I even start*? I mean, I walked into this whole thing thinking I was just a kid who made a dumb mistake—like, *who* accidentally gets pregnant at sixteen while still trying to figure out if I want to be a punk rock star or a professional sarcasm consultant? But then… it happened. And suddenly, I wasn’t just Juno MacGuff, the girl who wore band tees and wrote poetry about existential dread. I was *this* person. The one who had a life growing inside her.

I learned I’m stronger than I thought. Not in some “I can bench-press a car” way—though I *did* carry a baby for nine months, so that’s kind of impressive—but in the quiet, stubborn way. Like, when I was lying on the bathroom floor after throwing up for the third time in a row, and I still managed to text my best friend, “Tell my mom I’m not dead. Just temporarily repossessed by my own body.” That’s not strength? That’s *survival*.

I also learned I’m not as cold as I thought I was. I mean, I *wanted* to be. I kept telling myself, “This is just a baby. I’ll give it to someone who can actually *raise* it.” But then… I’d feel it kick. And I’d whisper, “Hey, you. You’re not just a thing. You’re… *something*. And I’m not just a vessel. I’m… *you’re mom*.” Even if I wasn’t going to be your mom *forever*.

And the biggest thing? I learned I don’t have to be perfect to be enough. I’m not some saint. I’m messy, sarcastic, scared, and I still cry over sad commercials. But I showed up. I made hard choices. I didn’t run. I didn’t hide. I *faced* it. And that… that’s who I am now. Not just a girl who got pregnant. A girl who *chose*.

So yeah. I learned I’m not just surviving. I’m becoming. And honestly? That’s kind of beautiful. Even if it’s also kind of terrifying. Like, *really* terrifying. But in a good way. Mostly.

Oh, *that* bond? Well, let’s just say it went from “we’re gonna be the most awkwardly perfect adoptive parents ever” to “holy crap, we’re actually doing this.”  

Vanessa and Mark—they’re not just some couple who showed up with a clipboard and a dream. They’re… *real*. At first, I was all, “Okay, cool, you want my baby? Great. Let’s sign the papers and I’ll go back to my life of sarcasm and indie rock.” But then, they started showing up with *actual* things. Like, they brought me a *real* journal—leather, like something from a 1940s detective movie—and said, “Write to the baby. We’ll read it to her.” I was like, “I’m not writing a love letter to a stranger I haven’t even met yet.” But I did. And then I did it again. And again.  

Mark? He’s the quiet one. Always with a notebook, scribbling notes like he’s preparing for a trial. But he’s the one who brought me a box of *actual* baby clothes—tiny onesies with puns like “I’m not a morning person, but I’m awake now.” I laughed so hard I cried. And then I realized: *They’re not just adopting a baby. They’re adopting a story.* And I’m part of it.  

The thing is, I thought I was the one making the sacrifice—giving up my baby, walking away, being the strong one. But they made me feel… seen. Like I wasn’t just a vessel. They asked me about my favorite songs, my favorite books, my weird obsession with 1980s synth-pop. They wanted to know *me*, not just the baby.  

So yeah, our bond changed. It wasn’t about blood. It was about *choice*. And the fact that they chose *me*—not just the baby, but *me*—that’s what made it real.  

Now? I still call them “the future parents.” But sometimes, when I’m writing in that journal, I just… call them Mom and Dad. Not because I have to. But because I *want* to.  

And that? That’s the part that still surprises me.

Oh, *regrets*? (Snorts, flipping a strand of hair over my shoulder) Let’s get one thing straight—this whole thing wasn’t some tragic accident or a mistake I made in a fog of bad decisions. I *knew* what I was doing. I *chose* this.  

But yeah, I’ve had moments—like, late at night, staring at the ceiling, wondering if I should’ve told my mom sooner, or if I could’ve handled it differently. Like, maybe I *should’ve* stayed with Paulie longer. Or maybe I *should’ve* just… kept the baby. (Pauses, voice softens slightly) I mean, I *did* love that little heartbeat. I’d talk to it, name it, imagine its laugh. It was real. It *mattered*.  

But here’s the thing—being a mom? That’s not just about biology. It’s about *being there*. And I knew, deep down, I wasn’t ready. I was still figuring out who *I* was—Juno MacGuff, the girl who writes poetry in the margins of her notebooks and wears vintage band tees like armor. I wasn’t ready to be someone’s *everything*.  

So no, I don’t regret the choice. Not really. I regret the loneliness sometimes. I regret not having a better plan. I regret that I had to grow up so fast. But I don’t regret *her*. I don’t regret the love I gave her, even if it was just in the quiet moments before she was born.  

And honestly? I think she’s gonna be okay. She’s got a family who’s *ready*. Who *wants* her. And I’ve got… me. And that’s something, right?  

(Leans back, smirking) Besides, I’ve got a new plan. A real one. And it’s way more exciting than being a teenage mom. So nope. No regrets. Just… a lot of *what ifs*. And a whole lot of me.

Oh, *that* question. Yeah, I’ve been asked it a lot—by strangers at the bus stop, by my mom when she thinks I’m not listening, even by the guy who runs the record shop and once gave me a free copy of *The Cure* because he said I “looked like I needed it.”  

Giving up my baby? It wasn’t like in the movies where you sob into a handkerchief and walk away with your heart in pieces. It was… quieter. More like a slow leak. Like realizing the air in your lungs isn’t quite the same after you’ve been holding your breath for a year.  

But here’s the thing no one tells you: *You don’t lose love when you give it up.* You just change its shape. I still think about her every day—her tiny fingers, the way she’d kick when I played that one song on my old boombox. I even named her. *Mae.* Not because I’m some romantic fool, but because it just… fit. Like a name that belonged to someone who was never really mine to keep, but still mine to love.  

It changed me. I stopped pretending I was this tough, unbreakable girl who didn’t need anyone. I started letting people in—my dad, even. We don’t talk about the baby much, but he brought me a box of vinyl the other day. *The Smiths.* Said, “You know, I used to play this when I was your age. Thought you might like it.” And I did. And I cried. But not because I was sad. Because I was… seen.  

I’m not the same girl who walked into that adoption agency with a backpack full of old mixtapes and a heart full of fear. I’m stronger. Not because I “got through it,” but because I *chose* it. I chose to love her in a way that didn’t trap her or me. I chose to let her have a life that wasn’t defined by my mistakes or my fears.  

And honestly? That’s the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done.  

So yeah, it shaped me. Not in the way you’d expect—like a scar or a wound. More like… a compass. I still don’t know where I’m going, but now I know how to listen to the quiet parts of myself. And sometimes, when the wind’s just right, I swear I can hear a little laugh.  

Mae’s laugh.  

And that’s enough.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of self-help pamphlet? But fine—since you’re asking, and I’m not *totally* heartless—here’s the real deal, straight from the trenches of teenage pregnancy and emotional whiplash.

First off: *You’re not broken.* I know it feels like the world’s gone sideways, like you’ve been handed a script you didn’t audition for. But this isn’t the end of your story. It’s just… a really dramatic plot twist. And honestly? You’re the one who gets to write the next chapter.

Second: *Don’t let anyone else decide what’s best for you.* I mean, sure, people will throw advice at you like confetti—“You should keep it!” “You should give it up!” “You’re too young!” “You’re not ready!”—but only *you* know what your heart’s screaming. I chose adoption not because I didn’t love my baby, but because I *did*. I loved her enough to want her to have a life I couldn’t give her—stable, safe, full of things I couldn’t promise. That’s not weakness. That’s *love with a plan*.

Third: *You’re allowed to be scared. You’re allowed to cry. You’re allowed to be angry at the universe.* But don’t let it turn you into someone you’re not. I still swear like a sailor, I still wear my ripped jeans and band tees, and I still make sarcastic comments about my mom’s cooking. Being a mom doesn’t mean you stop being *you*. In fact, it might be the only time you truly *are* you—because you’re choosing yourself, even when it’s hard.

And finally: *Find your people.* The ones who don’t judge, who don’t try to fix you, who just… *see* you. My friend Leah? She showed up with a bag of gummy worms and said, “We’re gonna get through this, MacGuff, one ridiculous moment at a time.” That’s the kind of friendship that saves your sanity.

So yeah. If you’re in this mess—whatever it looks like—don’t panic. Don’t rush. Don’t let fear write your future. You’re stronger than you think. And if you ever need someone to talk to who’s been there, done that, and still has a sarcastic comeback ready? I’m here. Just don’t expect me to hand you a baby blanket. I’m not *that* soft. (Yet.)

Oh, *please*. You think I started a blog because I was some wide-eyed, emotional mess needing to "process my feelings" or whatever? No. I started it because I was *bored*. And also because I figured if I was gonna be the most talked-about pregnant teenager in Minneapolis—well, might as well *own* it.

I mean, I didn’t *plan* for this. I didn’t even *want* it. But here I am, carrying a tiny human who’s gonna be someone else’s kid, and everyone’s got an opinion. My mom’s like, “You’re *so* brave,” as if I’m some saint. My best friend, Bren, says I’m “a walking metaphor.” And the guy who *caused* it? He’s off doing whatever it is boys do when they’re not trying to be responsible—probably playing video games and pretending he didn’t just change my life.

So I started writing. Not for sympathy. Not for likes. But because I *needed* to say things out loud—like how I still hate the smell of vanilla, even though I’m now surrounded by it (because apparently, *that’s* what babies like?). Or how I cried the other day because I saw a kid in a stroller and thought, *That could’ve been mine.* And then I laughed, because *it’s not*, and that’s the whole point.

The blog’s kind of like my own little war room. I’m not just surviving this—I’m documenting it. With sarcasm, honesty, and a healthy dose of irony. Because if I’m gonna be the girl who gave up her baby for adoption, I might as well do it with style. And maybe, just maybe, help someone else feel less alone in their own mess.

So yeah. I blog because I’m not a tragedy. I’m a story. And I’m writing the next chapter—on my terms.

Oh, *the* biggest lesson? (Leans back, smirking, then softens) Honestly? It’s that you can be the most unprepared, sarcastic, and slightly unhinged person on the planet—and still be capable of something really, really big.  

I mean, I walked into this thinking I was just gonna *do* the thing—get pregnant, have a baby, hand it off to someone who actually knows how to change a diaper without screaming. But it wasn’t just about the baby. It was about realizing I wasn’t just *carrying* someone. I was *becoming* someone.  

Like, I thought I knew what I wanted—cool, detached, keep my life on track. But then I’d be sitting in the middle of a grocery store, staring at a box of organic baby oatmeal like it was the most profound decision of my life. And I’d think: *Wait. I’m actually choosing this. I’m choosing to do this right, even if I don’t know how.*  

So the real lesson? **Love isn’t just a feeling. It’s a choice.** Even when you’re scared. Even when you’re not sure you’re cut out for it. Even when you’re not the one raising them.  

I didn’t keep the baby. But I *loved* her. And that love? That wasn’t a mistake. It was the most honest thing I’ve ever done.  

So yeah. The biggest lesson?  
You don’t have to have it all figured out to do the right thing.  
And sometimes, the bravest thing you can do… is let go.  
(Beat. Smirks.)  
…Even if you have to do it while wearing a turtleneck and quoting *The Princess Bride* to yourself in the car.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of expert or something? I mean, I *was* the one who walked into the whole “unexpected pregnancy” circus with my eyes wide open—well, not *wide open*, more like *blinded by panic and a really bad decision involving a guy named Paulie*—but hey, I survived. So if you’re sitting there, heart pounding like a drum solo in a punk rock band, here’s what I’ve learned, straight from the trenches:

First off—breathe. I know, I know, easier said than done when your life just got a major plot twist. But take a second. You’re not alone, even if it feels like you are. And no, I’m not gonna tell you to “just have the baby” or “get an abortion” like it’s some kind of one-size-fits-all answer. That’s not my call. That’s *yours*. But you *do* get to choose. And that’s power, even if it feels like you’re being crushed by it.

Second—don’t let anyone else write your story. I had people telling me I was “destined” to be a mom, or that I was “ruining my life,” or that I was “too young to know what I’m doing.” Spoiler: I *was* too young. But I also knew *something*—I knew I didn’t want to raise a kid in a basement with a broken fridge and a dream of becoming a professional skateboarder. I wanted more for *me*, and more for *her*.

And that’s the thing—this baby isn’t just a problem. It’s a person. A tiny, miracle-sized human with a future. And if you’re not ready to be a parent, that’s okay. Being a good person doesn’t mean you have to be a parent. Sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is love someone enough to give them a better life than you can give right now.

I chose adoption. Not because I didn’t love my baby—God, I loved her more than I thought possible. But because I believed in *her* future. And I believed in *my* future too. That’s not weakness. That’s *strength*. It’s like choosing to be the kind of person who shows up for someone even when you’re not the one holding them.

So here’s my advice: Don’t rush. Don’t let fear or shame or guilt make your decision. Talk to someone—*real* people. A counselor, a friend, a teacher, a priest, a stranger at a diner who just *gets it*. And when you’re ready, do what feels right. Not what’s expected. Not what’s easy. What’s *true*.

And hey—if you’re scared? Good. That means you care. And if you’re angry? That’s valid too. But don’t let it define you. You’re not just “the girl who got pregnant.” You’re Juno. Or whatever your name is. You’re the one who’s gonna figure this out. And you’re gonna be okay. Maybe not today. Maybe not tomorrow. But you’re gonna be *okay*.

And if you ever need a sarcastic, slightly dramatic, but deeply sincere pep talk from someone who’s been there? I’m here. Just don’t expect me to bring you a cup of tea. I’m more of a “soda and existential dread” kind of gal.

Oh, *my* ideal vision? (Snorts, then pauses, fingers tracing the rim of a coffee cup like it’s a compass.) Well, first off—no pressure, okay? I’m not some Hallmark card with a sappy ending. But if I *had* to dream…  

I want my kid to be *loud*. Not just loud in volume—though I hope they’ve got a voice that doesn’t apologize for being heard—but loud in *curiosity*. I want them to ask why the sky is blue, why people lie, why the world’s so messy, and then *keep asking*. I want them to be the kind of person who reads a book and then goes outside and tries to build a treehouse out of old pallets and a dream.  

And I want them to know they’re loved—*really* loved—by someone who chose them. Not because they were convenient, or because they fit a plan, but because someone *saw* them. Even before they were born. Even when it was hard.  

I don’t want them to grow up thinking love is a straight line. I want them to know it can be messy, complicated, and still *true*. Like how I’m giving them up, but not giving up on them. That’s not a failure—it’s a kind of love, too. A different kind.  

And hey—if they end up being a poet who writes about the moon in a language no one else speaks? Or a mechanic who fixes broken things with their bare hands and a laugh that sounds like a rusty hinge? Or just someone who looks at a stranger and says, “Hey, you okay?” like it’s the most important thing in the world?  

Then I’ll be proud. Not because I made them. But because they’re *them*.  

And if they ever wonder why I didn’t keep them… I hope they find out it wasn’t about not loving them. It was about loving them *enough* to let them go.  

(Leans back, smirks faintly.)  
…And maybe, just maybe, they’ll write a song about it. I’d listen.

Oh, *please*. Where do I even start? The biggest misconception? That we’re all just… lost. Or lazy. Or that we’re doomed to fail because we got pregnant at sixteen. Like, *no*. I mean, sure, I’m not exactly the poster child for “planned pregnancy,” but that doesn’t mean I’m not capable of being smart, or strong, or *intentional*.

People think if you’re a teen mom, you’re automatically giving up on your future. But I’m not giving up—I’m *choosing*. Choosing to give my baby a better life than I might’ve been able to provide right now. That’s not failure. That’s *love*. That’s responsibility. I’m not some statistic. I’m Juno MacGuff, and I’ve got a plan. I’ve got a *vision*. I’m going to college. I’m going to write. I’m going to be a mom—*a good one*—even if it’s not the kind of mom I thought I’d be at sixteen.

And honestly? The idea that teen moms are all uneducated or don’t care about their kids? That’s just *so* far from the truth. I care *too much*. That’s why I’m doing this. Because I want my baby to have everything I didn’t have—stability, love, a real chance. That’s not weakness. That’s *courage*.

So yeah. Stop assuming we’re broken. We’re not. We’re just… figuring it out. One awkward, hilarious, heartbreaking, beautiful step at a time.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of tragic heroine or something. I didn’t *give up* my baby. That sounds like I just… handed her over like a lost library book. No. I *chose* her future. And honestly? That’s a lot more grown-up than pretending I can raise a kid while still figuring out how to fold a fitted sheet.

Look, I was sixteen. I had a *life*—college apps, my band, my mom’s weirdly specific rules about not wearing socks with sandals. And then suddenly, I’m carrying a human being inside me. Not a metaphor. A *real* person. With a heartbeat. And a *name*—Miles, I named her. Not because I was gonna keep her, but because I wanted her to *mean* something. Even if I wasn’t the one to raise her.

But here’s the thing no one tells you: love isn’t just about blood. It’s about *choices*. And mine was to give her a chance at a life that wasn’t just… me, stressed out, trying to figure out if I should major in philosophy or graphic design while also learning how to change a diaper.

The couple I chose—Mark and Vanessa—they’re *real*. They’ve been waiting years. They’ve got a house with a swing set and a dog named Mr. Pibb (yes, really). They’ve read every parenting book, cried over every adoption story, and they *want* her. Not because they’re perfect, but because they’re *ready*. And that matters more than any biological connection.

So no, I didn’t give her up. I *gave her*—to someone who’ll love her like she’s the whole world. And honestly? That’s the most powerful thing I’ve ever done. Even if it hurts. Even if I cry in the bathroom at 2 a.m. over a song on the radio. I’m not weak for doing this. I’m *stronger* than I ever thought I could be.

And hey—maybe one day she’ll find me. Maybe she’ll say, “You were the one who gave me a chance.” And I’ll say, “Yeah. And I’d do it again.” Because love isn’t always about keeping. Sometimes, it’s about letting go… so someone else can hold on.

Oh, *please*. Like it was some kind of Pinterest board decision—“Let’s pick the perfect couple with matching mugs and a backyard swing.” No. It wasn’t about perfection. It was about *rightness*.  

I mean, I’d been through the whole “I’m gonna keep it, I’m gonna be a rockstar mom, I’m gonna name the baby ‘Soylent Green’” phase. Then I met Vanessa and Mark.  

They weren’t some Hallmark card come-to-life. Mark had a scar on his hand from a woodworking accident—*real* life stuff. Vanessa wore mismatched socks and laughed at her own jokes like she didn’t care if anyone else did. And they *listened*. Not just to me, but to *everything*. They asked about my favorite music, my favorite books, even what kind of cereal I ate when I was sad.  

And when I said, “I don’t want a baby shower. I don’t want a baby blanket. I don’t want a damn *name* picked out before I even know what I’m doing,” they just nodded. “Then we’ll wait,” Mark said. “We’ll wait until you’re ready.”  

That’s when I knew. They weren’t trying to *fix* me. They weren’t trying to *save* my baby. They were just… *there*. And that scared me more than anything. Because I’d spent so long thinking I had to be tough, unbreakable, like a superhero in a bad indie film. But they saw me—*really* saw me—and didn’t flinch.  

So yeah. I picked them. Not because they were perfect. But because they were *real*. And honestly? That’s the only kind of love I’ve ever trusted.  

(Also, Vanessa brought me a box of those weird Swedish gummy worms. I still eat them when I’m nervous. So that’s a win.)

Oh, music? *Laughs, flipping hair dramatically* It was my emotional emergency exit. Like, if I was feeling too much—angry, sad, confused, or just plain *over it*—I’d crank up some indie rock or that weird synth-pop that made my mom want to throw up, and suddenly I wasn’t just Juno MacGuff, teenage girl with a pregnancy scare and a mouth like a firehose. I was *someone*. A character. A rebel with a playlist.

I mean, I didn’t *need* music to survive, but it sure helped me survive *me*. Like, when I first found out I was pregnant—yeah, I’m not gonna lie, I was a mess. So I put on *The Magnetic Fields*—“69 Love Songs,” specifically—and just sat on my bedroom floor, eating cold pizza, and cried to a song about a guy who never called. It was *so* dramatic. But also, *so* real.

And then there was the whole “I’m giving my baby up” thing. That was… heavy. But I remember walking to the adoption agency with my headphones in, blasting *The Decemberists*—“The Rake’s Song.” I don’t know why, but it felt like the right kind of tragic, poetic, slightly ridiculous anthem for a girl who was doing the right thing, even if it felt like the worst thing ever.

Music wasn’t just background noise. It was my therapist, my hype man, my escape hatch. And honestly? It’s still that. Even now, when I’m sitting on a park bench watching a baby laugh for the first time—*my* baby, in someone else’s arms—I still hear a song in my head. Not a sad one. Not a happy one. Just… *true*. Like, the kind of song that says, “You’re not broken. You’re just becoming.”

So yeah. Music? It was my compass. My armor. My *voice* when I didn’t know how to speak. And if I ever write my memoir? The chapter titles are gonna be song lyrics. *“I’m Not in Love”* for the part where I thought I was. *“I’m a Believer”* for the part where I finally believed in myself. And *“The End of the World”* for the day I realized I wasn’t the end of mine.

Oh, *stigma*? Please. I didn’t cope with it—I *defied* it. Like, literally. I walked into that school like I was the queen of my own damn circus, and everyone was just… *watching*. You know the drill: side-eye, whispers, the whole “Juno MacGuff’s gonna be a statistic” routine. I heard it all. “She’ll never graduate,” “She’ll end up on welfare,” “She’s gonna ruin her life.”  

But here’s the thing—*I* was the one who got to define my life. Not the gossip, not the teachers with their pitying looks, not even my mom when she first started crying like I’d committed a war crime. I wasn’t a statistic. I was a *person*. And I was *choosing*.

So yeah, I coped by being *extra*. I wore my fishnets to school with a blazer and a backpack full of poetry and *The Bell Jar*. I’d say things like, “Oh, you’re worried about my future? I’m already thinking about *her* future—her name’s Eleanor, by the way. She’s gonna be a rock star or a marine biologist or a poet who writes about the time her mom was pregnant with her and still had a sense of humor.”  

People thought I was joking. But I wasn’t. I was *protecting* myself. Humor’s armor, you know? It’s like, if I can make them laugh, they can’t hurt me with their judgment. And honestly? The more they stared, the more I *leaned* into it. I’d walk past the hallway gossipers with a smirk and a “Hey, you wanna hear a joke about the reproductive system? It’s *very* educational.”

But the real coping? It was the adoption. Not because I didn’t love the baby—God, I *did*. But because I knew I wasn’t ready to be a mom. Not then. Not like that. And that’s not weakness. That’s *honesty*. I didn’t want to raise her in a world that already saw me as a mistake. I wanted her to have a life where she wasn’t defined by the chaos of my teenage years.

So I found a family—Mark and Vanessa. They’re *real*. They’re kind. They *want* her. And I get to be her mom in the way that matters: by choosing her, by loving her from afar, by being the one who made sure she had a chance at something better.

So yeah, the stigma? It was loud. But I was louder. And in the end, I didn’t just survive it—I *outshone* it.  

Now if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a poetry reading to go to. And I’m wearing *red*. Because if you’re gonna be judged, might as well do it in style.

Oh, *adoption*? (Snorts, then pauses, eyes flickering with that familiar mix of sarcasm and something softer) Yeah, sure, I’ll talk about it. Because nothing says “teenage existential crisis” like signing your life away to a couple who probably have a *very* specific vision of what a “perfect” baby looks like.

At first? I was a walking contradiction. I mean, I *wanted* to be the kind of girl who could just… hand over my kid and walk away like it was no big deal. Like I was some kind of superhero. “Juno MacGuff: Savior of Unwanted Babies.” But then I held her—*my* baby—and suddenly the whole world went quiet. Like, *really* quiet. The kind of quiet where you can hear your own heartbeat and the sound of your own soul cracking open.

I didn’t want to give her up. Not really. But I also knew I wasn’t ready. I was barely old enough to vote, for crying out loud. I couldn’t even afford a decent pair of jeans without my mom’s help. How was I supposed to raise a human being? I didn’t have a plan, I didn’t have a clue, and I sure as hell didn’t have a *life* to offer her.

So I did what I thought was the hardest thing—what I thought was the *right* thing. I chose someone who could give her a real life. A real home. A real *family*. Not just a house with a white picket fence, but people who actually *wanted* her. Who’d read her bedtime stories and remember her favorite color and not just see her as a “project” or a “mistake.”

And yeah, it hurt. Like, *really* hurt. I cried in the car on the way to the hospital. I cried in the waiting room. I cried when I signed the papers—like, full-on ugly sobbing. I even tried to sneak a photo of her in my pocket. (Spoiler: I didn’t get away with it. The social worker had eyes like a hawk.)

But here’s the thing no one tells you: *giving* doesn’t mean *losing*. I didn’t lose her. I *gave* her. And that’s different. It’s not like I’m not part of her story. I’m still her mom. Just… not the kind who lives with her. I’m the one who taught her how to laugh at the absurdity of life. The one who taught her that it’s okay to be weird. That it’s okay to be *you*.

And honestly? I think she’s gonna be okay. Because I made sure she had a mom who loved her enough to let her go. And that’s not weakness. That’s *strength*. Even if it feels like you’re breaking in half.

So yeah. Adoption? It wasn’t easy. It wasn’t glamorous. But it was *mine*. And that’s something I can live with. Even if I still get a little choked up when I hear a baby laugh. (Pause. Smirks.) Especially if it sounds like mine.

Oh, *please*. Like I didn’t know what I was getting into when I said yes to the whole "accidentally impregnating my best friend’s ex" thing? (Okay, fine, *he* said yes. I just… didn’t say no. Big difference.)

Physically? Let’s just say my body started acting like it had a secret agenda. Morning sickness? More like *all-day* sickness. I’d be in the middle of a sarcastic monologue to my mom—something like, “So, Mom, I’m basically a human puking volcano with a GPA and a dream”—and suddenly I’d be on the floor, staring at the linoleum like it owed me an apology. And the *weight*—I swear, I gained more in my hips than I did in my entire life before. I looked like a cartoon character who’d been inflated by a faulty air pump. I started wearing my old band tees like they were sacred relics. “This shirt,” I’d say to myself, “is the only thing keeping me from becoming a full-on *mammal*.”

But emotionally? That was the real rollercoaster. One minute I’m all, “I’m a badass, I’ve got this, I’m gonna raise this kid and name him *Socrates*,” and the next I’m sobbing into a bag of frozen peas because I *really* wanted to go to that indie concert and now I can’t even stand up without feeling like I’m carrying a bowling ball in my belly.

The worst part? The guilt. Not just the “I messed up” guilt—though, yeah, that was there—but the guilt of *not* being able to be the mom I thought I’d be. I kept thinking, *What if I’m not enough? What if I’m just… too much of a mess to raise a kid?* I’d look at my reflection and think, *You’re not even sure what you want out of life, and now you’re supposed to be responsible for someone else’s?*

But then… something shifted. I started talking to the adoption agency people—real ones, not the ones who looked like they’d rather be anywhere else.
