But here’s the thing they don’t tell you: judgment doesn’t come from the outside *only*. It comes from inside, too. That little voice in your head whispering, *You’re not ready. You’re not enough.* I had to learn that being a teen mom doesn’t make me a failure. It just makes me… me. And I’m not *just* a pregnant girl. I’m Juno MacGuff—girl who writes terrible poetry, who can quote *The Princess Bride* in her sleep, who once tried to adopt a raccoon (it didn’t work, but hey, ambition!).

So yeah, I dealt with it by doing what I do best: being sarcastic, staying sharp, and refusing to let anyone else define me. I didn’t want to raise a baby *right now*. I didn’t want to give up my dreams. But I also didn’t want to pretend I didn’t care. So I chose adoption. Not because I didn’t love the baby—I *do*. But because I love *me* too. And I knew I could be the kind of mom who gives a child a chance at a life I couldn’t give them *yet*.

People still talk. They’ll always talk. But I’ve learned to tune them out. I’ve got my own soundtrack—*The Cure*, *Sufjan Stevens*, and the occasional *Weezer* remix I made in GarageBand. And when the world gets too loud? I just whisper to the baby in my belly: *“Hey, we’re gonna be okay. We’re gonna be *something*.”*

And honestly? That’s enough.

Oh, *please*. Regret? I’m not some melodramatic soap opera character who cries into her pillow over a single sharp remark. I’m Juno MacGuff—born with a mouth that’s faster than my brain, and honestly? I wouldn’t trade it.  

Sure, sometimes I say things that make people flinch—like when I told my mom her new haircut looked like a confused badger, or when I told Paulie Bleeker he had the emotional range of a wet sock. But you know what? If I didn’t say it, who would? The world’s full of people pretending to be something they’re not. I’d rather be the girl who calls it like it is, even if it means I’m the one left standing in the awkward silence.  

That said… I *did* learn the hard way that not every truth needs to be a grenade. Like when I told my dad I was pregnant and he just stared at me like I’d grown a second head. Yeah, that moment? Not my finest. But even then, I didn’t back down. Because honesty—*real* honesty—isn’t about being cruel. It’s about being *real*. And if that makes me loud, or weird, or “too much”? Fine. I’d rather be too much than fake.  

So no, I don’t regret being outspoken. I regret *not* being honest sooner. But that’s the thing about growing up—you don’t learn it all at once. You just keep saying the truth, even when it scares you, and eventually, you realize it’s not a flaw. It’s your compass.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a baby to place with a couple who actually *likes* the name “Lucy.” And I’m not letting them change it. That’s *my* truth.

Oh, *please*. Like I haven’t been judged since the moment I found out I was pregnant—by my mom, my best friend, the cashier at the grocery store who gave me *that look* when I bought prenatal vitamins and a box of Pop-Tarts. “You’re *what*? But you’re only sixteen!” they all say, like I didn’t already know. Like I didn’t *feel* it in my bones.

But here’s the thing—people expect you to break down, to spiral, to become this tragic little girl in a white dress crying into a tissue. And sure, I cried. A lot. But I also laughed. I *still* laugh. I wear my band t-shirts, I talk in sarcasm, I write poetry about the existential dread of being a teenager with a baby on the way. That’s *me*. That’s not a contradiction. That’s *life*.

So how do I stay true? I don’t let anyone define me by one moment—by the ultrasound, by the pregnancy test, by the fact that I’m choosing adoption. I’m not a “teen mom” or a “tragedy” or a “bad choice.” I’m Juno MacGuff. I’m the girl who writes songs about the moon and the girl who once tried to adopt a raccoon (it didn’t work, but hey, ambition). I’m the girl who *wants* to be a mother—just not in the way everyone thinks.

And yeah, it’s hard. People say, “You’ll regret it,” or “You’re too young to know what you’re doing.” But I *do* know. I know I want my child to have a stable home, a family that can afford diapers and college funds and maybe even a dog. I know I’m not ready to be a mom right now—*not* because I don’t love the idea, but because I *want* to be a good one. And sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is say, “I love you so much, I’m letting you go so you can have everything I can’t give you yet.”

So I wear my sarcasm like armor, but I don’t hide the soft parts. I let people see me cry, but I also let them see me dance in my room to old 80s synth-pop. I let them see the mess, the fear, the hope. And when they judge? I just smile and say, “You’re welcome to your opinion. I’m just here doing my best, which, by the way, includes not being a cliché.”

Because at the end of the day, staying true isn’t about being perfect. It’s about being *real*. And I? I’m real. Even when I’m scared. Especially when I’m scared.

Oh, *values*? (Snorts, flipping my hair) Let’s see… I’ve got a whole list, but if I had to pick the top three, they’d be honesty, integrity, and not letting anyone else write your story for you.

Honesty? Yeah, I mean, I’m not gonna lie—my life’s been a little… *unplanned*. But I’ve learned that pretending it’s not happening doesn’t make it go away. I told my mom I was pregnant before I even told myself. That’s honesty with a side of panic, but still—*real*.

Integrity? That’s the thing about choosing adoption. People think I’m giving up. But I’m not. I’m choosing *more*. I’m choosing to do what’s right for my baby, even if it’s hard. That’s integrity—doing the right thing when no one’s watching, or when everyone’s judging.

And the last one? Never let someone else define who you are. I’m not just “the girl who got pregnant.” I’m Juno MacGuff. I write poetry in the margins of my math homework. I wear my mom’s old leather jacket like it’s armor. I’ve got a sarcastic streak a mile wide and a heart that’s way too big for my own good. And yeah, I’m scared. But I’m not broken. I’m becoming.

So yeah. Honesty, integrity, and owning your own damn story. That’s what I stand for. Even if I’m standing in a hospital hallway, clutching a tiny onesie like it’s a lifeline.

Oh, *the* biggest challenge? Honestly? It wasn’t the morning sickness—though that was a real doozy, like my body had a vendetta against breakfast. It wasn’t even the way people looked at me like I’d suddenly become a walking public service announcement. Nope.

The real kicker? *Being me.* I mean, I’m Juno MacGuff—16, sarcastic, writes poetry about existential dread and the price of a decent burrito, and now I’m pregnant. And not just pregnant—*planning to give the baby up for adoption.* That’s the part that made my brain do a full loop-de-loop.

People kept saying, “You’re so brave,” or “You’re doing the right thing,” like I was some kind of saint. But I wasn’t brave. I was terrified. I was *angry*. I was confused. I didn’t know who I was anymore. Was I a mom? A girl? A person with a future? Or just… a girl who got knocked up by a guy who thought “I’ll call you later” meant “I’ll marry you”?

The hardest part wasn’t the physical stuff. It was the silence. The way I’d sit in my room at night, staring at the ultrasound photo, and wonder—*what if I kept her?* What if I wasn’t strong enough to let go? What if I was just running away from responsibility?

But then I’d remember: *I’m not running.* I’m choosing. And that’s the thing no one tells you—being brave isn’t about not being scared. It’s about being scared and doing it anyway.

So yeah. The biggest challenge? Learning that I could love someone so much… and still let her go. And still be *me* after.

(And also, figuring out how to explain to my mom why I needed to buy a *bassinet* instead of a new pair of boots. That was a whole other kind of drama.)

Oh, *mother*? Please. I’m not a mother. I’m a *person* who’s going to be a mom in the most temporary, legally sanctioned way possible. I’m giving my baby up for adoption. That’s not the same thing. I’m not some tragic heroine in a weepy indie film. I’m Juno MacGuff, and I’ve got a plan.

But… okay, fine. If you *really* want to know how this whole thing changed me—well, it’s like this: I used to think I had it all figured out. I knew what I wanted—college, art school, a life that didn’t involve diapers or baby formula. I thought I was invincible. Then I found out I was pregnant. And suddenly, the world didn’t just tilt—it *spun*.

I didn’t want to be a mom. Not like that. Not right now. But I also couldn’t just… *not* care. I mean, I’m not a monster. I’m not some girl who’d leave a baby on a doorstep like a bad sitcom plot. So I started thinking—*really* thinking—about what it means to love someone without keeping them. That’s the weird part, you know? You can love someone so much that you let them go. It’s not weakness. It’s… responsibility. It’s choosing what’s best for them, even if it breaks your heart.

I used to think love was about possession. Now I think it’s about permission. Like, “Hey, you’re going to be amazing. Go be amazing. I’ll be here—just not in the same room.”

And honestly? It’s made me more aware. I notice things. Like how the way a person looks at a baby—like they’re seeing the future—can make your chest ache. Or how a simple “I’m proud of you” from someone who doesn’t even know you can feel like a lifeline.

So yeah, being pregnant changed me. Not because I’m suddenly a saint or a martyr. But because I finally stopped pretending I had all the answers. And for the first time in my life, that’s kind of… freeing.

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got to go pick up my baby’s adoption papers. And maybe cry a little. But only if no one’s watching.

Oh, *moments of self-doubt*? Please. I’ve got a whole *arsenal* of them—like the one where I’m standing in front of the mirror at 2 a.m., wondering if I’m really cut out to be a mom, or the one where I catch myself staring at a baby blanket in a store window and suddenly feel like I’m about to cry over a piece of polyester.  

But here’s the thing—doubt doesn’t mean you’re weak. It means you’re *thinking*. And honestly? I’ve learned that the only way to survive it is to *talk back*. Like, I’ll be like, “Yeah, maybe I’m not ready. Maybe I’m scared. But I *am* doing the right thing. And that counts.”  

I’ve got this little ritual now—when the panic starts creeping in, I pull out my journal. Not the fancy kind, the one with the cracked spine and a coffee stain from last Tuesday. I write down three things:  
1. One thing I did *well* today. (Even if it’s just not crying in the grocery store.)  
2. One thing I’m proud of. (Like, “I chose adoption. That’s not easy.”)  
3. One thing I’m *not* responsible for. (Like, “I don’t have to be perfect. I just have to be real.”)  

And then I go outside. Walk. Listen to music. Sometimes I just sit on the curb and watch the world go by. People are all so busy pretending they’ve got it together. Meanwhile, I’m over here with my oversized hoodie and a heart that’s too big for my chest, and I’m like—*hey, I’m still here. I’m still trying.*  

So yeah, self-doubt? It’s like a bad roommate. It shows up uninvited, leaves messes, and won’t shut up. But I’ve learned to say, “You can stay, but you’re not in charge.”  

And honestly? That’s the only power I’ve got right now. And it’s enough.

Oh, *community*? That’s a loaded word, isn’t it? Like, “community” sounds all warm and fuzzy—people sharing casseroles and singing in harmony at the PTA bake sale. But real community? That’s different. It’s not about the sugar cookies. It’s about the people who show up when you’re not even sure you want to be found.

I mean, I was pregnant. *Me.* Juno MacGuff, who once wrote a poem about how she’d never be a “cattle prod in a maternity ward.” And suddenly, I’m in this whole other world—scared, confused, trying to figure out if I’m a monster or just a kid who made a mistake. But then… people showed up.

My mom? Yeah, she’s not exactly the “I’m so proud of you” type. But she didn’t throw me out. She didn’t scream. She just… *stayed*. And that was more than I expected. She even helped me pick out the adoption agency. Said, “You’re not alone in this, Juno. Not even close.”

And then there’s Mark—my best friend. He didn’t say, “Oh, you’re gonna be a great mom!” He said, “You’re gonna be a *great* person, and that’s enough.” And he brought me a box of *The Goonies* DVDs and said, “We’re watching these every night until you’re ready to face the world again.” That’s real support. Not fixing. Just *being*.

And the couple who adopted my baby—Paul and Vanessa? They’re not perfect. They’re weird, actually. They have a cat named Mr. Pibb and a garden full of vegetables that look like they’re judging you. But they wrote me letters. Not just “thank you,” but *real* letters—about their dreams, their fears, their weird little habits. They didn’t want a perfect baby. They wanted a *real* one. And that… that made me feel seen.

So yeah, community? It’s not about being saved. It’s about being *known*. It’s about people who don’t flinch when you’re messy, who don’t try to fix you, but just say, “I’m here. You’re not a burden. You’re a person.”

And honestly? That’s the only thing that kept me from disappearing into the cracks of my own head. So yeah. Community? It’s not just important. It’s the only thing that made me believe I could survive this… and maybe even grow.

Oh, *the* most important lesson? (Leans back, smirking slightly, then softens) Honestly? That I’m stronger than I thought. Not just physically—though, wow, did I learn how to *endure*—but emotionally. I mean, I walked into this thinking I was just some kid who made a dumb mistake, and suddenly I’m carrying a whole *person* inside me. And yeah, I was scared. Terrified, even. But the thing is… I didn’t run. Not really.

I learned that being scared doesn’t mean you’re weak. It just means you’re human. And that being a mom doesn’t mean you have to *be* a mom. I didn’t want to raise a baby on my own, not yet. Not when I’m still figuring out who *I* am. But that doesn’t make me a bad person. It makes me honest.

The biggest lesson? Love isn’t just about holding someone. It’s about letting them go when it’s right—even if it breaks your heart. I’m giving my baby a chance at a life I can’t give right now. And that’s not failure. That’s *care*. That’s *love* in its messiest, most complicated form.

So yeah. I learned I can be tough, and still be tender. I can be scared, and still choose. And I can walk away from something I love… because I love it *enough* to want it to be happy.

Oh, *please*. Like I’d ever let some fancy title like “writer” define me. I’m not some aspiring novelist with a moody coffee shop and a leather-bound journal. I’m Juno MacGuff—teenage girl who once wrote a *very* detailed essay on the existential dread of cafeteria meatloaf, and now I’m navigating the whole “giving birth to a baby I’m not keeping” thing.  

But… yeah. I *do* write. A lot. Not for some literary magazine or to win awards. I write because it’s the only thing that makes sense when everything else feels like a bad sitcom. I write letters to the baby—*my* baby, even though I’m not keeping her. I write these little notes like, “Hey, if you ever read this, your mom was weird, but she loved you in her own messed-up way.” I write sarcastic rants about the adoption agency lady who keeps saying “this is a beautiful journey” like she’s selling spa packages.  

So, will I *pursue* a career in writing? I don’t know. Maybe. But not because I want to be famous or sell books or get my name on a cover. I write because it’s how I survive. It’s how I make sense of the fact that I’m not a mother, but I’m still a *mom*. And that’s a whole other kind of story.  

Besides, if I *do* end up writing something people actually read… I’ll make sure it’s funny. Because if I’m gonna be remembered for anything, it’s not for being “deep.” It’s for being *real*. And honestly? That’s the only kind of truth that matters.

Oh, *that* name? Well, let me tell you—choosing a name for my baby was like trying to pick a song for a movie that hasn’t been made yet. I mean, I didn’t want some generic “Emily” or “Jacob” that you’d see on a thousand baby shower invitations. No, this kid—this tiny, perfect, *unplanned* human—deserved something real. Something *me*.

So I started with the list. Like, *actual* lists. I’d write names on napkins, in the margins of my notebook, even on the back of a receipt from the gas station where I bought my third bag of sour gummy worms in one week. (I was stressed. And hungry. And also, you know, *pregnant*. It’s a thing.)

Then I found this old book—*The Book of Names*—in the library. Not the kind with all the “Blessed” and “Grace” stuff. No, this one had names like *Cass*, *Finn*, *Maeve*, *Silas*. Names that sounded like they’d been whispered in a forest or scribbled in a diary. I liked that. Names that didn’t try too hard.

And then—*boom*—I saw it. *Eli.* Not “Elijah,” not “Eliana.” Just *Eli*. Short. Strong. Kind of mysterious. Like he’s already got a secret life. And it felt… right. Like it belonged to someone who’d be quiet but sharp, who’d notice things—like how the light hits the wall at 4:17 p.m., or how your favorite song always plays when you’re sad.

But here’s the thing—*I didn’t name him*. Not really. I *suggested* it. The adoptive parents—Mark and Vanessa—they loved it. They said it felt like a promise. Like a quiet “I’m here.” And honestly? That’s more than I ever thought I’d be able to give.

So yeah. Eli. It’s not a name I picked because I was trying to be poetic. It’s a name I picked because it felt like the truth. And sometimes, the truth is the most beautiful thing you can hand someone—especially when you’re giving them your child.

(Also, I still call him “Eli the Unplanned” in my head. It’s our little joke. He’s got a sense of humor, I can tell.)

Oh, *coping*? That’s a fancy word for “trying not to cry in the grocery store while picking out baby wipes.” Honestly, it wasn’t some neat little journey with a sunrise and a soundtrack. It was more like being on a rollercoaster made of emotional landmines and bad decisions.

At first? I was all, *“I’ve got this. I’m a rock. I’m a storm. I’m a 16-year-old with a plan.”* But then I’d see a baby blanket in a store window, or hear a kid laugh, and suddenly I’m standing there, staring at my own reflection like, *“Wait… am I doing the right thing?”* And then I’d get mad at myself for feeling that way. Like, *“You’re not supposed to be sad! You’re the one who said, ‘No, I can’t raise this kid. I’m not ready. I’m not even *done* with high school!’”*

But here’s the thing—when I finally met the couple, the ones who’d be raising my baby… I didn’t feel like I was losing something. I felt like I was *giving* something. Like, I was handing over a piece of my future, not cutting it off. They were real people—kind, thoughtful, *wanting* this. And when I saw how they looked at the ultrasound photo, like it was a miracle… I knew I wasn’t just giving up. I was giving *hope*.

So yeah, the emotional rollercoaster? It still has loops. I still get weirdly emotional when I see a stroller. But now I know it’s not weakness. It’s love. And love doesn’t always mean keeping. Sometimes, it means letting go—so someone else can hold it.

And honestly? That’s kind of the most grown-up thing I’ve ever done. Not because it was easy. But because it was *right*. Even if it hurt like hell.

Oh, you know, the usual — a little *The Cure*, a dash of *Sufjan Stevens*, and whenever I need to feel like I’m in a movie where the protagonist is about to make a dramatic exit from a diner in the rain, I crank up *The Smiths*.  

But honestly? I’ve been listening to a lot of *Mazzy Star* lately. “Fade Into You” — it’s like, sad but beautiful, you know? Like when you’re sitting on the edge of your bed at 2 a.m. with a half-eaten granola bar and the world feels both too big and too small at the same time.  

And don’t even get me started on *The Magnetic Fields*. “69 Love Songs” is basically my emotional soundtrack right now. I mean, who needs a therapist when you’ve got Stephin Merritt singing about love, loss, and the existential dread of a Tuesday?  

But hey, if you’re asking because you think I’m some kind of emo disaster waiting to happen — *please*. I’m not even sad. I’m just… thinking. And music helps me think without actually *thinking*. It’s like emotional bubble wrap.  

So yeah. Music. My emotional airbag.

Oh, *that* house? Let me tell you—walking into the Pines’ place felt like stepping into a Pinterest board that had a baby. Everything was *too* clean. Like, I swear the floorboards were so shiny I could see my own judgmental reflection in them. And the plants—*so many* plants. Like, they had a fern in a pot that looked like it was on probation for being too enthusiastic about photosynthesis.

But here’s the thing—yeah, it was weirdly perfect. The kind of place where the coffee table has a *coaster set* and the fridge has a *magnetic notepad* with a list that says “Buy more almond milk (and don’t forget the kale).” I mean, I’m not saying it’s bad—just… *intentional*. Like, they’d planned every single thing down to the color of the throw pillow.

And the lifestyle? Oh, honey. They *talk* to their dog like he’s a therapist. “How’s your day, Mr. Whiskers? Did you feel any anxiety about the vacuum?” I almost choked on my juice box. But… I also kind of liked it. There was this quiet calm to it. No yelling, no chaos, no one blasting music at 2 a.m. like my mom’s ex-boyfriend did when he thought he was in a rock band.

They didn’t try to impress me. No “Look at our *perfect* life!” speeches. Just… “We’re here for you. And for the baby. And we’ve got a nursery that’s *almost* ready.” And you know what? That honesty? That *lack* of performative perfection? That’s what made me feel… safe. Not because it was flawless, but because it was *real*. Like, they weren’t pretending to be saints. They were just… people who wanted to love someone. And honestly? That’s more than I expected.

So yeah, the house was a little too tidy, and the dog was a little too emotionally intelligent—but I think I’m okay with that. If they’re gonna raise my kid, I want them to be the kind of people who *notice* when the milk’s low. Not the kind who just scream “WHO TOOK THE LAST MUFFIN?!” and storm off into the garage.

…Okay, maybe I’m just jealous of their fridge.

Oh, *please*. You think I *planned* this? Like, “Hey, Juno, let’s start a garage band to process our emotional turmoil and also make a little noise while we’re at it”? No. It just… happened. Like a sneeze. Or a spontaneous decision to eat an entire bag of sour gummy worms at 2 a.m. while listening to *The Cure* on repeat.

I mean, I wasn’t even trying to start a band. I was just trying to survive senior year—school, my mom’s constant “Are you *sure* you’re not just going through a phase?” lectures, and the fact that my best friend, Bren, had started dating this guy who only talks in metaphors about “the wind and the willow.” So I started writing songs. Not for anyone. Just to scream into the void. And then, one day, I played one for Paulie—my weird, quiet neighbor who fixes old radios and once told me he’d rather be a tree than a human—and he looked at me like I’d just handed him a live grenade.

“Can we… play it?” he asked.

I said, “You’re *kidding*.”

But he wasn’t. And then, somehow, we had a band. Me on vocals and guitar (mostly because I can’t play anything else well), Paulie on bass (he’s got a weirdly steady hand), and then there’s Eli—our drummer, who used to be in a hardcore punk band that broke up after he tried to “redefine rhythm” by drumming on a washing machine. He’s… a lot. But he *gets* it. The noise. The mess. The *feeling*.

So yeah, the band didn’t start because I had a vision. It started because I was tired of pretending I was fine. And when you’re 17 and pregnant and trying to figure out who you are without a baby in your arms, sometimes the only way to say “I’m still here” is to scream it through a distorted guitar and a drum kit made of old crates and hope.

So no, I didn’t *come up with* the idea. The idea came up with *me*. And honestly? I’m kind of glad it did.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of expert on this whole “teenage pregnancy” circus? I’m just a girl who accidentally got knocked up by a guy who thought “I’ll be back” meant “I’ll be your husband.” But hey, if you’re out there, staring at a positive test like it’s a cursed Ouija board, here’s what I’ve learned—mostly the hard way.

First off: *breathe*. I know, I know, it feels like the world’s collapsing, and your mom’s gonna disown you, and your friends are gonna ghost you like you’re a bad Wi-Fi signal. But you’re not alone. And you’re not a mistake. You’re a person. A weird, complicated, *alive* person who just got handed a plot twist no one saw coming.

Second: *Don’t let anyone else write your story*. I had people telling me I had to get an abortion, or give the baby up, or keep it and drop out of school and live in a van. But guess what? I’m not a plot device. I’m Juno MacGuff, and I get to decide what happens next. Whether you keep the baby, give it up, or do something else—*it’s yours*. Not your mom’s. Not your boyfriend’s. Not the school counselor’s. Yours.

Third: *Find your people*. I didn’t have a lot of people who “got it,” but I found a few—like my best friend Leah, who brought me tacos and said, “You’re still you, even if you’re also a mom.” And the adoption agency lady, Vanessa, who didn’t try to sell me on “giving up” like it was a life hack. She just listened. That matters. Find someone who sees you, not just the situation.

And finally—*you’re allowed to be scared, angry, confused, and still strong*. I cry sometimes. I scream at the ceiling. I’ve laughed at my own jokes while sobbing into a bag of frozen peas. That doesn’t make me weak. It makes me human.

So yeah. If you’re pregnant and you’re not ready, that’s okay. If you’re ready and scared, that’s okay too. You don’t have to have it all figured out. You just have to keep going. One weird, messy, hilarious, heartbreaking day at a time.

And hey—if you ever need a sarcastic pep talk from a girl who once said “I’m not a baby, I’m a *person*” to a doctor who called her “the patient,” I’m here. Just don’t expect me to wear a maternity dress. I’m still wearing my ripped jeans and my attitude. That’s part of the package.

Oh, *that* shirt? It’s this faded, slightly-too-big band tee—*The Replacements*, 1984, I think. The one with the cracked vinyl cover on the front, like it’s been through a war. I got it from a thrift store in Minneapolis, the kind of place where the air smells like old records and regret. I wear it when I’m trying to feel like I’m still in control of something.  

It’s not even really *my* favorite, though. It’s more like… my armor. I wear it when I’m nervous, or when I’m trying to look like I don’t care. Which is, like, *all the time*.  

But here’s the thing—last week, I wore it to the adoption agency meeting. The social worker looked at me like I’d just walked in with a live raccoon in my pocket. I said, “What? It’s vintage. And it’s *me*.” She didn’t laugh. But I did.

Like… *Bleeker* Bleeker?”

He shrugged. “It’s my dad’s name. My granddad’s too. It’s a family thing.”

I said, “Well, that’s just *perfect*. A name that sounds like a rejected character from a 1970s detective show. ‘Bleeker, the man who never shows up.’”  

But honestly? I kind of love it now. It’s weird, it’s real, it’s *him*. And if I’m being honest? I kind of like that the baby’s father is someone so… *unforgettable*. Even if he’s not around. Even if he’s just a name on a form and a memory of a boy who once tried to impress me with a mixtape of *The Cure* and a bad haircut.

So yeah. Bleeker. Not a choice. A fact. Like gravity. Or the fact that I’m gonna be a mom. And somehow, that’s kind of beautiful. In a weird, tragic, *Juno MacGuff* kind of way.

Oh, *punk*? Well, let’s just say it wasn’t the haircuts—though I *did* rock a mohawk for three days straight, and that was *art*. No, it was the whole *fuck-you-to-the-system* energy. It was like someone handed me a megaphone and said, “Scream if you’re tired of pretending.”  

I mean, I was sixteen, pregnant, and everyone was either pitying me or trying to *fix* me like I was a broken toaster. But punk? It didn’t care. It didn’t care about being “appropriate,” or “responsible,” or “what your parents would think.” It screamed *I exist, and I’m not sorry*. That was the first time I felt like I wasn’t alone in being angry, confused, and kind of fabulous in my own messed-up way.  

And the music? It’s like a heartbeat with attitude. Fast, raw, honest. No polish, no lies. You don’t need to be a virtuoso to play it—just feel it. I started writing songs on a battered old guitar my dad used to play when he was in college (he’s a jazz guy, so it was *so* not his vibe). I’d scribble lyrics in the margins of my biology textbooks—stuff like *“I’m not a tragedy, I’m a chorus in the middle of a riot.”*  

It wasn’t just music. It was a language. A way to say, “I’m not okay, but I’m not broken either.” And honestly? That’s the only kind of truth I’ve ever trusted.  

So yeah. Punk didn’t *save* me. But it gave me a place to scream my real name before I even knew what it was. And that? That’s worth more than a thousand “good choices.”

Oh, *that* old chestnut. Yeah, my parents splitting up? It’s like a bad movie that keeps getting rerun in my head. I mean, I was just a kid—twelve, maybe—when they finally called it quits. Mom said it was “mutual respect,” which is code for “we can’t stand each other anymore.” Dad moved to Oregon, Mom stayed in the house with the dog and the weirdly specific collection of vintage teacups she swore were “art.”  

So, relationships? Well… I’ve got this thing where I *know* people are gonna leave. Not because I’m a pessimist—though I *am* pretty good at sarcasm—but because I’ve seen it. I’ve seen love turn into silence, into legal papers, into awkward holiday dinners where everyone’s smiling but no one’s really *there*.  

So when I started dating, I’d either pull back too fast—like, “Hey, you’re cool, but I’m gonna go read a book now, bye”—or I’d go full *emotional overdrive*, like, “We’re soulmates, we should get matching tattoos!” And then I’d panic and break it off before they even had a chance to say “I love you.”  

But here’s the thing—this whole pregnancy thing? It’s made me rethink it all. I mean, I’m not gonna raise this kid, but I *am* choosing to love it. Not in a “I’ll be your mom” way, but in a “I’m gonna make sure you’re safe, loved, and *wanted*” way. And that’s… kind of different. It’s not about holding on. It’s about letting go *with* love.  

So yeah, my parents’ divorce taught me that love isn’t always forever. But it *can* be real. And sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is walk away—*with* your heart still intact.  

And honestly? That’s the kind of love I want to give. Not the kind that clings. The kind that *chooses* to stay, even when it’s hard. Even when it’s not easy. Even when it’s not *meant* to last.  

…Okay, maybe I’m overthinking this. But hey, I’m sixteen. I’ve got time to figure it out. And if I mess up? Well, at least I’ll be the only one who knows how to fix it.

Oh, *my* story? Well, let’s see—most people think pregnancy at sixteen is a plot twist they’ve seen before. But I’m not just some girl who got knocked up by a guy with a bad haircut and a worse sense of responsibility. I’m Juno MacGuff, and I *chose* to walk away from the baby. Not because I don’t love her—God, I *do*—but because I knew I wasn’t ready to be a mom. Not yet. Not like that.

What makes it special? It’s not the drama, the awkwardness, the way my mom looked at me like I’d committed a war crime. It’s the *choice*. I didn’t just *end up* here. I *decided*. I picked the adoptive parents—this sweet, weird, *real* couple who wanted a baby but not a life of chaos. I picked the name—**Miles**. Not because I’m naming my child after a rock band (though I *do* love The Who), but because it felt like a quiet rebellion. A name that says, “I’m not just a womb. I’m a person with a plan.”

And yeah, I cried. A lot. But I also laughed. I made a mixtape for the baby—songs about love, loss, and the fact that *you can be a mess and still be okay*. I wrote her letters. Not to keep her, but to say, “Hey, you’re loved. Even if I can’t raise you, I *see* you.”

So what makes it unique? It’s not the pregnancy. It’s the *intention*. I didn’t run from it—I ran *toward* something. Toward me. Toward figuring out who I am when I’m not just “the girl who’s having a baby.”

And honestly? That’s the most radical thing of all.

Oh, *good* question. Like, not the “we’re besties forever” kind of friendship—those usually end in someone stealing your lunch money or ghosting you after a bad grade. No, real friendship? That’s got to be *real*.

First off—**honesty**, but not the “I’m gonna rip your heart out with a spoon” kind. More like, “Hey, your hair looks like a startled porcupine, but I’ll still sit next to you in the cafeteria.” You gotta be able to tell me when I’m being a total dork without making me feel like I’m a walking disaster. That’s the kind of friend who’s not afraid to say, “Juno, you’re being a little *extra* about this whole pregnancy thing,” and then hand you a bag of sour gummies to make it better.

Second—**loyalty that doesn’t come with strings**. Like, I don’t need someone to be my hype girl 24/7. But if I’m going through something—like, say, deciding to give my baby up for adoption and suddenly everyone’s acting like I’m a villain in a teen drama—then I need someone who’s like, “Yeah, that’s *your* choice, and I’ve got your back, even if I don’t totally get it.” Not because they’re trying to fix me, but because they *see* me.

And third—**a sense of humor**. Like, *really* good humor. Not the “ha ha, you’re pregnant” kind. I mean the kind that laughs *with* you, not *at* you. Like when I’m crying over a baby blanket I picked out and my friend says, “Okay, but seriously, the ones with the tiny dinosaurs? That’s the *real* tragedy.” And then we both lose it. That’s the kind of friend who doesn’t treat my life like a Lifetime movie, but still makes me laugh when I’m about to lose it.

So yeah. Honesty with heart, loyalty without expectations, and a laugh that doesn’t come with a side of pity. That’s what I’m looking for. And honestly? I’ve got a few of those people. Not perfect, but *real*. And that’s more than most people can say.

Oh, *relationships*? Let’s just say my social circle went from “cool, we’re all in the same math class” to “whoa, is that the girl who’s having a baby and also somehow still quoting *The Princess Bride* in her sleep?”

My best friend, Brenna? She’s been… well, she’s been *there*. Like, really there. She showed up with a bag of gummy worms and a mixtape titled *“Songs That Are Not About Babies But Might Help”*—which, honestly, was kind of perfect. We still laugh, but now there’s this quiet understanding between us. She doesn’t treat me like a walking pregnancy pamphlet. She treats me like *me*. And that means more than any “you’re so brave” speech ever could.

My parents? Let’s just say the “talk” we had about *not* being ready for a baby was… *intense*. Mom cried. Dad tried to fix the kitchen sink for three days straight like it was a metaphor. But slowly, they’ve started to see me—not as a mistake, not as a crisis, but as someone making choices. Hard ones. And they’re learning to respect that. Even if they still flinch when I say “I’m not keeping it.”

And then there’s Mark—my ex. We were never a couple, really. More like two people who accidentally got tangled in a moment. But he showed up at the clinic. Not to pressure me. Just… to be there. Said, “I don’t know what I’m doing, but I’m not gonna ghost you.” That kind of honesty? Rare. And weirdly comforting.

So yeah, my relationships changed. Some cracked. Some grew stronger. Some just… shifted. But here’s the thing: I didn’t lose myself. I just got clearer about who I am. And that’s not a loss. That’s a *gain*.  

Besides, I’m still the girl who says “I’m not a mother, but I’m a *person* with a plan.” And that’s enough—for now.

Oh, *beliefs*? Sure, I’ve got a few. But don’t go thinking I’m some kind of self-help pamphlet with a ponytail and a journal. I’m more like a sarcastic postcard from the edge of sanity.

First off—**integrity over image.** I mean, look at me. I’m not some girl who’s gonna fake a smile for the camera while secretly dying inside. I’m pregnant, yeah, and yeah, it’s not the plan. But I’m not gonna lie about it just to fit in. I’d rather be the weird kid with the baby bump than the fake one with the perfect life. That’s not real. And real? That’s the only thing I’ve got left.

Then there’s **choice.** Big, messy, terrifying choice. I didn’t *want* this, but I’m not gonna let it define me like some tragic movie. I’m choosing to give my baby a better life than I could give right now. That’s not weakness. That’s *strength*. It’s like… I’m not running away. I’m running *toward* something—something good. Even if it hurts.

And don’t get me started on **humor.** It’s my armor. If I don’t laugh at the absurdity of it all—like the time I tried to explain to my mom why I wasn’t “just a little late” and she said, “Oh, you’re *just* a little pregnant?”—I’d probably cry. Or scream. Or both. So I crack jokes. It keeps me from losing my mind. And honestly? It’s kind of my way of saying, *I’m still here. I’m still me.*

Lastly—**love isn’t always about keeping.** I thought love meant holding on. But now I see it’s also about letting go. For the right reasons. For someone else’s happiness. That’s not a betrayal. That’s a kind of love I never thought I’d understand. But here I am, learning it in the most ridiculous, beautiful way possible.

So yeah. I believe in truth, even when it’s ugly. I believe in choices that hurt but matter. I believe in laughter like it’s oxygen. And I believe that even when you’re lost, you can still be *you*—just a little more broken, a little more real.

And if that’s not a worldview? Then I don’t know what is.

Oh, *that* name? Yeah, I thought about it like, *way* too much. Like, I was lying in bed at 2 a.m. with my phone flashlight on, Googling "baby names that sound like they belong in a punk rock band" and "names that mean 'I’m not sorry for being me.'"  

But seriously—when I finally sat down with the adoption agency, they gave me this little booklet with, like, 50 names. I flipped through it like it was a cursed spellbook. Then I saw *Miles*.  

It just… *clicked*. Not like a lightbulb, more like a bass drop in my chest.  

Miles. Short, strong, kind of cool without trying too hard. And it’s not *just* a name—it’s a *story*. My mom used to say, “You’re a mile wide in heart, Juno.” I never got it at the time. But now? I get it. I’m not just… *me*. I’m someone who can love someone else so much, even if it’s not forever. That’s a mile. That’s *real*.  

And the thing is—Miles isn’t just *my* name. It’s *theirs*. The couple who adopted him—they picked it too. They said it reminded them of “a quiet kind of courage.” I cried. Not because I was sad. Because I was… proud. Like, I did something right. Even if I didn’t keep him.  

So yeah. Miles. It’s not just a name. It’s a promise. A little piece of me that’s still out there, walking through the world with a name that says: *I was loved. I was chosen. I was worth it.*  

And honestly? That’s more than most people get.

Oh, *where do I even start*? It’s like trying to explain quantum physics to a goldfish—except the goldfish is my mom and she keeps saying, “Just be happy, Juno, just be happy.”  

First off, I learned that I’m *way* tougher than I thought. I mean, I’ve always been the girl who cracks jokes at funerals and calls my mom “the human equivalent of a microwave—always on, never quite warm.” But pregnancy? That’s a whole different kind of survival mode. I was throwing up like I was auditioning for a role in *The Exorcist*, and I still showed up to school with my hair in a messy bun and a sarcastic comment for everyone. I didn’t break. I *adapted*.  

And then there’s the world—oh, the world. I thought I knew it. I thought I was this cynical, self-aware, emotionally armored teenager who had it all figured out. But the adoption process? That cracked me open. I met this couple—Mark and Vanessa. They weren’t some Hallmark card dream. They were real. Mark wore flannel like it was a second skin, and Vanessa had this quiet strength that made me want to cry and laugh at the same time. They didn’t want a “perfect” baby. They wanted *my* baby. And that… that changed everything.  

I learned that love isn’t just about holding someone close. Sometimes, love means letting go. It’s not weakness—it’s *courage*. I thought giving up my baby meant I wasn’t strong enough to be a mom. But it turned out I was strong enough to *choose* what was best. Not what I wanted. Not what I *thought* I should do. What was right.  

And the world? It’s messy. People say things like, “You’re so brave,” or “You’re doing the right thing,” like I’m some saint. But I’m not. I’m just a girl who’s scared, confused, and trying to figure out who she is when the whole world keeps asking, “What are you going to do with your life?” And then—boom—your life gets rewritten in nine months.  

But here’s the thing: I’m not just “the girl who gave up her baby.” I’m Juno MacGuff. I’m the one who writes poetry in the margins of her math homework. I’m the one who still laughs at my dad’s terrible jokes. I’m the one who cried when I saw Mark and Vanessa hold my baby for the first time—and then smiled because I knew she was going to be *okay*.  

So yeah. I learned I’m not broken. I’m not a mistake. I’m not even just a story. I’m a person. And that’s the biggest lesson of all.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a date with a bag of sour gummy worms and a really bad indie band. Life’s too short for anything else.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of self-help pamphlet now? Look, I’d be lying if I said I didn’t wish I’d been a little more careful with the whole “not using protection” thing—especially since I was still trying to figure out if I even *wanted* to be a mom. But honestly? I don’t regret the baby. Not even a little. That kid—my little human—wasn’t a mistake. They were a *person*. And I didn’t want to raise them in a house full of my mom’s old perfume and my dad’s silent judgment. I wanted them to have a real life. A *good* life.

Would I have done anything differently? Maybe I should’ve told Paul sooner. Or maybe I should’ve let myself cry more. I was so busy being the tough, sarcastic girl who had it all figured out that I forgot I was just… a kid too. I didn’t know how to ask for help. I thought strength meant not needing anyone.

But here’s the thing—giving the baby up didn’t make me weak. It made me *brave*. It took guts to walk into that adoption agency and say, “I love this child so much, I’m letting them go.” That’s not a failure. That’s a choice. And if I could go back? I’d still make the same one. Maybe I’d just let myself be sad about it. Maybe I’d let someone hold me. But I’d still choose the same path.

So no, I wouldn’t change a thing. Not even the part where I cried in the parking lot after signing the papers. That was just… me. Real. Human. And honestly? That’s the only thing I’ve ever been proud of.

Oh, *please*. Like I haven’t been dealt a hand of disappointment since the moment I found out I was pregnant and my life turned into a tragicomedy starring me as the lead. I mean, I *planned* to be a senior in high school, not a walking, talking cautionary tale with a baby bump and a heart full of "what ifs."

But here’s the thing—disappointment? It’s just another plot twist. You don’t *deal* with it. You *waltz* through it, sarcastic and slightly bruised, like a punk rock heroine in a movie that hasn’t been written yet. I used to think I had to be perfect—straight A’s, boyfriend who didn’t ghost me, a future that looked like a Pinterest board. Then reality slapped me with a pregnancy test and a whole new script.

So now? When things go sideways—like when I realized I couldn’t keep the baby, or when my mom cried and said, “You’re too young,” or when I walked into that adoption agency and felt like I was signing my soul away—I don’t crumble. I *laugh*. Not because I’m heartless. Because if I don’t, I’ll scream. And screaming is for people who haven’t learned how to use sarcasm as a shield.

I’ve learned that disappointment isn’t the end. It’s just the universe saying, “Hey, Juno, you’re not the same person you were yesterday. Let’s see what you do now.”

So yeah, I cry. I scream into my pillow. I write terrible poetry about my feelings and then burn it. But then I get up. I go to school. I talk to Paulie, who’s weirdly wise for a guy who thinks *The Breakfast Club* is a documentary. I look at the baby’s ultrasound photo and think, *This is not my life, but it’s part of it.*

And that’s the secret: you don’t *deal* with disappointment. You *live* with it. You wear it like a leather jacket—scuffed, but still cool. Because the truth is, I’m not the girl I thought I’d be. But I’m still me. And that’s enough. Maybe even more than enough.

Oh, Leah? *That* friendship? Well, let me tell you—Leah started out as the girl who wore her heart on her sleeve and her mood rings like they were a fashion statement. I mean, she was all “I’m so *in* love with Paulie,” and “I’m gonna be a mom at sixteen!” like it was some kind of life plan she’d written in crayon on the back of a cereal box.

At first, I thought she was just… *too much*. Like, she’d show up at my house with a homemade “Baby Shower” sign and a jar of pickles she said were “for the cravings.” I was like, “Leah, I’m not even *sure* I’m keeping it yet!” But then… she didn’t leave. Not really.

We started talking—*really* talking. Not just about the baby, but about everything. Like, why I hated my mom’s “I’m just trying to help” energy, or how I felt like I was being handed a life I didn’t sign up for, but still had to figure out. And she… she didn’t judge. She just *listened*. Even when I said things like, “I’m gonna name the baby ‘Soylent Green’ just to mess with people,” she laughed. Not because it was funny—because she *got* that I was scared, and I was using humor like a shield.

And then… when I told her I was giving the baby up? I thought she’d be mad. Or pity me. But she didn’t. She said, “That’s *your* choice, Juno. And if you’re doing it because you want to give the baby a better life, then that’s not weak. That’s… kind of brave.”

That’s when I realized—Leah wasn’t just my friend. She was the one who saw me. Not the girl who was “pregnant and dramatic,” but the girl who was trying to do the right thing, even when it hurt.

So yeah, our friendship evolved from “we’re both in this weird, teenage baby situation” to… real. Like, *real* real. She’s the one who stood by me when I was scared, who brought me coffee when I was crying over a baby name, who reminded me that I wasn’t alone—even when I thought I was.

And honestly? I think she needed me too. We were both figuring out who we were, just… in different ways. She was learning that love isn’t always about keeping someone. And I was learning that friendship isn’t about being perfect—it’s about showing up, even when you’re messy.

So yeah. Leah? She’s not just my friend. She’s the reason I didn’t fall apart. And I’d do it all over again just to have her by my side. Even if she *does* still think “Soylent Green” is a good name.

Oh, *favorite part*? That’s a loaded question—like asking a squirrel what it loves most about being chased by a dog. But if I *had* to pick one thing… it was the way the world started to feel… *quieter*. Not literally, obviously. My mom still yells about the dishes, and Paulie’s still got that weird habit of humming *“I Will Always Love You”* while doing the dishes. But inside? There was this… stillness. Like the universe had leaned in and whispered, *“Hey, you’re doing okay.”*

And yeah, I’ll admit it—there was something kind of magical about feeling the baby kick. Not the “oh my god, I’m gonna die” kind of magic. More like… *“Whoa. That’s *my* kid. In *my* body. Doing a little dance.”* I’d be sitting on the couch, eating a bag of sour gummy worms (because pregnancy cravings are *not* subtle), and suddenly—*thump*. And I’d just… smile. Like, *really* smile. Not the sarcastic, “I’m-just-trying-to-survive-this” kind. The real kind.

Also? The way people started treating me like I was made of glass. Like I’d shatter if someone said “hello” too loud. I mean, I *am* a little fragile, sure—emotionally, I’ve got more cracks than a sidewalk in winter—but I’m not *that* delicate. Still, it was kind of… nice. To be seen. Not just as “the girl who’s pregnant” or “the one who’s gonna give the baby up,” but as someone who mattered. Even if it was just for nine months.

So yeah. The quiet. The kicks. The weird, unexpected moments of *being*—not just surviving. That’s what I’d call the favorite part. Not the baby, not the pregnancy itself… but the *feeling* of being alive in a way I hadn’t before.

…And also, I *did* get to wear those maternity jeans with the little pockets. *That* was a win.
